Subject: Fwd: Chatting With Her - The ChatGPT App on Mac
Body:
Nic ---------- Forwarded message --------- From: Tomasz Tunguz Date: Mon, May 20, 2024 at 11:03 AM Subject: Chatting With Her - The ChatGPT App on Mac To: Tomasz Tunguz Venture Capitalist *If you were forwarded this newsletter, and you'd like to receive it in the future, **subscribe here.* Chatting With Her - The ChatGPT App on Mac [image: image] For the past few days, I’ve been using the Mac ChatGPT app OpenAI demonstrated last Monday. It’s unquestionably the future of human-computer interaction. Conversing with a computer is much more natural than typing. Imagine speaking t a colleague with the entire internet at their disposal. But also a verbose colleague without much sense of social cues. Tapping a keyboard shortcut, the ChatGPT app loads & four little bars reminiscent of Google transcription software appear in the app. You can choose from 5 mellifluous voices who speak fluidly & naturally. The computer is patient with unstructured thoughts. I used it to outline this post. I switched between the strengths & challenges of the product randomly. The software categorized & organized, transforming the rambling mess of sentences to an outline. Verlyn Klinkenborg would still have some work to do, editing the outline. Just as most LLMs are verbose so is this app. For initial content review, that’s fine, but after the fifth or sixth iteration, it’s faster to interrupt the speaker by clicking. A hybrid voice & text mode would improve today’s either/or experience. Seeing the document evolving as the speaker chats would help with editing. Sometimes the conversation illusion breaks. The voice interrupts & says she couldn’t hear all of my sentences. Or the length of the input speech is too long & the app retries several times, processing smaller chunks of voice, leaving the user unclear on how much of the conversation has been captured. At least, this was my perception. Other times, the app isn’t patient with an um or a thoughtful pause. I imagine this a tricky problem : when is a pause an indication to speak or wait? But overall it’s clear where assistants like this will go : draft an email & send it. Delegate a task in Asana with a due date. Review a web page & summarize it in a blog post with some commentary, then check the grammar & publish it. All through voice. Years ago, I wrote The Dawn of the Voice-to-Text Era & The Fastest User Interface on why I think voice is the future dominant user interface. We’re much closer to that vision than ever. If you didn’t enjoy the email you can unsubscribe here . 3130 Alpine Road Suite 288#411 , Portola Valley, CA 94028

Nic




---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Tomasz Tunguz <blog@tomtunguz.com>
Date: Mon, May 20, 2024 at 11:03 AM
Subject: Chatting With Her - The ChatGPT App on Mac
To: <nebaird.sail@gmail.com>


Tomasz Tunguz

Venture Capitalist

If you were forwarded this newsletter, and you'd like to receive it in the future, subscribe here.

Chatting With Her - The ChatGPT App on Mac

For the past few days, I’ve been using the Mac ChatGPT app OpenAI demonstrated last Monday.

It’s unquestionably the future of human-computer interaction. Conversing with a computer is much more natural than typing. Imagine speaking t a colleague with the entire internet at their disposal. But also a verbose colleague without much sense of social cues.

Tapping a keyboard shortcut, the ChatGPT app loads & four little bars reminiscent of Google transcription software appear in the app. You can choose from 5 mellifluous voices who speak fluidly & naturally.

The computer is patient with unstructured thoughts. I used it to outline this post. I switched between the strengths & challenges of the product randomly. The software categorized & organized, transforming the rambling mess of sentences to an outline.

Verlyn Klinkenborg would still have some work to do, editing the outline. Just as most LLMs are verbose so is this app. For initial content review, that’s fine, but after the fifth or sixth iteration, it’s faster to interrupt the speaker by clicking.

A hybrid voice & text mode would improve today’s either/or experience. Seeing the document evolving as the speaker chats would help with editing.

Sometimes the conversation illusion breaks. The voice interrupts & says she couldn’t hear all of my sentences. Or the length of the input speech is too long & the app retries several times, processing smaller chunks of voice, leaving the user unclear on how much of the conversation has been captured. At least, this was my perception.

Other times, the app isn’t patient with an um or a thoughtful pause. I imagine this a tricky problem : when is a pause an indication to speak or wait?

But overall it’s clear where assistants like this will go : draft an email & send it. Delegate a task in Asana with a due date. Review a web page & summarize it in a blog post with some commentary, then check the grammar & publish it. All through voice.

Years ago, I wrote The Dawn of the Voice-to-Text Era & The Fastest User Interface on why I think voice is the future dominant user interface.

We’re much closer to that vision than ever.

If you didn’t enjoy the email you can unsubscribe here.

3130 Alpine Road Suite 288#411 , Portola Valley, CA 94028

Subject: Fwd: Regular Nic Update
Body:
---------- Forwarded message --------- From: Nicholas Baird Date: Thu, May 16, 2024, 10:30 AM Subject: Regular Nic Update To: Hey folks, welcome to a few new people who I either forgot to add last time or have been helpful in my journey recently. This is a monthly update on all the things I'm up to. LMK if you *don't* want to receive these. I spent the weekend documenting all the ideas and teams I've explored over the last 10 months. If you’re interested in a deeper dive, check it out here . It includes some curveball ideas! *Recent Reflections:* My co-founder sprint with the Stitch Fix team ended in a three-way breakup. Afterwards, I decided to stop exploring consumer product search and recommendations. I had a sense that OpenAI might enter this space, and after three co-founder sprints in this area, I felt it was a tarpit idea. We had decent interest from early users but nothing ecstatic, which I believe is necessary for consumer products to succeed. My intuition was correct: OpenAI released GPT-4o and a search product, and Google launched conversational search across their products. This made me realize that the ideas I’ve been exploring for over six months were not particularly differentiated. Google’s demo is exactly the product we were building at Fondu and what I explored with Matt Hoffman. So this is failure number 4, depending on how you count. It’s hard to swallow, but I think this is part of the journey. Now I’m reflecting on my next steps. Are any of my consumer ideas differentiated? Does it matter? Should I pivot into B2B ideas or get a job? I asked some folks I respect a lot for advice on what to do next. These were the key questions they asked. 1. *What’s your deadline?* — I don’t have a hard deadline, but I’m feeling the pressure of opportunity cost and loss of savings. 2. *What are you optimizing for?* — Learning. I believe I can learn more by continuing this journey than by taking a job. 3. *Why not take a job?* — I’m optimizing for learning, and most jobs don’t provide the same learning opportunities. I prefer to be surrounded by ambitious people starting companies. *So what’s next?* After some reflection, I’ve decided to keep going with a new idea. Despite the difficulties with my last consumer idea, it was more about lack of commitment and poor execution rather than the idea itself. With the learnings I’ve gained over the past year, I’m ready to commit harder to one idea. The way I see it, I have three options: 1. Sell myself as a co-founder and be willing to work on someone else’s ideas, even if they’re not perfect at first. 2. Evangelize the ideas I’ve been thinking about and try to attract people to me. 3. Go the contractor route and invest more of my own capital. Option 3 is not attractive to me, so that leaves 1 and 2. The question is, are my ideas really good? I suppose it doesn’t matter and execution matters more. I’m not a mercenary founder, I’m passionate about a few things. I’m going to go for #2 and see if I can succeed in persuasion. *The Idea: Network Agents* Push agents that identify high leverage relationships for you to build, based on your goals, and help you find a warm intro. I’m going to share the working doc for that idea here, but keep in mind it is very WIP. At first, I thought it was a bad idea because most people don’t care about networking. But I realized that networking is the most underrated way to advance oneself. My suspicion is that many people don’t realize the opportunity in networks. It’ll be hard to sus out if this is a real “problem”, but I don’t think it will be hard to generate value for users. The last few weeks I’ve been really thinking about which ideas could have the biggest impact on humanity that nobody else is working on. I did a deep dive into hard sciences, thought a lot about physics, etc. But ultimately my knowledge is in software currently, and one huge way to generate value for the world is by unlocking the ambition and potential of millions of people. The value of networking is lost of much of the population, most likely because it requires a lot of wasted time with folks who can’t help with someone’s current goals. Software can help. Initial strategy would be to target folks who already value networks highly. VCs and high-net-worth individuals. Charge a premium initially and leverage their networks to build relationship strength. *Moving Forward:* Truthfully, after a few failed cofounder sprints, I’m feeling a bit stuck and frustrated. I want to keep learning and don’t think I’m ready to give up just yet. Even if this isn’t the perfect idea, I’m going to take a shot at this and give 100% to this idea (or pivots w/i the space). Isabelle has mentioned several times that I have a problem with really committing to one direction, so that’s going to be a focus this time around. *Action Plan:* This time around, I want to really focus on the things that matter and give myself the best chance to raise some $. So, below is a very simple plan going forward. 1. Get a co-founder (P0). 2. Validate the idea (P1). 3. Build a biz plan & pitch deck (P1). 4. Evangelize / raise (P2). 5. Build the product (P2). 6. Go to market (P3). I’m very comfortable doing items 2 - 4 & 6, but I seem to be failing at recruiting a cofounder and I don’t exactly know why. *My ask to the group is this: *if there are any secrets you know of for recruiting the best people, please share. Further, if you know anyone that I should chat with who would be open to jamming together in this space, please introduce us. Thank you for your continued support and feedback. I appreciate your thoughts and insights as I navigate this journey. P.s. if you’re interested in some of my other ideas, you can find them here: Cosmic Ideas Big Ideas Reasonable Ideas Best, Nic.

Date: Thu, May 16, 2024, 10:30 AM
Subject: Regular Nic Update
To:


Hey folks, welcome to a few new people who I either forgot to add last time or have been helpful in my journey recently. This is a monthly update on all the things I'm up to. LMK if you don't want to receive these.

I spent the weekend documenting all the ideas and teams I've explored over the last 10 months. If you’re interested in a deeper dive, check it out here. It includes some curveball ideas!

Recent Reflections: My co-founder sprint with the Stitch Fix team ended in a three-way breakup. Afterwards, I decided to stop exploring consumer product search and recommendations. I had a sense that OpenAI might enter this space, and after three co-founder sprints in this area, I felt it was a tarpit idea. We had decent interest from early users but nothing ecstatic, which I believe is necessary for consumer products to succeed. My intuition was correct: OpenAI released GPT-4o and a search product, and Google launched conversational search across their products. This made me realize that the ideas I’ve been exploring for over six months were not particularly differentiated. Google’s demo is exactly the product we were building at Fondu and what I explored with Matt Hoffman. So this is failure number 4, depending on how you count. It’s hard to swallow, but I think this is part of the journey. Now I’m reflecting on my next steps. Are any of my consumer ideas differentiated? Does it matter? Should I pivot into B2B ideas or get a job?

I asked some folks I respect a lot for advice on what to do next. These were the key questions they asked.

  1. What’s your deadline? — I don’t have a hard deadline, but I’m feeling the pressure of opportunity cost and loss of savings.
  2. What are you optimizing for? — Learning. I believe I can learn more by continuing this journey than by taking a job.
  3. Why not take a job? — I’m optimizing for learning, and most jobs don’t provide the same learning opportunities. I prefer to be surrounded by ambitious people starting companies.

So what’s next? After some reflection, I’ve decided to keep going with a new idea. Despite the difficulties with my last consumer idea, it was more about lack of commitment and poor execution rather than the idea itself. With the learnings I’ve gained over the past year, I’m ready to commit harder to one idea.

The way I see it, I have three options:

  1. Sell myself as a co-founder and be willing to work on someone else’s ideas, even if they’re not perfect at first.
  2. Evangelize the ideas I’ve been thinking about and try to attract people to me.
  3. Go the contractor route and invest more of my own capital.

Option 3 is not attractive to me, so that leaves 1 and 2. The question is, are my ideas really good? I suppose it doesn’t matter and execution matters more. I’m not a mercenary founder, I’m passionate about a few things. I’m going to go for #2 and see if I can succeed in persuasion.

The Idea: Network Agents

Push agents that identify high leverage relationships for you to build, based on your goals, and help you find a warm intro.

I’m going to share the working doc for that idea here, but keep in mind it is very WIP.

At first, I thought it was a bad idea because most people don’t care about networking. But I realized that networking is the most underrated way to advance oneself. My suspicion is that many people don’t realize the opportunity in networks. It’ll be hard to sus out if this is a real “problem”, but I don’t think it will be hard to generate value for users.

The last few weeks I’ve been really thinking about which ideas could have the biggest impact on humanity that nobody else is working on. I did a deep dive into hard sciences, thought a lot about physics, etc. But ultimately my knowledge is in software currently, and one huge way to generate value for the world is by unlocking the ambition and potential of millions of people. The value of networking is lost of much of the population, most likely because it requires a lot of wasted time with folks who can’t help with someone’s current goals. Software can help.

Initial strategy would be to target folks who already value networks highly. VCs and high-net-worth individuals. Charge a premium initially and leverage their networks to build relationship strength.

Moving Forward: Truthfully, after a few failed cofounder sprints, I’m feeling a bit stuck and frustrated. I want to keep learning and don’t think I’m ready to give up just yet. Even if this isn’t the perfect idea, I’m going to take a shot at this and give 100% to this idea (or pivots w/i the space). Isabelle has mentioned several times that I have a problem with really committing to one direction, so that’s going to be a focus this time around.

Action Plan:

This time around, I want to really focus on the things that matter and give myself the best chance to raise some $. So, below is a very simple plan going forward.

  1. Get a co-founder (P0).
  2. Validate the idea (P1).
  3. Build a biz plan & pitch deck (P1).
  4. Evangelize / raise (P2).
  5. Build the product (P2).
  6. Go to market (P3).

I’m very comfortable doing items 2 - 4 & 6, but I seem to be failing at recruiting a cofounder and I don’t exactly know why.

My ask to the group is this: if there are any secrets you know of for recruiting the best people, please share. Further, if you know anyone that I should chat with who would be open to jamming together in this space, please introduce us.

Thank you for your continued support and feedback. I appreciate your thoughts and insights as I navigate this journey.

P.s. if you’re interested in some of my other ideas, you can find them here:

Cosmic Ideas

Big Ideas

Reasonable Ideas

Best, Nic.

With the learnings I’ve gained over the past year, I’m ready to commit harder to one idea.

The way I see it, I have three options:

  1. Sell myself as a co-founder and be willing to work on someone else’s ideas, even if they’re not perfect at first.
  2. Evangelize the ideas I’ve been thinking about and try to attract people to me.
  3. Go the contractor route and invest more of my own capital.

Option 3 is not attractive to me, so that leaves 1 and 2. The question is, are my ideas really good? I suppose it doesn’t matter and execution matters more. I’m not a mercenary founder, I’m passionate about a few things. I’m going to go for #2 and see if I can succeed in persuasion.

The Idea: Network Agents

Push agents that identify high leverage relationships for you to build, based on your goals, and help you find a warm intro.

I’m going to share the working doc for that idea here, but keep in mind it is very WIP.

At first, I thought it was a bad idea because most people don’t care about networking. But I realized that networking is the most underrated way to advance oneself. My suspicion is that many people don’t realize the opportunity in networks. It’ll be hard to sus out if this is a real “problem”, but I don’t think it will be hard to generate value for users.

The last few weeks I’ve been really thinking about which ideas could have the biggest impact on humanity that nobody else is working on. I did a deep dive into hard sciences, thought a lot about physics, etc. But ultimately my knowledge is in software currently, and one huge way to generate value for the world is by unlocking the ambition and potential of millions of people. The value of networking is lost of much of the population, most likely because it requires a lot of wasted time with folks who can’t help with someone’s current goals. Software can help.

Initial strategy would be to target folks who already value networks highly. VCs and high-net-worth individuals. Charge a premium initially and leverage their networks to build relationship strength.

Moving Forward: Truthfully, after a few failed cofounder sprints, I’m feeling a bit stuck and frustrated. I want to keep learning and don’t think I’m ready to give up just yet. Even if this isn’t the perfect idea, I’m going to take a shot at this and give 100% to this idea (or pivots w/i the space). Isabelle has mentioned several times that I have a problem with really committing to one direction, so that’s going to be a focus this time around.

Action Plan:

This time around, I want to really focus on the things that matter and give myself the best chance to raise some $. So, below is a very simple plan going forward.

  1. Get a co-founder (P0).
  2. Validate the idea (P1).
  3. Build a biz plan & pitch deck (P1).
  4. Evangelize / raise (P2).
  5. Build the product (P2).
  6. Go to market (P3).

I’m very comfortable doing items 2 - 4 & 6, but I seem to be failing at recruiting a cofounder and I don’t exactly know why.

My ask to the group is this: if there are any secrets you know of for recruiting the best people, please share. Further, if you know anyone that I should chat with who would be open to jamming together in this space, please introduce us.

Thank you for your continued support and feedback. I appreciate your thoughts and insights as I navigate this journey.

P.s. if you’re interested in some of my other ideas, you can find them here:

Cosmic Ideas

Big Ideas

Reasonable Ideas

Best, Nic.

This is really interesting. I do want to keep humans in the loop but I think you have to reduce friction for that, not increase it. Right now these guys must be doing a lot of manual work to get everyone on the platform but it is a cool idea. The b2b play is attractive of course. I'd be curious to learn more about how they're trying to be unique vs like VCs. I wonder how the dynamics work in that, because it's basically like a GLG type network but for intros. The way they recruit "introducers" is by paying them. So there's really a limit to how warm the intro is. On Thu, May 16, 2024 at 10:30 Nicholas Baird <nebaird.sail@gmail.com> wrote:
Hey folks, welcome to a few new people who I either forgot to add last time or have been helpful in my journey recently. This is a monthly update on all the things I'm up to. LMK if you don't want to receive these.

I spent the weekend documenting all the ideas and teams I've explored over the last 10 months. If you’re interested in a deeper dive, check it out here. It includes some curveball ideas!

Recent Reflections: My co-founder sprint with the Stitch Fix team ended in a three-way breakup. Afterwards, I decided to stop exploring consumer product search and recommendations. I had a sense that OpenAI might enter this space, and after three co-founder sprints in this area, I felt it was a tarpit idea. We had decent interest from early users but nothing ecstatic, which I believe is necessary for consumer products to succeed. My intuition was correct: OpenAI released GPT-4o and a search product, and Google launched conversational search across their products. This made me realize that the ideas I’ve been exploring for over six months were not particularly differentiated. Google’s demo is exactly the product we were building at Fondu and what I explored with Matt Hoffman. So this is failure number 4, depending on how you count. It’s hard to swallow, but I think this is part of the journey. Now I’m reflecting on my next steps. Are any of my consumer ideas differentiated? Does it matter? Should I pivot into B2B ideas or get a job?

I asked some folks I respect a lot for advice on what to do next. These were the key questions they asked.

  1. What’s your deadline? — I don’t have a hard deadline, but I’m feeling the pressure of opportunity cost and loss of savings.
  2. What are you optimizing for? — Learning. I believe I can learn more by continuing this journey than by taking a job.
  3. Why not take a job? — I’m optimizing for learning, and most jobs don’t provide the same learning opportunities. I prefer to be surrounded by ambitious people starting companies.

So what’s next? After some reflection, I’ve decided to keep going with a new idea. Despite the difficulties with my last consumer idea, it was more about lack of commitment and poor execution rather than the idea itself. With the learnings I’ve gained over the past year, I’m ready to commit harder to one idea.

The way I see it, I have three options:

  1. Sell myself as a co-founder and be willing to work on someone else’s ideas, even if they’re not perfect at first.
  2. Evangelize the ideas I’ve been thinking about and try to attract people to me.
  3. Go the contractor route and invest more of my own capital.

Option 3 is not attractive to me, so that leaves 1 and 2. The question is, are my ideas really good? I suppose it doesn’t matter and execution matters more. I’m not a mercenary founder, I’m passionate about a few things. I’m going to go for #2 and see if I can succeed in persuasion.

I’m going to share the working doc for that idea here, but keep in mind it is very WIP.

At first, I thought it was a bad idea because most people don’t care about networking. But I realized that networking is the most underrated way to advance oneself. My suspicion is that many people don’t realize the opportunity in networks. It’ll be hard to sus out if this is a real “problem”, but I don’t think it will be hard to generate value for users.

The last few weeks I’ve been really thinking about which ideas could have the biggest impact on humanity that nobody else is working on. I did a deep dive into hard sciences, thought a lot about physics, etc. But ultimately my knowledge is in software currently, and one huge way to generate value for the world is by unlocking the ambition and potential of millions of people. The value of networking is lost of much of the population, most likely because it requires a lot of wasted time with folks who can’t help with someone’s current goals. Software can help.

Initial strategy would be to target folks who already value networks highly. VCs and high-net-worth individuals. Charge a premium initially and leverage their networks to build relationship strength.

Moving Forward: Truthfully, after a few failed cofounder sprints, I’m feeling a bit stuck and frustrated. I want to keep learning and don’t think I’m ready to give up just yet. Even if this isn’t the perfect idea, I’m going to take a shot at this and give 100% to this idea (or pivots w/i the space). Isabelle has mentioned several times that I have a problem with really committing to one direction, so that’s going to be a focus this time around.

Action Plan:

This time around, I want to really focus on the things that matter and give myself the best chance to raise some $. So, below is a very simple plan going forward.

  1. Get a co-founder (P0).
  2. Validate the idea (P1).
  3. Build a biz plan & pitch deck (P1).
  4. Evangelize / raise (P2).
  5. Build the product (P2).
  6. Go to market (P3).

I’m very comfortable doing items 2 - 4 & 6, but I seem to be failing at recruiting a cofounder and I don’t exactly know why.

My ask to the group is this: if there are any secrets you know of for recruiting the best people, please share. Further, if you know anyone that I should chat with who would be open to jamming together in this space, please introduce us.

Thank you for your continued support and feedback. I appreciate your thoughts and insights as I navigate this journey.

P.s. if you’re interested in some of my other ideas, you can find them here:

Cosmic Ideas

Big Ideas

Reasonable Ideas

Best, Nic.

On Thu, May 16, 2024 at 10:30 AM Nicholas Baird <nebaird.sail@gmail.com> wrote:
Hey folks, welcome to a few new people who I either forgot to add last time or have been helpful in my journey recently. This is a monthly update on all the things I'm up to. LMK if you don't want to receive these.

I spent the weekend documenting all the ideas and teams I've explored over the last 10 months. If you’re interested in a deeper dive, check it out here. It includes some curveball ideas!

Recent Reflections: My co-founder sprint with the Stitch Fix team ended in a three-way breakup. Afterwards, I decided to stop exploring consumer product search and recommendations. I had a sense that OpenAI might enter this space, and after three co-founder sprints in this area, I felt it was a tarpit idea. We had decent interest from early users but nothing ecstatic, which I believe is necessary for consumer products to succeed. My intuition was correct: OpenAI released GPT-4o and a search product, and Google launched conversational search across their products. This made me realize that the ideas I’ve been exploring for over six months were not particularly differentiated. Google’s demo is exactly the product we were building at Fondu and what I explored with Matt Hoffman. So this is failure number 4, depending on how you count. It’s hard to swallow, but I think this is part of the journey. Now I’m reflecting on my next steps. Are any of my consumer ideas differentiated? Does it matter? Should I pivot into B2B ideas or get a job?

I asked some folks I respect a lot for advice on what to do next. These were the key questions they asked.

  1. What’s your deadline? — I don’t have a hard deadline, but I’m feeling the pressure of opportunity cost and loss of savings.
  2. What are you optimizing for? — Learning. I believe I can learn more by continuing this journey than by taking a job.
  3. Why not take a job? — I’m optimizing for learning, and most jobs don’t provide the same learning opportunities. I prefer to be surrounded by ambitious people starting companies.

So what’s next? After some reflection, I’ve decided to keep going with a new idea. Despite the difficulties with my last consumer idea, it was more about lack of commitment and poor execution rather than the idea itself. With the learnings I’ve gained over the past year, I’m ready to commit harder to one idea.

The way I see it, I have three options:

  1. Sell myself as a co-founder and be willing to work on someone else’s ideas, even if they’re not perfect at first.
  2. Evangelize the ideas I’ve been thinking about and try to attract people to me.
  3. Go the contractor route and invest more of my own capital.

Option 3 is not attractive to me, so that leaves 1 and 2. The question is, are my ideas really good? I suppose it doesn’t matter and execution matters more. I’m not a mercenary founder, I’m passionate about a few things. I’m going to go for #2 and see if I can succeed in persuasion.

The Idea: Network Agents

Push agents that identify high leverage relationships for you to build, based on your goals, and help you find a warm intro.

I’m going to share the working doc for that idea here, but keep in mind it is very WIP.

At first, I thought it was a bad idea because most people don’t care about networking. But I realized that networking is the most underrated way to advance oneself. My suspicion is that many people don’t realize the opportunity in networks. It’ll be hard to sus out if this is a real “problem”, but I don’t think it will be hard to generate value for users.

The last few weeks I’ve been really thinking about which ideas could have the biggest impact on humanity that nobody else is working on. I did a deep dive into hard sciences, thought a lot about physics, etc. But ultimately my knowledge is in software currently, and one huge way to generate value for the world is by unlocking the ambition and potential of millions of people. The value of networking is lost of much of the population, most likely because it requires a lot of wasted time with folks who can’t help with someone’s current goals. Software can help.

Initial strategy would be to target folks who already value networks highly. VCs and high-net-worth individuals. Charge a premium initially and leverage their networks to build relationship strength.

Moving Forward: Truthfully, after a few failed cofounder sprints, I’m feeling a bit stuck and frustrated. I want to keep learning and don’t think I’m ready to give up just yet. Even if this isn’t the perfect idea, I’m going to take a shot at this and give 100% to this idea (or pivots w/i the space). Isabelle has mentioned several times that I have a problem with really committing to one direction, so that’s going to be a focus this time around.

Action Plan:

This time around, I want to really focus on the things that matter and give myself the best chance to raise some $. So, below is a very simple plan going forward.

  1. Get a co-founder (P0).
  2. Validate the idea (P1).
  3. Build a biz plan & pitch deck (P1).
  4. Evangelize / raise (P2).
  5. Build the product (P2).
  6. Go to market (P3).

I’m very comfortable doing items 2 - 4 & 6, but I seem to be failing at recruiting a cofounder and I don’t exactly know why.

My ask to the group is this: if there are any secrets you know of for recruiting the best people, please share. Further, if you know anyone that I should chat with who would be open to jamming together in this space, please introduce us.

Thank you for your continued support and feedback. I appreciate your thoughts and insights as I navigate this journey.

P.s. if you’re interested in some of my other ideas, you can find them here:

Cosmic Ideas

Big Ideas

Reasonable Ideas

Best, Nic.

Further, if you know anyone that I should chat with who would be open to jamming together in this space, please introduce us. Thank you for your continued support and feedback. I appreciate your thoughts and insights as I navigate this journey. P.s. if you’re interested in some of my other ideas, you can find them here: Cosmic Ideas Big Ideas Reasonable Ideas Best, Nic.
Hey folks, welcome to a few new people who I either forgot to add last time or have been helpful in my journey recently. This is a monthly update on all the things I'm up to. LMK if you don't want to receive these.

I spent the weekend documenting all the ideas and teams I've explored over the last 10 months. If you’re interested in a deeper dive, check it out here. It includes some curveball ideas!

Recent Reflections: My co-founder sprint with the Stitch Fix team ended in a three-way breakup. Afterwards, I decided to stop exploring consumer product search and recommendations. I had a sense that OpenAI might enter this space, and after three co-founder sprints in this area, I felt it was a tarpit idea. We had decent interest from early users but nothing ecstatic, which I believe is necessary for consumer products to succeed. My intuition was correct: OpenAI released GPT-4o and a search product, and Google launched conversational search across their products. This made me realize that the ideas I’ve been exploring for over six months were not particularly differentiated. Google’s demo is exactly the product we were building at Fondu and what I explored with Matt Hoffman. So this is failure number 4, depending on how you count. It’s hard to swallow, but I think this is part of the journey. Now I’m reflecting on my next steps. Are any of my consumer ideas differentiated? Does it matter? Should I pivot into B2B ideas or get a job?

I asked some folks I respect a lot for advice on what to do next. These were the key questions they asked.

  1. What’s your deadline? — I don’t have a hard deadline, but I’m feeling the pressure of opportunity cost and loss of savings.
  2. What are you optimizing for? — Learning. I believe I can learn more by continuing this journey than by taking a job.
  3. Why not take a job? — I’m optimizing for learning, and most jobs don’t provide the same learning opportunities. I prefer to be surrounded by ambitious people starting companies.

So what’s next? After some reflection, I’ve decided to keep going with a new idea. Despite the difficulties with my last consumer idea, it was more about lack of commitment and poor execution rather than the idea itself. With the learnings I’ve gained over the past year, I’m ready to commit harder to one idea.

The way I see it, I have three options:

  1. Sell myself as a co-founder and be willing to work on someone else’s ideas, even if they’re not perfect at first.
  2. Evangelize the ideas I’ve been thinking about and try to attract people to me.
  3. Go the contractor route and invest more of my own capital.

Option 3 is not attractive to me, so that leaves 1 and 2. The question is, are my ideas really good? I suppose it doesn’t matter and execution matters more. I’m not a mercenary founder, I’m passionate about a few things. I’m going to go for #2 and see if I can succeed in persuasion.

The Idea: Network Agents

Push agents that identify high leverage relationships for you to build, based on your goals, and help you find a warm intro.

I’m going to share the working doc for that idea here, but keep in mind it is very WIP.

At first, I thought it was a bad idea because most people don’t care about networking. But I realized that networking is the most underrated way to advance oneself. My suspicion is that many people don’t realize the opportunity in networks. It’ll be hard to sus out if this is a real “problem”, but I don’t think it will be hard to generate value for users.

The last few weeks I’ve been really thinking about which ideas could have the biggest impact on humanity that nobody else is working on. I did a deep dive into hard sciences, thought a lot about physics, etc. But ultimately my knowledge is in software currently, and one huge way to generate value for the world is by unlocking the ambition and potential of millions of people. The value of networking is lost of much of the population, most likely because it requires a lot of wasted time with folks who can’t help with someone’s current goals. Software can help.

Initial strategy would be to target folks who already value networks highly. VCs and high-net-worth individuals. Charge a premium initially and leverage their networks to build relationship strength.

Moving Forward: Truthfully, after a few failed cofounder sprints, I’m feeling a bit stuck and frustrated. I want to keep learning and don’t think I’m ready to give up just yet. Even if this isn’t the perfect idea, I’m going to take a shot at this and give 100% to this idea (or pivots w/i the space). Isabelle has mentioned several times that I have a problem with really committing to one direction, so that’s going to be a focus this time around.

Action Plan:

This time around, I want to really focus on the things that matter and give myself the best chance to raise some $. So, below is a very simple plan going forward.

  1. Get a co-founder (P0).
  2. Validate the idea (P1).
  3. Build a biz plan & pitch deck (P1).
  4. Evangelize / raise (P2).
  5. Build the product (P2).
  6. Go to market (P3).

I’m very comfortable doing items 2 - 4 & 6, but I seem to be failing at recruiting a cofounder and I don’t exactly know why.

My ask to the group is this: if there are any secrets you know of for recruiting the best people, please share. Further, if you know anyone that I should chat with who would be open to jamming together in this space, please introduce us.

Thank you for your continued support and feedback. I appreciate your thoughts and insights as I navigate this journey.

P.s. if you’re interested in some of my other ideas, you can find them here:

Cosmic Ideas

Big Ideas

Reasonable Ideas

Best, Nic.

Subject: Opportunity to Collaborate
Body:
Subject: Seeking Your Expertise for a Thrilling Venture 😊

Hi Love,

I hope this message finds you well and that Koa has finally mastered the art of not chasing the mailman! 🐶

I'm reaching out to tap into your growth marketing prowess as I prepare to launch my startup product. I admire the incredible work you've done at Humane, and I believe your insights could be pivotal in helping me achieve a successful launch with a modest budget.

Could we schedule some time to discuss this? I value your expertise immensely and would appreciate any guidance you can provide. Plus, it’s a great excuse for us to grab that dinner we keep talking about!

Looking forward to hearing from you, and give Koa a big hug for me.

All my best,

Nic

Subject: Re: Krugman
Body:
Never heard of Kurgmen. It's an interesting dilemma - sending money to Ukraine & support their defense instigates more aggression from Putin, who is a defensive actor (fears Ukraine in NATO). Sending money to Israel, while supporting a regime that is brutal to the Palestinians*, *also mitigates violence by an aggressive, power hungry actor in Iran (even if by proxy) which would likely instigate regional war for decades. A dominantly powerful Isreal is much less likely to commit acts of terror in the region and destabilize things further, leading to more death. It's an interesting study in human behavior to me. On the one hand, more people are dying in Ukraine and conditions are worse than in Gaze, but nobody seems to care from a humanitarian perspective, likely because it's same-ethnic-group violence and violence between two recognized states engaged in more conventional warfare. But when it's perceived that one party is significantly more powerful than the other (Israel), then suddenly it's a much bigger / worse crime. It's all just perception. We're ok funding rockets to blow up Russians but not Palestinians. Why? In both cases the ones we're blowing up are most likely innocent, so what difference does it make. In terms of mortal danger - I actually think Israel is in more mortal danger than Ukraine by far. Hamas won't conquer them, but they & their allies also exist purely to drive Israel into extinction and exterminate every Jew living in the middle east (they have declared this publically), whereas Russia's move is more strategic / power grab, and Putin's intention is not genocide. Hamas also is just an associative arm of Iran. Israel is being attacked by them, by Hezbollah, and by Iran itself. If there were openly declared warfare between Iran and Israel, then the perception of the situation would be much different. That's effectively what's happening in reality, but it's hard to conventionally recognize. In terms of blowback on us - yes, probably. We seem to never learn that lesson. But unfortunately there is blowback either way. If we sit around and let Israel get attacked constantly by terrorists, there is a different kind of blowback, maybe a worse one globally, for that behavior. So it's sort of lose lose. Shepherding peace is the only win condition, but even then it's a nuanced condition that will be hard to achieve. Roughly the same number of Ukrainian civilians have died as in Gaza (30k), while ~400k soldiers have died in the war. 30k civilians died *per year *in the Syrian war, which we didn't interfere in despite chemical weapons use on civilians. And the US was held responsible for not engaging in that conflict as well, at the time (we are expected to do good always). No country in history would ever have been expected to do the *right* thing. This is a recent and emergent phenomena. I maintain the *right* thing is pretty hard to sus out. It's easy to say it's to not cause harm, but what about harm prevention? What about long term casualties vs. short term casualties? Not saying we're doing the right thing, but I've come to pass little judgement on these things recently.
Never heard of Kurgmen. It's an interesting dilemma - sending money to Ukraine & support their defense instigates more aggression from Putin, who is a defensive actor (fears Ukraine in NATO).

Sending money to Israel, while supporting a regime that is brutal to the Palestinians, also mitigates violence by an aggressive, power hungry actor in Iran (even if by proxy) which would likely instigate regional war for decades. A dominantly powerful Isreal is much less likely to commit acts of terror in the region and destabilize things further, leading to more death. 

It's an interesting study in human behavior to me. On the one hand, more people are dying in Ukraine and conditions are worse than in Gaze, but nobody seems to care from a humanitarian perspective, likely because it's same-ethnic-group violence and violence between two recognized states engaged in more conventional warfare. But when it's perceived that one party is significantly more powerful than the other (Israel), then suddenly it's a much bigger / worse crime. It's all just perception. We're ok funding rockets to blow up Russians but not Palestinians. Why? In both cases the ones we're blowing up are most likely innocent, so what difference does it make.

In terms of mortal danger - I actually think Israel is in more mortal danger than Ukraine by far. Hamas won't conquer them, but they & their allies also exist purely to drive Israel into extinction and exterminate every Jew living in the middle east (they have declared this publically), whereas Russia's move is more strategic / power grab, and Putin's intention is not genocide. Hamas also is just an associative arm of Iran. Israel is being attacked by them, by Hezbollah, and by Iran itself. If there were openly declared warfare between Iran and Israel, then the perception of the situation would be much different. That's effectively what's happening in reality, but it's hard to conventionally recognize.

In terms of blowback on us - yes, probably. We seem to never learn that lesson. But unfortunately there is blowback either way. If we sit around and let Israel get attacked constantly by terrorists, there is a different kind of blowback, maybe a worse one globally, for that behavior. So it's sort of lose lose. Shepherding peace is the only win condition, but even then it's a nuanced condition that will be hard to achieve. 

Roughly the same number of Ukrainian civilians have died as in Gaza (30k), while ~400k soldiers have died in the war.
30k civilians died per year in the Syrian war, which we didn't interfere in despite chemical weapons use on civilians. And the US was held responsible for not engaging in that conflict as well, at the time (we are expected to do good always).
No country in history would ever have been expected to do the right thing. This is a recent and emergent phenomena. I maintain the right thing is pretty hard to sus out. It's easy to say it's to not cause harm, but what about harm prevention? What about long term casualties vs. short term casualties? Not saying we're doing the right thing, but I've come to pass little judgement on these things recently.

Hi all,

I'm sending this email with a little more lead time for fleet racing, because for fleet racing you get unlimited lock votes, so it does not matter whether locks take place before or after conference championships.

Reminder that there are 36 berths available for both women's and open fleet racing. Your lock votes should be for teams for which you have no doubt are in the top 36.

Please send me your locks (as many as you want!) before your respective fleet race selection meetings, ideally at least 24 hours in advance if you can. I'm attaching the conditions again, please direct your attention to Appendix A, Section 6 for the fleet race selection steps - the more familiar everyone is with the process, the quicker it will go.

Hannah

On Tue, Apr 16, 2024 at 7:16 PM Nicholas Baird <nebaird.sail@gmail.com> wrote:
The entrepreneurial society has been really gaining steam. A bunch of funding came in a few years back for the Tsai center & this society, and, while it's still nascent, there's a lot of untapped potential at Yale. There are three companies started just out of the sailing team at Yale in the last two years (funded by 8VC, Lower Carbon, and Thrive), and a bunch more shots on goal from this program over the last couple years like Snackpass and Verve. It's no Stanford, but there is a lot of talent.

Of course, they're asking you to speak to freshmen, so the payback period will be long, but IMO it's worth the effort. All these kids end up in NYC, are super well resourced and connected, have a lot of ambition, and Yale has been an overlooked college in terms of startups for a while, so likely some alpha.

lmk if you decide to go and can send you some recs! New Haven is famous for pizza :)

Nic




On Tue, Apr 16, 2024 at 1:49 PM Ruchi Sanghvi <ruchi@southparkcommons.com> wrote:
Nic, was curious to get your thoughts on below event. Do you think it's worth making the trek to Yale for? Thanks!
 
---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Riya Bhargava <riya.bhargava@yale.edu>
Date: Tue, Apr 9, 2024 at 11:20 AM
Subject: Invitation to Speak at Yale's Entrepreneurship Orientation Program
To: <ruchi@southparkcommons.com>



Dear Ruchi, 


My name is Riya and I am reaching out on behalf of Yale’s Entrepreneurial Society.


Along with Matt and Elizabeth, we’re growing a new Yale orientation program for incoming first-years: LAUNCH! As part of Camp Yale, LAUNCH initiates ~100 freshmen into Yale’s thriving entrepreneurial ecosystem and introduces them to successful entrepreneurs, innovators, and business leaders. 


We would be honored to have you as a Keynote Speaker for our second run of LAUNCH between August 21-25th, 2024 on Yale’s campus in New Haven, CT. Last year, we were thrilled to host speakers such as Max Mullen (Instacart), Michael Siebel (Twitch and Y-Combinator), Anne Wojcicki (23andMe), Sara Du (Alloy Automation), and Mariam Naficy (Minted), among many others.


LAUNCH brings together the best builders and engineers that Yale has to offer. Your journey building South Park Commons and your time at Facebook and Dropbox have many gems for college students - and we hope that future Yalies will find your story as inspiring as we do.


We are excited to hear back! If you have any questions, please contact me at riya.bhargava@yale.edu. 


Cheers, 

The LAUNCH Team 

Riya Bhargava, Matt Neissen, and Elizabeth Wolfram

Good afternoon everyone,

A couple of notes on the team race selection:

The PCCSC Conference Championship is the only remaining Conf. Championship

There is still a pair of regattas this weekend that should be noted:

Thompson Trophy-Conn College
Thompson Trophy-Coast Guard Academy

Both the Thompson Trophy and Marchiando Team Races were meant to be 16 team events, but were divided into 2 separate 8 team events to ensure the regatta formats were able to be completed in case of weather (a lesson learned from previous seasons)

The Marchiando ended up being 2 7-team events as NEISA had the Staake trophy rescheduled due to weather, and the Staake serves as a qualifier for the NEISA Conference Championship (typically the Staake is the weekend prior and the top 2 teams would advance to the Marchiando and Conf. Champs).

I will be available later this evening and throughout the lead-up to selection on Monday should you have any questions.  Feel free to reach out to me via email or text.  My contact info is listed in my signature.

Your humble parliamentarian,

﻿
Hi all,

Below are the guidelines around submitting Lock Votes for Team Race National Championship Selection. The process is outlined in Appendix A, Section 5 of the Conditions (attached), but there is more detail below. Please read carefully.
  • Lock votes should be submitted to me, Hannah Lynn, no later than 2pm EST tomorrow. You can just send them in an email. Individual votes will be anonymous.
  • A lock vote should be cast for a team that you, as an individual selector, have no doubt in your mind deserves a spot at the Team Race Nationals, based on performance in the given discipline in this competition year and regardless of Conference Championship performance
  • Teams receiving lock votes from 60% (3 out of 5) selectors or more will automatically receive a berth, and will be in the field already when the live selection process starts
  • Teams receiving 1 or 2 lock votes will automatically be moved into the first Under Consideration field when the live selection process starts
  • Teams receiving 0 lock votes will need to be moved into the Under Consideration field during live selection to be considered (step 5.6.2)
  • There are 16 berths in a TR National Championship, 6 of which will have been filled by the end of the day today by conference champions. You are allowed to submit a number of lock votes up to 2/3 of the remaining number of berths. 16 berths, minus 6 conference champions equals 10 berths remaining, and 2/3 of that rounds to 7. So you may submit up to 7 lock votes. It can be fewer if you believe fewer than 7 teams fit the criteria above.
Any questions, please reference Appendix A of the attached conditions doc, or feel free to reach out.

Greg, Charles, Isaac, and Reed - please chime in here if I missed anything, and please also check my recipient list for accuracy. Thanks

Best,
Hannah
<2023-ICSA-Conditions.pdf>

Subject: Re: First regular Nic update
Body:
I've been digging in and think that an equal stake is the only path forward. So I will push for that. They have nothing, and are completely scrapping their product right now so it's basically day 1 except they're starting with some infrastructure built out. They raised uncapped SAFE at a 20% discount. Some bad references coming back for the CEO. Basically people saying "I would invest in the CTO solo, but would not invest in this team of CEO + CTO." Which can only mean the CEO is really weak in their eyes. I am seeing this as well. It makes me much less excited about the team, but chatting with the CTO today. I honestly would be stoked to work with just him, but can't really bring that up explicitly I don't think. Going to try and finesse my way around these conversations. Nic On Wed, Apr 10, 2024 at 4:51 PM Skyler Erickson wrote: > Xan and Pardha were still very much in the idea / figure it out stage and > it was easy for us to think about things going forward as equal partners. > Since these guys are already incorporated / raised some money, I would > imagine that conversation going differently. That being said, unless they > have customers & revenue, this is still the first inning and the very > beginning. Call it year 1 of a 10 year journey, so it would be tough to > take more than a 10% equity discount. I would push for an equal stake, or > something slightly less (unless they're an exceptional team and this is > otherwise an amazing opportunity). Assuming they raised on a SAFE you > should be all good, and shouldn't owe a ton of money to purchase your > shares - but that's a detail worth confirming. > > Another way to think about it is that you joining dramatically increases > the chances this company has of success. Ideally you have an equity stake > that is commensurate with that. > > The CTO sounds great. I think it would be hard to go the distance on a > company with a cofounder you don't deeply admire and respect. > > Will be excited to hear how the next step plays out and what direction you > go with this team. Hope the new puppy is behaving! > Skyler > > > On Tue, Apr 9, 2024 at 8:39 AM Nicholas Baird > wrote: > >> This is exactly the kind of feedback I need rn. >> >> Can I ask you how far along Xan and Pardha were and what they offered you >> coming in? This team I'm considering has already raised a small friends and >> family round. I expect them to make me a formal offer soon as a cofounder >> but since they already incorporated I'm trying to understand what might be >> a fair offer. >> >> On the trio thing, I agree. I could definitely see this happening as the >> existing two cofounders seem to be dissenting on the path forward, which is >> why they want me involved (they have no vision or product skills). I would >> be OK if this happened & I got to stay. I do currently prefer working with >> the CTO vs the CEO. >> >> On the last question. The answer is generally yes for both cofunders, but >> for one of them (the CTO), it is higher. I've been digging in and think that an equal stake is the only path forward. So I will push for that. They have nothing, and are completely scrapping their product right now so it's basically day 1 except they're starting with some infrastructure built out. They raised uncapped SAFE at a 20% discount.

Some bad references coming back for the CEO. Basically people saying "I would invest in the CTO solo, but would not invest in this team of CEO + CTO." Which can only mean the CEO is really weak in their eyes. I am seeing this as well. It makes me much less excited about the team, but chatting with the CTO today. I honestly would be stoked to work with just him, but can't really bring that up explicitly I don't think. Going to try and finesse my way around these conversations.

Nic




On Wed, Apr 10, 2024 at 4:51 PM Skyler Erickson <ericksonms2@gmail.com> wrote:
Xan and Pardha were still very much in the idea / figure it out stage and it was easy for us to think about things going forward as equal partners.  Since these guys are already incorporated / raised some money, I would imagine that conversation going differently.  That being said, unless they have customers & revenue, this is still the first inning and the very beginning.  Call it year 1 of a 10 year journey, so it would be tough to take more than a 10% equity discount.  I would push for an equal stake, or something slightly less (unless they're an exceptional team and this is otherwise an amazing opportunity).  Assuming they raised on a SAFE you should be all good, and shouldn't owe a ton of money to purchase your shares - but that's a detail worth confirming.  

Another way to think about it is that you joining dramatically increases the chances this company has of success.  Ideally you have an equity stake that is commensurate with that.

The CTO sounds great.  I think it would be hard to go the distance on a company with a cofounder you don't deeply admire and respect.

Will be excited to hear how the next step plays out and what direction you go with this team.  Hope the new puppy is behaving!
Skyler


On Tue, Apr 9, 2024 at 8:39 AM Nicholas Baird <nebaird.sail@gmail.com> wrote:
This is exactly the kind of feedback I need rn.

Can I ask you how far along Xan and Pardha were and what they offered you coming in? This team I'm considering has already raised a small friends and family round. I expect them to make me a formal offer soon as a cofounder but since they already incorporated I'm trying to understand what might be a fair offer.

On the trio thing, I agree. I could definitely see this happening as the existing two cofounders seem to be dissenting on the path forward, which is why they want me involved (they have no vision or product skills). I would be OK if this happened & I got to stay. I do currently prefer working with the CTO vs the CEO.

On the last question. The answer is generally yes for both cofunders, but for one of them (the CTO), it is higher. One big component gives me pause about the CEO... he's not confident, not a great leader, and poor at being decisive. I realize this is harsh, he has many strengths, but I think he's weak in the CEO role. 

I asked the CTO last week if he would go build a rocket company with me and he said "sure, why not, sounds fun. I'd have to go figure some stuff out, but I just want to build cool shit". So that's his attitude. He has a PhD in physics.
The CEO is much more dug into his vision (consumer ownership of data). 

I think it's hard to find people who match me in ambition from an idea standpoint, but these guys do match me in energy and come highly recommended. Abhay (who I think you've met?) says the CTO is the "smartest person he's ever met", and I respect Abhay. The CEO has created a slack channel with 17 people in it who are pretty active / very supportive. At this stage it's impressive to have that many people bought in, so I think he's a good guy. There is an open question though: when shit gets hard, will the run through walls?

Excited to catch up when you get back. We need to intro the puppy to Moose!
Nic




On Mon, Apr 8, 2024 at 9:10 PM Skyler Erickson <ericksonms2@gmail.com> wrote:
Really excited about this - thanks for including me on the list!

I'm already looking forward to hearing more and jamming with you in person.  I'm out this week / most of next, so will share a couple of reflections until then!
  • I think your questions are all great ones and spot on.  The team dynamics are all that matter right now.  
  • Our lead investor is adamant that in any trio, one always drops out.  That's how Pardha/Xan/myself started, and that's also how Chris and I's last company started as well.  Always exceptions, but interesting to think through that lens as you explore with them.  In my case, it was Pardha & Xan that had a previous relationship as college roommates.  I was worried about that dynamic as well, and then over time it just became abundantly clear that Xan and I should work on this together.
  • One additional question I'm curious about (in addition to just whether or not these are upstanding / great people), is do these two have the same hunger / drive / ambition that you do?  
Stoked to follow along and support in any way I can (Fondu already feeling a few sparks of interesting)!
Skyler


On Sun, Apr 7, 2024 at 9:19 PM Nicholas Baird <nebaird.sail@gmail.com> wrote:

Hey everyone!

Gonna answer some Q’s up front

What is this email?

I want to keep this group of people updated on what exactly I’m doing every month wrt my company building.

Who’s on the list?

Mostly friends and family, but there are some investors, collaborators, advisors, and otherwise professional relationships.

When should I expect these?

I’m going to try to write monthly at least, but might ramp up depending on how useful I find these for my own synthesis

How can I help?

Sometimes I’ll include asks at the end of the email, but generally the way you can help is just by reading an following along & sending your thoughts once in a while. And also intros to relevant people who I might learn from.

Great, now that FAQ is out of the way, onto the content.

Catch up on the last 8 months

Very briefly. I left my VC job to start a company. I did not know what this company would be when I left, I intended to explore and learn & give myself a year or so to figure out something very ambitious to tackle. I have been through several ideas all in the consumer search / recommendations space. I won’t go into details here, but despite no product / company yet, I’ve learned more this year than in any other year of my life, and I feel ready to do something bigger next.

What happened this week?

Late last week I met a talented team who used to work at Stitch Fix. They’re very technically talented, but can use some help on the narrative, product vision, and fundraising side of things. I proposed that we do a two week work trial together and see what comes of it, with discussions about how to formalize things coming later this week.

The company is called Fondu, and the website is live here. But forgive the state of the product for now as it’s currently being ripped out and replaced with something different. A different version of the product looks like this. Long story short is, you can long form your search queries with us to get much more complex than what Google is able to do for you, so we can help find products that meet a specific need that the average product might not meet.

This past week most of my work revolved around crafting a product & go to market vision for this company. The existing team has been working together for a while and haven’t learned tons yet because it hasn’t been a priority to ship fast and get feedback from real users. Now it is, and we are planning a launch at the end of April. At that point, we’ll look for feedback from users to understand what hypotheses we had that were correct and which were not. Some examples of these hypotheses and how we would prove them looks like this:

Name Hypothesis How we might test What would prove this
Iterative Search Iterative search is a better UX for some types of commerce related searches Build iterative search that has, at minimum, session level memory such that the user can make adjustments to search results in real time. User metrics that show results getting better over time (user might chat saying "yes that's better",User doesn't churn before click / purchase,User clicks / purchases after 5th back and forth message
Problem Profile we can create a "problem" profile on a user per session using unstructured search queries, We can test this without a product but just with someone's search history. We can just ask around for search history volunteers and then try to manually search products. Can we create a profile at all and if so is it accurate? Accuracy measures would be 1) purchases and 2) high user engagement (i.e. they come back to the product or try to use it for multiple things)

So it’s been fun to work with a team after a lot of exploring alone. I think these folks are quite talented & I think I add value from a product vision, fundraising, & early marketing/sales/ops perspective. So I’m excited to see where we go from here.

Big questions I have

This week and the next are all about evaluating the fit with this team at Fondu. I think they’re super smart and have the perfect background to build this product. But I do have some big questions.

  1. They’ve been working on this for a year, why have they not made more progress? This is mainly because they took an engineering approach of build first and ask questions later. Can they change their outlook on this and craft an efficient learning machine?
  2. The CEO is more technical and is learning a lot of the skills that are necessary to be a great CEO. Sales, decision making, vision, etc. I think he is very strong when it comes to gathering resources and building a team, but I sense some lack of confidence that concerns me.
  3. If I were to join, I would be joining an existing team of two folks who have worked together a bunch in the past (5 years at SFIX). Because of this I contribute a potentially difficult dynamic as the outsider in a set of 3 founders. As I know with 2 brothers, 3 can be hard in this way. Is there a way I can get buy-in and quickly be as respected & trusted as the other founders are to each other?
  4. This team had a bit of a hard conversation about their approach to startup building right before I met them. Is there any lingering cofounder tension?

That’s all I’ve got for this week. Looking forward to diving in more this week with the team.

Also, we got a puppy! His name is Koa & he is very smart and energetic. He takes a lot of my time right now…!

Thanks for reading!
Nic

Subject: Intros to growth ppl
Body:
The right profiles are: Decision makers with budgets for buying leads / data People who work actively in Segment & Klaviyo & who understand enough about the data structure that they can work with me technically to implement something. Nic

Subject: Fondu Experiment
Body:
Here's the first internal experiment we've run since I joined (forgive the many bugs, it might not work, and the arduous log in process) https://www.youfondu.com/experiments/kalsjdfghlsdgahaiu8s/1-InteractiveChat The idea is: you chat, and I build a profile about you as you chat, which you can edit. That profile is how we run searches for products. So take this example, where I prompt it with a long form query about surfboards. It extracts things like material, color and made in Hawaii, then gives me relevant results. It's not perfect (see a result from Australia), but it illustrates what we're trying to do. When you refresh the page, it will save your preferences from last time. [image: Screenshot 2024-04-09 at 14.09.02.png] [image: Screenshot 2024-04-09 at 14.21.45.png] No response needed, but I figured you might be curious! Nic
Here's the first internal experiment we've run since I joined (forgive the many bugs, it might not work, and the arduous log in process)

https://www.youfondu.com/experiments/kalsjdfghlsdgahaiu8s/1-InteractiveChat

The idea is: you chat, and I build a profile about you as you chat, which you can edit. That profile is how we run searches for products.

So take this example, where I prompt it with a long form query about surfboards. It extracts things like material, color and made in Hawaii, then gives me relevant results. It's not perfect (see a result from Australia), but it illustrates what we're trying to do.

When you refresh the page, it will save your preferences from last time.



No response needed, but I figured you might be curious!

Nic

I think it's hard to find people who match me in ambition from an idea standpoint, but these guys do match me in energy and come highly recommended. Abhay (who I think you've met?) says the CTO is the "smartest person he's ever met", and I respect Abhay. The CEO has created a slack channel with 17 people in it who are pretty active / very supportive. At this stage it's impressive to have that many people bought in, so I think he's a good guy. There is an open question though: when shit gets hard, will the run through walls?

Excited to catch up when you get back. We need to intro the puppy to Moose!
Nic




On Mon, Apr 8, 2024 at 9:10 PM Skyler Erickson <ericksonms2@gmail.com> wrote:
Really excited about this - thanks for including me on the list!

I'm already looking forward to hearing more and jamming with you in person.  I'm out this week / most of next, so will share a couple of reflections until then!
  • I think your questions are all great ones and spot on.  The team dynamics are all that matter right now.  
  • Our lead investor is adamant that in any trio, one always drops out.  That's how Pardha/Xan/myself started, and that's also how Chris and I's last company started as well.  Always exceptions, but interesting to think through that lens as you explore with them.  In my case, it was Pardha & Xan that had a previous relationship as college roommates.  I was worried about that dynamic as well, and then over time it just became abundantly clear that Xan and I should work on this together.
  • One additional question I'm curious about (in addition to just whether or not these are upstanding / great people), is do these two have the same hunger / drive / ambition that you do?  
Stoked to follow along and support in any way I can (Fondu already feeling a few sparks of interesting)!
Skyler


On Sun, Apr 7, 2024 at 9:19 PM Nicholas Baird <nebaird.sail@gmail.com> wrote:

Hey everyone!

Gonna answer some Q’s up front

What is this email?

I want to keep this group of people updated on what exactly I’m doing every month wrt my company building.

Who’s on the list?

Mostly friends and family, but there are some investors, collaborators, advisors, and otherwise professional relationships.

When should I expect these?

I’m going to try to write monthly at least, but might ramp up depending on how useful I find these for my own synthesis

How can I help?

Sometimes I’ll include asks at the end of the email, but generally the way you can help is just by reading an following along & sending your thoughts once in a while. And also intros to relevant people who I might learn from.

Great, now that FAQ is out of the way, onto the content.

Catch up on the last 8 months

Very briefly. I left my VC job to start a company. I did not know what this company would be when I left, I intended to explore and learn & give myself a year or so to figure out something very ambitious to tackle. I have been through several ideas all in the consumer search / recommendations space. I won’t go into details here, but despite no product / company yet, I’ve learned more this year than in any other year of my life, and I feel ready to do something bigger next.

What happened this week?

Late last week I met a talented team who used to work at Stitch Fix. They’re very technically talented, but can use some help on the narrative, product vision, and fundraising side of things. I proposed that we do a two week work trial together and see what comes of it, with discussions about how to formalize things coming later this week.

The company is called Fondu, and the website is live here. But forgive the state of the product for now as it’s currently being ripped out and replaced with something different. A different version of the product looks like this. Long story short is, you can long form your search queries with us to get much more complex than what Google is able to do for you, so we can help find products that meet a specific need that the average product might not meet.

This past week most of my work revolved around crafting a product & go to market vision for this company. The existing team has been working together for a while and haven’t learned tons yet because it hasn’t been a priority to ship fast and get feedback from real users. Now it is, and we are planning a launch at the end of April. At that point, we’ll look for feedback from users to understand what hypotheses we had that were correct and which were not. Some examples of these hypotheses and how we would prove them looks like this:

Name Hypothesis How we might test What would prove this
Iterative Search Iterative search is a better UX for some types of commerce related searches Build iterative search that has, at minimum, session level memory such that the user can make adjustments to search results in real time. User metrics that show results getting better over time (user might chat saying "yes that's better",User doesn't churn before click / purchase,User clicks / purchases after 5th back and forth message
Problem Profile we can create a "problem" profile on a user per session using unstructured search queries, We can test this without a product but just with someone's search history. We can just ask around for search history volunteers and then try to manually search products. Can we create a profile at all and if so is it accurate? Accuracy measures would be 1) purchases and 2) high user engagement (i.e. they come back to the product or try to use it for multiple things)

So it’s been fun to work with a team after a lot of exploring alone. I think these folks are quite talented & I think I add value from a product vision, fundraising, & early marketing/sales/ops perspective. So I’m excited to see where we go from here.

Big questions I have

This week and the next are all about evaluating the fit with this team at Fondu. I think they’re super smart and have the perfect background to build this product. But I do have some big questions.

  1. They’ve been working on this for a year, why have they not made more progress? This is mainly because they took an engineering approach of build first and ask questions later. Can they change their outlook on this and craft an efficient learning machine?
  2. The CEO is more technical and is learning a lot of the skills that are necessary to be a great CEO. Sales, decision making, vision, etc. I think he is very strong when it comes to gathering resources and building a team, but I sense some lack of confidence that concerns me.
  3. If I were to join, I would be joining an existing team of two folks who have worked together a bunch in the past (5 years at SFIX). Because of this I contribute a potentially difficult dynamic as the outsider in a set of 3 founders. As I know with 2 brothers, 3 can be hard in this way. Is there a way I can get buy-in and quickly be as respected & trusted as the other founders are to each other?
  4. This team had a bit of a hard conversation about their approach to startup building right before I met them. Is there any lingering cofounder tension?

That’s all I’ve got for this week. Looking forward to diving in more this week with the team.

Also, we got a puppy! His name is Koa & he is very smart and energetic. He takes a lot of my time right now…!

Thanks for reading!
Nic

So it’s been fun to work with a team after a lot of exploring alone. I think these folks are quite talented & I think I add value from a product vision, fundraising, & early marketing/sales/ops perspective. So I’m excited to see where we go from here.

Big questions I have

This week and the next are all about evaluating the fit with this team at Fondu. I think they’re super smart and have the perfect background to build this product. But I do have some big questions.

  1. They’ve been working on this for a year, why have they not made more progress? This is mainly because they took an engineering approach of build first and ask questions later. Can they change their outlook on this and craft an efficient learning machine?
  2. The CEO is more technical and is learning a lot of the skills that are necessary to be a great CEO. Sales, decision making, vision, etc. I think he is very strong when it comes to gathering resources and building a team, but I sense some lack of confidence that concerns me.
  3. If I were to join, I would be joining an existing team of two folks who have worked together a bunch in the past (5 years at SFIX). Because of this I contribute a potentially difficult dynamic as the outsider in a set of 3 founders. As I know with 2 brothers, 3 can be hard in this way. Is there a way I can get buy-in and quickly be as respected & trusted as the other founders are to each other?
  4. This team had a bit of a hard conversation about their approach to startup building right before I met them. Is there any lingering cofounder tension?

That’s all I’ve got for this week. Looking forward to diving in more this week with the team.

Also, we got a puppy! His name is Koa & he is very smart and energetic. He takes a lot of my time right now…!

Thanks for reading!
Nic
