Subject: First regular Nic update
Body:
Hey everyone! Gonna answer some Q’s up front *What is this email?* I want to keep this group of people updated on what exactly I’m doing every month wrt my company building. *Who’s on the list?* Mostly friends and family, but there are some investors, collaborators, advisors, and otherwise professional relationships. *When should I expect these?* I’m going to try to write monthly at least, but might ramp up depending on how useful I find these for my own synthesis *How can I help?* Sometimes I’ll include asks at the end of the email, but generally the way you can help is just by reading an following along & sending your thoughts once in a while. And also intros to relevant people who I might learn from. Great, now that FAQ is out of the way, onto the content. Catch up on the last 8 months Very briefly. I left my VC job to start a company. I did not know what this company would be when I left, I intended to explore and learn & give myself a year or so to figure out something very ambitious to tackle. I have been through several ideas all in the consumer search / recommendations space. I won’t go into details here, but despite no product / company yet, I’ve learned more this year than in any other year of my life, and I feel ready to do something bigger next. What happened this week? Late last week I met a talented team who used to work at Stitch Fix. They’re very technically talented, but can use some help on the narrative, product vision, and fundraising side of things. I proposed that we do a two week work trial together and see what comes of it, with discussions about how to formalize things coming later this week. The company is called Fondu, and the website is live here . But forgive the state of the product for now as it’s currently being ripped out and replaced with something different. A different version of the product looks like this . Long story short is, you can long form your search queries with us to get much more complex than what Google is able to do for you, so we can help find products that meet a specific need that the average product might not meet. This past week most of my work revolved around crafting a product & go to market vision for this company. The existing team has been working together for a while and haven’t learned *tons* yet because it hasn’t been a priority to ship fast and get feedback from real users. Now it is, and we are planning a launch at the end of April. At that point, we’ll look for feedback from users to understand what hypotheses we had that were correct and which were not. Some examples of these hypotheses and how we would prove them looks like this: Name Hypothesis How we might test What would prove this Iterative Search Iterative search is a better UX for some types of commerce related searches Build iterative search that has, at minimum, session level memory such that the user can make adjustments to search results in real time. User metrics that show results getting better over time (user might chat saying "yes that's better",User doesn't churn before click / purchase,User clicks / purchases after 5th back and forth message Problem Profile we can create a "problem" profile on a user per session using unstructured search queries, We can test this without a product but just with someone's search history. We can just ask around for search history volunteers and then try to manually search products. Can we create a profile at all and if so is it accurate? Accuracy measures would be 1) purchases and 2) high user engagement (i.e. they come back to the product or try to use it for multiple things) So it’s been fun to work with a team after a lot of exploring alone. I think these folks are quite talented & I think I add value from a product vision, fundraising, & early marketing/sales/ops perspective. So I’m excited to see where we go from here. Big questions I have This week and the next are all about evaluating the fit with this team at Fondu. I think they’re super smart and have the perfect background to build this product. But I do have some big questions. 1. They’ve been working on this for a year, why have they not made more progress? This is mainly because they took an engineering approach of build first and ask questions later. Can they change their outlook on this and craft an efficient learning machine? 2. The CEO is more technical and is learning a lot of the skills that are necessary to be a great CEO. Sales, decision making, vision, etc. I think he is very strong when it comes to gathering resources and building a team, but I sense some lack of confidence that concerns me. 3. If I were to join, I would be joining an existing team of two folks who have worked together a bunch in the past (5 years at SFIX). Because of this I contribute a potentially difficult dynamic as the outsider in a set of 3 founders. As I know with 2 brothers, 3 can be hard in this way. Is there a way I can get buy-in and quickly be as respected & trusted as the other founders are to each other? 4. This team had a bit of a hard conversation about their approach to startup building right before I met them. Is there any lingering cofounder tension? That’s all I’ve got for this week. Looking forward to diving in more this week with the team. Also, we got a puppy! His name is Koa & he is very smart and energetic. He takes a lot of my time right now…! [image: PHOTO-2024-03-31-01-09-18.jpg] Thanks for reading! Nic

Hey everyone!

Gonna answer some Q’s up front

What is this email?

I want to keep this group of people updated on what exactly I’m doing every month wrt my company building.

Who’s on the list?

Mostly friends and family, but there are some investors, collaborators, advisors, and otherwise professional relationships.

When should I expect these?

I’m going to try to write monthly at least, but might ramp up depending on how useful I find these for my own synthesis

How can I help?

Sometimes I’ll include asks at the end of the email, but generally the way you can help is just by reading an following along & sending your thoughts once in a while. And also intros to relevant people who I might learn from.

Great, now that FAQ is out of the way, onto the content.

Catch up on the last 8 months

Very briefly. I left my VC job to start a company. I did not know what this company would be when I left, I intended to explore and learn & give myself a year or so to figure out something very ambitious to tackle. I have been through several ideas all in the consumer search / recommendations space. I won’t go into details here, but despite no product / company yet, I’ve learned more this year than in any other year of my life, and I feel ready to do something bigger next.

What happened this week?

Late last week I met a talented team who used to work at Stitch Fix. They’re very technically talented, but can use some help on the narrative, product vision, and fundraising side of things. I proposed that we do a two week work trial together and see what comes of it, with discussions about how to formalize things coming later this week.

The company is called Fondu, and the website is live here. But forgive the state of the product for now as it’s currently being ripped out and replaced with something different. A different version of the product looks like this. Long story short is, you can long form your search queries with us to get much more complex than what Google is able to do for you, so we can help find products that meet a specific need that the average product might not meet.

This past week most of my work revolved around crafting a product & go to market vision for this company. The existing team has been working together for a while and haven’t learned tons yet because it hasn’t been a priority to ship fast and get feedback from real users. Now it is, and we are planning a launch at the end of April. At that point, we’ll look for feedback from users to understand what hypotheses we had that were correct and which were not. Some examples of these hypotheses and how we would prove them looks like this:

Name Hypothesis How we might test What would prove this
Iterative Search Iterative search is a better UX for some types of commerce related searches Build iterative search that has, at minimum, session level memory such that the user can make adjustments to search results in real time. User metrics that show results getting better over time (user might chat saying "yes that's better",User doesn't churn before click / purchase,User clicks / purchases after 5th back and forth message
Problem Profile we can create a "problem" profile on a user per session using unstructured search queries, We can test this without a product but just with someone's search history. We can just ask around for search history volunteers and then try to manually search products. Can we create a profile at all and if so is it accurate? Accuracy measures would be 1) purchases and 2) high user engagement (i.e. they come back to the product or try to use it for multiple things)

So it’s been fun to work with a team after a lot of exploring alone. I think these folks are quite talented & I think I add value from a product vision, fundraising, & early marketing/sales/ops perspective. So I’m excited to see where we go from here.

Big questions I have

This week and the next are all about evaluating the fit with this team at Fondu. I think they’re super smart and have the perfect background to build this product. But I do have some big questions.

  1. They’ve been working on this for a year, why have they not made more progress? This is mainly because they took an engineering approach of build first and ask questions later. Can they change their outlook on this and craft an efficient learning machine?
  2. The CEO is more technical and is learning a lot of the skills that are necessary to be a great CEO. Sales, decision making, vision, etc. I think he is very strong when it comes to gathering resources and building a team, but I sense some lack of confidence that concerns me.
  3. If I were to join, I would be joining an existing team of two folks who have worked together a bunch in the past (5 years at SFIX). Because of this I contribute a potentially difficult dynamic as the outsider in a set of 3 founders. As I know with 2 brothers, 3 can be hard in this way. Is there a way I can get buy-in and quickly be as respected & trusted as the other founders are to each other?
  4. This team had a bit of a hard conversation about their approach to startup building right before I met them. Is there any lingering cofounder tension?

That’s all I’ve got for this week. Looking forward to diving in more this week with the team.

Also, we got a puppy! His name is Koa & he is very smart and energetic. He takes a lot of my time right now…!

Thanks for reading!
Nic

Rarely available is this incredibly unique property located just steps from the town of Ross, CA. Originally built in 1908 and situated on a level, double parcel are these two stately homes creating a true compound. The entire property was restored and renovated by Polsky Perlstein Architects and BK Interior Design and was completed in 2019.

Enter through the formal foyer and you are welcomed by high ceilings and period details throughout including french-oak herringbone wood flooring, gorgeous moldings and custom lighting. The main living area flows openly from the living room to the kitchen and dining areas with gorgeous doors that open on to stone patios, the grounds and to the pool. The kitchen, which opens to the dining area, consists of custom millwork, marble countertops, a copper hood and high end appliances.

The primary suite is located on the main level and features a walk-in closet, additional dedicated closet space and a five-piece primary bath with marble counter tops, waterworks tile and fixtures. There is also a half bath on this level.

Ascend the stairway to the upper level where there are three full bedrooms and two bathrooms (one bedroom is en-suite). A pitched roof and gables are reminiscent of a home on the east coast. There is an additional bonus room on this level, currently used as a home gym.

Across the stone patios and adjacent to the pool is the second home. French doors lead to a gorgeous living room just off the pool complete with a stone-clad fireplace and a wet bar. There is a convenient full bath on this level. Upstairs there is a second living space which serves as a terrific family room. There are two additional bedrooms and a full bath on this level as well.

To the rear of this second home is a fully appointed, one bedroom apartment which features a complete kitchen, living room also with its’ own fireplace, dedicated laundry and a private bedroom.

The property is fully fenced and gated, and is surrounded by mature landscape for a true estate-like, private feel. There are multiple storage areas, security gates and ample off street parking.

Showings are available exclusively by appointment.

Subject: Fwd:
Body:
Nic ---------- Forwarded message --------- From: Nicholas Baird Date: Tue, Mar 19, 2024 at 10:23 AM Subject: To: Cole Smith *BUILDING STRONG RELATIONSHIPS* - *How should founders interact with investors?* *High level advice: Don't be afraid to ask.* - VCs get pretty good at saying no to requests from portfolio companies (or they'll find another person on their team to help you instead). A good rule of thumb is to let an investor do the filtering on what's too much work. - That said, every investor has a different philosophy: some investors are strictly seeking option value. For example, a Series A fund may participate in a seed round just for the opportunity to make a future investment. There are other funds that spray and pray (making lots of investments, even without conviction). In this case, your investor may be less engaged. - SPC is a high conviction, high ownership fund. SPC only leads or co-leads rounds, because the expectation is that once a partner makes an investment, they treat themselves as a member of the founding team. They’re on board to serve and help you. - *What makes for a good relationship?* The best investor-founder relationships are the ones where there's a high degree of trust and frequent collaboration. Yes there's a power dynamic between investors and founders; but after investment, investors want to make their money work. As an investor, I want to be treated as a member of the founding team. There's no such thing as asking too much, or overloading me. Your investor should know everything that's happening at the company, and should know enough to jump in if they had to (even though they're not involved in the day-to-day). Don't be worried about impressing them. Trust and transparency first. The healthiest relationships have almost complete transparency. - *How to know if your relationship has gone awry?* If a founder always communicates that everything is roses, then an investor knows that: 1) there is a lack of mutual trust; 2) the founder is scared of the investor; or 3) the founder is not being honest with themselves (i.e. avoiding the pain of reality). All of these are red flags. On the flip side, a good investor should have your back. They’re part of the company. If they’re not with you for the whole ride (the good and the bad), they're not a true partner. You shouldn’t need to worry about sharing the failures with them. The version of the company they present to the world will be the version that they'd want presented if they were the founders. Here are some specific signs that an investor is not pulling weight: - They’re not putting in time. Don’t expect an investor to drop everything (they also have lives), but responses should not be several days late… You should expect normal email protocol. - You never have conversations that feel high bandwidth. At some point, you should be discussing core issues with your investor, not the surface-level issues that every company needs to figure out. It's a good sign if it feels like a collaborative relationship, with problem-solving at the earliest stages. - *If you think an investor's instincts are off, how/when to communicate this?* Immediately. Investors have a lot of ideas, and they are used to spouting off. They need to go a mile wide and an inch deep; they're good at pattern matching across industries. But the founder knows a lot more about their own company. Post-funding, if you're the CEO, you almost have an obligation to correct your investors’ instincts. The situation may be different pre-funding... But generally investors respect founders who are comfortable pushing back, as long as they're respectful. If a founder has a strong point of view about their own domain, I respect their priors (even for domains that I think I know well). Even today, when I meet a company in a space I've operated in, my default is that all my information is old or out-dated. I enter with a point of view, but I’m open to being shown otherwise. Investors who think they know more than the startup are likely arrogant. For an investor, a good philosophy is that if a founder has a strong point of view, the default is that they're right (until you can prove that they're wrong). - *How does the founder-investor relationship change over time?* The most successful long-term relationships are ones with a human bond. Where the founder and investor genuinely have an interest in each other’s success (something that transcends the business value of success). You both want the product to succeed, and you want the people involved to get some reward. This doesn’t happen with every relationship. Over the longer-term, you also develop a sense of the other person’s strengths and weaknesses — e.g. where they’re most effective. You’ll know when to reach out to each other for different problems or opportunities. This is not always obvious *a priori*, especially when first making an investment. It’s builds, based on the level of comfort in the relationship. *RELATIONSHIP MAINTENANCE* - *What’s the best way to share updates with investors?* Good investors will read all the reports sent by portfolio companies, and will even reply. Most updates have an ask, and investors will try to chime and help. Here are a few best practices: - Use the same format each time, to maintain flow across updates. - Bucket your content into what’s going well (i.e., where we’re winning); what’s not going well (i.e. where we’re losing, where investors can help); and some of your longer-term thinking. - The longer-term thinking might spark ideas for investors -- e.g. who should I make an intro to for this founder? - Check out: Investor Updates for a template. - *How to prioritize the company’s needs over investor updates?* Prioritizing day-to-day is more art than science. The tricky part about being a CEO is the duality of having to deal with the thorniest/most ambiguous stuff (if you’ve hired well, other people will handle the more straightforward stuff), while also being the fulcrum for the cadence of the company (like leading all-hands, running board meetings, keeping the pulse). You can’t afford to give up your role in setting and maintaining pace. You have to take care of fires while keeping the overall structure in place. There will always be issues that threaten your routines -- every week. But you can’t let that disrupt the flow. Some guidelines: - Never cancel a board meeting. - Never cancel an all-hands. There’s nothing more important than communicating with your team. - Never cancel a regular meeting with your executives. It may be OK to cancel a 1:1 if you need to put out a fire. But there are disciplines you need to keep. You need to balance short-term fires with maintaining the company’s structure and cadence. - *What is something most founders obsess about, that turns out to not matter that much?* When it comes to relationships with investors, founders often obsess about coming off as having everything under control, all the time. True leadership means acknowledging what you don't know, and that the startup journey is an experiment (with ebbs and flows). Investors who have been operators will already understand this. By the way, it's obvious when things are not going well. Don't put on a brave face. It's healthier for you and the relationship to be honest. - *How do investors view internal conflicts, e.g. when there are strong but divergent convictions within a company?* Every company needs an individual responsible for big decisions. The principle needs to be “*we disagree, but commit*.” This could be CEO’s role, but there always needs to be someone whose job is to make the final decision. - It’s poisonous for a company when people disagree but don’t commit; then you get passive aggression and open conflict. - Even when there are two co-founders, you always need the CEO to make a decision and move on. You can’t keep pursuing consensus. As an investor, no opinion should count more than the CEO’s. Investors might provide capital and serve as advisors, but it’s not their company. Investors can’t force the firm to wait before raising the next round, or avoid a specific co-investor. They should support whatever the CEO decides. Investors do have a voice, and they want to be listened to -- but the best ones are humble, and just provide the advice. *COMMUNICATING PRE-INVESTMENT* - *How should founders approach investors with an investment opportunity?* There is a different relationship between an entrepreneur and an investor before a funding commitment is made. Before an investment, investors want to hear from founders at most once per month. Honestly not much happens in a month, no matter how quickly a company is moving. Of course a good investor will never turn down an offer to get more information; information is power. At the same time, there are three problems with communication: 1. It takes time to digest information. When you haven't committed to helping a company, getting too many updates can feel like overload. 2. It takes effort to process updates that are poorly written. This can make it feel like the entrepreneur is lazy. 3. Too much communication comes across as desperate. There are also entrepreneurs that try to get VCs to do work for them, as a power play. But for everyone, the most precious commodity is time. - *At what stage should SPC members come talk to the SPC Fund?* Once you join SPC, there’s a commitment we make to each other -- a commitment to help out. With many of SPC’s investments in member companies, the relationship between the fund partner and the company started well before investment. One of the partners will have spent time brainstorming and regularly jamming with the founders. SPC partners also play a role as members of the community, giving feedback to others. If one of us is slammed, we might refer you to another partner. But members should err on the side of hanging out, spending time, getting feedback.
📖 Check out our fundraise resources:
💡 SPC Fund partners hold weekly office hours for members. This is a great starting point for an early conversation about fundraising or a practice pitch. Ping @Danh Trang for details.
💬 Schedule an Unofficial Board Meeting with SPC partners. Ping @Arian Agrawal for details.
👥 Come join our next quarterly “Fundraising Lunch + Learn” in NY or SF. Ping @Arian Agrawal and @Evan Tana for details.
- *If you're getting pursued by an investor while at SPC, what's the best way to interact?* Regardless of the “quality” of an investor, most good VCs will want you to have a strong idea when they meet with you — something that's worth pursuing. So, chats with investors are the most interesting and useful when you're focused on an idea and ready for feedback. - You should be poised to discuss and ask about your target markets, and whether they make sense. - It's not crazy to meet for coffee earlier on, but if it's a completely undirected conversation (and a low-strength connection), it's easy to waste your time. Also, the investors who are most anxious to get involved at the earliest stages may not end up being strategic partners. Most “good” VCs are not pursuing random outreach. They tend to be more directed and systematic, especially if they’re a Series A/B firm. More venerable firms ask their junior associates to learn by cutting small checks. But in this case, you won't get much input from the senior partner at that firm. A general note: capital for ventures is in abundance, and no good idea will go unfunded. Don't feel anxiety about access to capital; worry about whether what you’re working on is a good idea. - *How can you tell if you’ve got investor-founder fit?* - Remember, you are partnering not with the brand name of the firm, but with the partner. This should be someone you can trust, because ultimately your interface to the firm is the partner. And it sucks if you’re just one of the 30 companies in a partner’s stack (especially if you’re at the bottom of the pile). - When you're selecting an investor: if you don't feel like you have transparency, then you need to think twice. Find somebody you feel a connection to, and someone who will spend time on your company. - In addition to the sense of connection and transparency, consider the partner’s relevant investing and/or operating experience in the area that you’re building. - What’s the investor’s slope in understanding your market? Are they asking you meaningful questions that help inflect your understanding or are they mostly surface-level questions? As much as investors want you to think they’re the “make or break”, ultimately it’s up to you. Investors can play a role, but you shouldn’t need to spend time worrying what your investor thinks. You need to trust that they’re on your team and will help out when you need it. Nic

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Nicholas Baird <nebaird.sail@gmail.com>
Date: Tue, Mar 19, 2024 at 10:23 AM
Subject:
To: Cole Smith <cole.s.smith1@gmail.com>


BUILDING STRONG RELATIONSHIPS

  • How should founders interact with investors?

    High level advice: Don't be afraid to ask.

    • VCs get pretty good at saying no to requests from portfolio companies (or they'll find another person on their team to help you instead). A good rule of thumb is to let an investor do the filtering on what's too much work.
    • That said, every investor has a different philosophy: some investors are strictly seeking option value. For example, a Series A fund may participate in a seed round just for the opportunity to make a future investment. There are other funds that spray and pray (making lots of investments, even without conviction). In this case, your investor may be less engaged.
    • SPC is a high conviction, high ownership fund. SPC only leads or co-leads rounds, because the expectation is that once a partner makes an investment, they treat themselves as a member of the founding team. They’re on board to serve and help you.

  • What makes for a good relationship?

    The best investor-founder relationships are the ones where there's a high degree of trust and frequent collaboration. Yes there's a power dynamic between investors and founders; but after investment, investors want to make their money work. As an investor, I want to be treated as a member of the founding team. There's no such thing as asking too much, or overloading me.

    Your investor should know everything that's happening at the company, and should know enough to jump in if they had to (even though they're not involved in the day-to-day). Don't be worried about impressing them. Trust and transparency first. The healthiest relationships have almost complete transparency.

  • How to know if your relationship has gone awry?

    If a founder always communicates that everything is roses, then an investor knows that: 1) there is a lack of mutual trust; 2) the founder is scared of the investor; or 3) the founder is not being honest with themselves (i.e. avoiding the pain of reality). All of these are red flags.

    On the flip side, a good investor should have your back. They’re part of the company. If they’re not with you for the whole ride (the good and the bad), they're not a true partner. You shouldn’t need to worry about sharing the failures with them. The version of the company they present to the world will be the version that they'd want presented if they were the founders.

    Here are some specific signs that an investor is not pulling weight:

    • They’re not putting in time. Don’t expect an investor to drop everything (they also have lives), but responses should not be several days late… You should expect normal email protocol.
    • You never have conversations that feel high bandwidth. At some point, you should be discussing core issues with your investor, not the surface-level issues that every company needs to figure out. It's a good sign if it feels like a collaborative relationship, with problem-solving at the earliest stages.

  • If you think an investor's instincts are off, how/when to communicate this?

    Immediately. Investors have a lot of ideas, and they are used to spouting off. They need to go a mile wide and an inch deep; they're good at pattern matching across industries. But the founder knows a lot more about their own company. Post-funding, if you're the CEO, you almost have an obligation to correct your investors’ instincts.

    The situation may be different pre-funding... But generally investors respect founders who are comfortable pushing back, as long as they're respectful. If a founder has a strong point of view about their own domain, I respect their priors (even for domains that I think I know well). Even today, when I meet a company in a space I've operated in, my default is that all my information is old or out-dated. I enter with a point of view, but I’m open to being shown otherwise. Investors who think they know more than the startup are likely arrogant.

    For an investor, a good philosophy is that if a founder has a strong point of view, the default is that they're right (until you can prove that they're wrong).

  • How does the founder-investor relationship change over time?

    The most successful long-term relationships are ones with a human bond. Where the founder and investor genuinely have an interest in each other’s success (something that transcends the business value of success). You both want the product to succeed, and you want the people involved to get some reward. This doesn’t happen with every relationship.

    Over the longer-term, you also develop a sense of the other person’s strengths and weaknesses — e.g. where they’re most effective. You’ll know when to reach out to each other for different problems or opportunities. This is not always obvious a priori, especially when first making an investment. It’s builds, based on the level of comfort in the relationship.

RELATIONSHIP MAINTENANCE

  • What’s the best way to share updates with investors?

    Good investors will read all the reports sent by portfolio companies, and will even reply. Most updates have an ask, and investors will try to chime and help.

    Here are a few best practices:

    • Use the same format each time, to maintain flow across updates.
    • Bucket your content into what’s going well (i.e., where we’re winning); what’s not going well (i.e. where we’re losing, where investors can help); and some of your longer-term thinking.
    • The longer-term thinking might spark ideas for investors -- e.g. who should I make an intro to for this founder?
    • Check out: Investor Updates for a template.

  • How to prioritize the company’s needs over investor updates?

    Prioritizing day-to-day is more art than science. The tricky part about being a CEO is the duality of having to deal with the thorniest/most ambiguous stuff (if you’ve hired well, other people will handle the more straightforward stuff), while also being the fulcrum for the cadence of the company (like leading all-hands, running board meetings, keeping the pulse).

    You can’t afford to give up your role in setting and maintaining pace. You have to take care of fires while keeping the overall structure in place. There will always be issues that threaten your routines -- every week. But you can’t let that disrupt the flow.

    Some guidelines:

    • Never cancel a board meeting.
    • Never cancel an all-hands. There’s nothing more important than communicating with your team.
    • Never cancel a regular meeting with your executives.

    It may be OK to cancel a 1:1 if you need to put out a fire. But there are disciplines you need to keep. You need to balance short-term fires with maintaining the company’s structure and cadence.

  • What is something most founders obsess about, that turns out to not matter that much?

    When it comes to relationships with investors, founders often obsess about coming off as having everything under control, all the time. True leadership means acknowledging what you don't know, and that the startup journey is an experiment (with ebbs and flows). Investors who have been operators will already understand this.

    By the way, it's obvious when things are not going well. Don't put on a brave face. It's healthier for you and the relationship to be honest.

  • How do investors view internal conflicts, e.g. when there are strong but divergent convictions within a company?

    Every company needs an individual responsible for big decisions. The principle needs to be “we disagree, but commit.” This could be CEO’s role, but there always needs to be someone whose job is to make the final decision.

    • It’s poisonous for a company when people disagree but don’t commit; then you get passive aggression and open conflict.
    • Even when there are two co-founders, you always need the CEO to make a decision and move on. You can’t keep pursuing consensus.

    As an investor, no opinion should count more than the CEO’s. Investors might provide capital and serve as advisors, but it’s not their company. Investors can’t force the firm to wait before raising the next round, or avoid a specific co-investor. They should support whatever the CEO decides. Investors do have a voice, and they want to be listened to -- but the best ones are humble, and just provide the advice.

COMMUNICATING PRE-INVESTMENT

  • How should founders approach investors with an investment opportunity?

    There is a different relationship between an entrepreneur and an investor before a funding commitment is made. Before an investment, investors want to hear from founders at most once per month. Honestly not much happens in a month, no matter how quickly a company is moving.

    Of course a good investor will never turn down an offer to get more information; information is power. At the same time, there are three problems with communication:

    1. It takes time to digest information. When you haven't committed to helping a company, getting too many updates can feel like overload.
    2. It takes effort to process updates that are poorly written. This can make it feel like the entrepreneur is lazy.
    3. Too much communication comes across as desperate.

    There are also entrepreneurs that try to get VCs to do work for them, as a power play. But for everyone, the most precious commodity is time.

  • At what stage should SPC members come talk to the SPC Fund?

    Once you join SPC, there’s a commitment we make to each other -- a commitment to help out. With many of SPC’s investments in member companies, the relationship between the fund partner and the company started well before investment. One of the partners will have spent time brainstorming and regularly jamming with the founders. SPC partners also play a role as members of the community, giving feedback to others. If one of us is slammed, we might refer you to another partner. But members should err on the side of hanging out, spending time, getting feedback.

    <aside> 📖 Check out our fundraise resources:

    </aside>

    <aside> 💡 SPC Fund partners hold weekly office hours for members. This is a great starting point for an early conversation about fundraising or a practice pitch. Ping @Danh Trang for details.

    </aside>

    <aside> 💬 Schedule an Unofficial Board Meeting with SPC partners. Ping @Arian Agrawal for details.

    </aside>

    <aside> 👥 Come join our next quarterly “Fundraising Lunch + Learn” in NY or SF. Ping @Arian Agrawal and @Evan Tana for details.

    </aside>

  • If you're getting pursued by an investor while at SPC, what's the best way to interact?

    Regardless of the “quality” of an investor, most good VCs will want you to have a strong idea when they meet with you — something that's worth pursuing. So, chats with investors are the most interesting and useful when you're focused on an idea and ready for feedback.

    • You should be poised to discuss and ask about your target markets, and whether they make sense.
    • It's not crazy to meet for coffee earlier on, but if it's a completely undirected conversation (and a low-strength connection), it's easy to waste your time.

    Also, the investors who are most anxious to get involved at the earliest stages may not end up being strategic partners. Most “good” VCs are not pursuing random outreach. They tend to be more directed and systematic, especially if they’re a Series A/B firm. More venerable firms ask their junior associates to learn by cutting small checks. But in this case, you won't get much input from the senior partner at that firm.

    A general note: capital for ventures is in abundance, and no good idea will go unfunded. Don't feel anxiety about access to capital; worry about whether what you’re working on is a good idea.

  • How can you tell if you’ve got investor-founder fit?

    • Remember, you are partnering not with the brand name of the firm, but with the partner. This should be someone you can trust, because ultimately your interface to the firm is the partner. And it sucks if you’re just one of the 30 companies in a partner’s stack (especially if you’re at the bottom of the pile).
    • When you're selecting an investor: if you don't feel like you have transparency, then you need to think twice. Find somebody you feel a connection to, and someone who will spend time on your company.
    • In addition to the sense of connection and transparency, consider the partner’s relevant investing and/or operating experience in the area that you’re building.
    • What’s the investor’s slope in understanding your market? Are they asking you meaningful questions that help inflect your understanding or are they mostly surface-level questions?

    As much as investors want you to think they’re the “make or break”, ultimately it’s up to you. Investors can play a role, but you shouldn’t need to spend time worrying what your investor thinks. You need to trust that they’re on your team and will help out when you need it.

Nic

Body:
Nic ---------- Forwarded message --------- From: Nicholas Baird Date: Tue, Mar 19, 2024 at 10:14 AM Subject: planning a raise To: Cole Smith High-Level Thoughts - *Commit to the process.* If you're going to fundraise, commit to it and do it properly. You'll waste time and be ineffective if you are haphazard or non-committal about your raise. - *Fundraising requires a ton of time and energy.* You need to budget for the productivity hit. Make sure one person takes the lead to limit the distraction to your co-founders and teammates. - *Run a tight and strategic process.* Be deliberate about how you prioritize your investors and schedule them within a tight timeframe. Avoid large time gaps between your conversations; otherwise, you risk losing leverage and the ability to generate momentum. - *Approach with an iterative mindset.* Every pitch is an opportunity to understand what resonates and what doesn't. Make sure you reflect on what can be improved and don't be afraid to iterate and experiment with your pitch. (With that said, recognize that some investors simply won't get it and aren't a fit. While you should iterate, don't over-rotate.) - *Don't be afraid of "getting to a no".* Be prepared to be told "no" many times in the process. A "no" helps you move on and prioritize your other conversations. “If you receive a no, ask for feedback and be okay if they don’t respond. Every now and again, you’ll get a gem that vastly accelerates your learning.” - *SPC is here to help you fundraise successfully.* Please engage us early in the process so we can help you prepare the narrative and also help accelerate your investor intros. Checklist for your Fundraise - [ ] Pitch Deck - [ ] Blurb & Company Description - [ ] Fundraise Timeline - Avoid Thanksgiving through New Years (late November through early January) and late summer (July and August) - [ ] Intro List - Who you plan to reach out to to help you fundraise - Include anyone in your network you feel comfortable asking - you never know who knows who - Strategizing on how introductions are made is very important. Portfolio company founders and SPC staff will be your strongest channels for intros. - [ ] Investor List - Create this spreadsheet of who you want to raise from and who will connect you to that person - A good starting point to create this list is from the SPC Investor Network - Prioritize the list (practice, Tier I and Tier 2) Types of investors There are many different types of investors you are going to pitch, the below will help you prioritize who you meet and when. Anchor on having some early friendlier conversations to get warmed up. Schedule your larger fund conversations near one another. Additionally, group potential investors into tiers 1 (your tier 1 will be your target ideal investors) ,2, and 3 and reach out to 5-7 funds from tier 2 to warm up before pitching tier 1 investors. This way you can hear feedback and incorporate or pause to course-correct if there’s something weak. 1. Friends & Family: Small check sizes (under $25k), quick closings, minimal effort. 2. Eager Angel Investors: Check sizes not important, focus on quick investment and generating momentum. 3. Angel Investors with Domain Expertise: Check sizes not important, look for quick movers and industry credibility. 4. Well-Respected Angels: Closing deals with these angels increases credibility, preparation is key. 5. Seed Firms (aka "Angel Firms"): Seek firms with previous investments, domain experts, and respected angels. Multiple meetings may be required. 6. Series A Multi-stage VC Firms: Mainly write Series A and B checks ($5M+), variable policies on seed checks, low conversion rates. Some use seed checks to buy an option into the Series A Proposed Timeline 6-8 weeks before first investor pitch 1. Create a pitch outline. 1. The outline is fine as a written one-pager. (It’s better to start with an outline to focus on the high-level narrative and content and avoid getting slowed by deck design.) 2. Get feedback from the SPC staff on this early outline. 2. Create or update your shareable investor blurb . 3. Create your target investor list (you can copy this format ) 1. Include on this list people you think are your ideal investors 2. A good starting point to create this list is from the SPC Investor Network 3. Ask the SPC staff + other founders in SPC which other investors they would be able to introduce you to. 4. Create spreadsheet or update your personal crm with everyone you plan to notify that you are going out to raise and will need their help 4-6 weeks before 1. Create your pitch deck . We recommend spending a bit of time and money on deck design. Great looking slides go a long way! 2. Start outreach to friends and network to fill out your spreadsheet with who they can help you with intros to. 1. This spreadsheet will be public and shared with your friends and close investors like SPC, *so do not use it to track notes* on your meetings, create a separate CRM for you and your team only. Once you are starting connections and tracking notes on who you meet with to follow up. 2. Keep your ask simple, clear and short. You want people to fill out their name in the spreadsheet. 1. Sample ask: “I’m going out to fundraise in a few weeks and wanted to plan out the outreach strategy. I wanted to see if you would be comfortable making any introductions to any investors on this spreadsheet attached. My ask is if you see someone on this list that you would be comfortable introducing me to in a few weeks when I am ready, that you list your name in column E or F if you have a connection, and if you think of anyone else.” 3. Email your partner and cc investors@southparkcommons.com to get their help filling out the spreadsheet of intros you are looking for. Present your fundraising strategy and timeline in the email. 4. Engage with designer to take a pass on deck 2-4 weeks before 1. Schedule a practice pitch with the SPC staff 2. Demo product and pitch within whole SPC community with your ask being for intros to investors or customers 3. Queue up another 5 friendly investor-like people to get real feedback on the pitch so that you go into the first round of meetings with more confidence and experience 4. Iterate on feedback 1-3 weeks before 1. Send out note to everyone that was willing to connect you and tell them you are kicking off the raise and ask them to introduce you to the people they agreed to. Include your blurb with the clear ask . 2. Begin to schedule meetings in person or over zoom for dates starting the week you had planned to kick off based on intros as they come in. - Investors love fomo, having a busy schedule of back to back meetings over a condensed amount of time, increases the likelihood that you can drum it up. - Try to reply within a few hours of being connected. 3. Create a CRM to track of all meetings and people and conversations so you know who to follow up with and don’t forget anyone Week before first meeting 1. Practice practice practice 1. Do it with friends, do it with each other, do with the SPC partners Once the meetings are kicked off 1. Take notes on every meeting that you think is promising in your private CRM tracker 2. Be responsive to investor emails afterwards Additional Resources - Asking for an intro - Blurb & Company Description - Intro Emails - Elad Intro - Pitch Deck - ‣ - Fundraising advice - https://www.healthtechnerds.com/articles/community-wisdom-fundraising-at-the-seed-stage Nic

Nic




---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Nicholas Baird <nebaird.sail@gmail.com>
Date: Tue, Mar 19, 2024 at 10:14 AM
Subject: planning a raise
To: Cole Smith <cole.s.smith1@gmail.com>


High-Level Thoughts

  • Commit to the process. If you're going to fundraise, commit to it and do it properly. You'll waste time and be ineffective if you are haphazard or non-committal about your raise.
  • Fundraising requires a ton of time and energy. You need to budget for the productivity hit. Make sure one person takes the lead to limit the distraction to your co-founders and teammates.
  • Run a tight and strategic process. Be deliberate about how you prioritize your investors and schedule them within a tight timeframe. Avoid large time gaps between your conversations; otherwise, you risk losing leverage and the ability to generate momentum.
  • Approach with an iterative mindset. Every pitch is an opportunity to understand what resonates and what doesn't. Make sure you reflect on what can be improved and don't be afraid to iterate and experiment with your pitch. (With that said, recognize that some investors simply won't get it and aren't a fit. While you should iterate, don't over-rotate.)
  • Don't be afraid of "getting to a no". Be prepared to be told "no" many times in the process. A "no" helps you move on and prioritize your other conversations. “If you receive a no, ask for feedback and be okay if they don’t respond. Every now and again, you’ll get a gem that vastly accelerates your learning.”
  • SPC is here to help you fundraise successfully. Please engage us early in the process so we can help you prepare the narrative and also help accelerate your investor intros.

Checklist for your Fundraise

  • [ ] Pitch Deck
  • [ ] Blurb & Company Description
  • [ ] Fundraise Timeline
    • Avoid Thanksgiving through New Years (late November through early January) and late summer (July and August)
  • [ ] Intro List
    • Who you plan to reach out to to help you fundraise
      • Include anyone in your network you feel comfortable asking - you never know who knows who
      • Strategizing on how introductions are made is very important. Portfolio company founders and SPC staff will be your strongest channels for intros.
  • [ ] Investor List
    • Create this spreadsheet of who you want to raise from and who will connect you to that person
    • A good starting point to create this list is from the SPC Investor Network
    • Prioritize the list (practice, Tier I and Tier 2)

Types of investors

There are many different types of investors you are going to pitch, the below will help you prioritize who you meet and when. Anchor on having some early friendlier conversations to get warmed up. Schedule your larger fund conversations near one another.

Additionally, group potential investors into tiers 1 (your tier 1 will be your target ideal investors) ,2, and 3 and reach out to 5-7 funds from tier 2 to warm up before pitching tier 1 investors. This way you can hear feedback and incorporate or pause to course-correct if there’s something weak.

  1. Friends & Family: Small check sizes (under $25k), quick closings, minimal effort.
  2. Eager Angel Investors: Check sizes not important, focus on quick investment and generating momentum.
  3. Angel Investors with Domain Expertise: Check sizes not important, look for quick movers and industry credibility.
  4. Well-Respected Angels: Closing deals with these angels increases credibility, preparation is key.
  5. Seed Firms (aka "Angel Firms"): Seek firms with previous investments, domain experts, and respected angels. Multiple meetings may be required.
  6. Series A Multi-stage VC Firms: Mainly write Series A and B checks ($5M+), variable policies on seed checks, low conversion rates. Some use seed checks to buy an option into the Series A

Proposed Timeline

6-8 weeks before first investor pitch

  1. Create a pitch outline.
    1. The outline is fine as a written one-pager. (It’s better to start with an outline to focus on the high-level narrative and content and avoid getting slowed by deck design.)
    2. Get feedback from the SPC staff on this early outline.
  2. Create or update your shareable investor blurb.
  3. Create your target investor list (you can copy this format)
    1. Include on this list people you think are your ideal investors
    2. A good starting point to create this list is from the SPC Investor Network
    3. Ask the SPC staff + other founders in SPC which other investors they would be able to introduce you to.
  4. Create spreadsheet or update your personal crm with everyone you plan to notify that you are going out to raise and will need their help

4-6 weeks before

  1. Create your pitch deck. We recommend spending a bit of time and money on deck design. Great looking slides go a long way!
  2. Start outreach to friends and network to fill out your spreadsheet with who they can help you with intros to.
    1. This spreadsheet will be public and shared with your friends and close investors like SPC, so do not use it to track notes on your meetings, create a separate CRM for you and your team only. Once you are starting connections and tracking notes on who you meet with to follow up.
    2. Keep your ask simple, clear and short. You want people to fill out their name in the spreadsheet.
      1. Sample ask: “I’m going out to fundraise in a few weeks and wanted to plan out the outreach strategy. I wanted to see if you would be comfortable making any introductions to any investors on this spreadsheet attached. My ask is if you see someone on this list that you would be comfortable introducing me to in a few weeks when I am ready, that you list your name in column E or F if you have a connection, and if you think of anyone else.”
  3. Email your partner and cc investors@southparkcommons.com to get their help filling out the spreadsheet of intros you are looking for. Present your fundraising strategy and timeline in the email.
  4. Engage with designer to take a pass on deck

2-4 weeks before

  1. Schedule a practice pitch with the SPC staff
  2. Demo product and pitch within whole SPC community with your ask being for intros to investors or customers
  3. Queue up another 5 friendly investor-like people to get real feedback on the pitch so that you go into the first round of meetings with more confidence and experience
  4. Iterate on feedback

1-3 weeks before

  1. Send out note to everyone that was willing to connect you and tell them you are kicking off the raise and ask them to introduce you to the people they agreed to. Include your blurb with the clear ask.
  2. Begin to schedule meetings in person or over zoom for dates starting the week you had planned to kick off based on intros as they come in.
    • Investors love fomo, having a busy schedule of back to back meetings over a condensed amount of time, increases the likelihood that you can drum it up.
    • Try to reply within a few hours of being connected.
  3. Create a CRM to track of all meetings and people and conversations so you know who to follow up with and don’t forget anyone

Week before first meeting

  1. Practice practice practice
    1. Do it with friends, do it with each other, do with the SPC partners

Once the meetings are kicked off

  1. Take notes on every meeting that you think is promising in your private CRM tracker
  2. Be responsive to investor emails afterwards

Additional Resources

  • Asking for an intro
    • Blurb & Company Description
    • Intro Emails
    • Elad Intro
  • Pitch Deck
    • ‣
  • Fundraising advice
    • https://www.healthtechnerds.com/articles/community-wisdom-fundraising-at-the-seed-stage
Nic

Nic ---------- Forwarded message --------- From: Nicholas Baird Date: Tue, Mar 19, 2024 at 10:01 AM Subject: Decks To: Cole Smith Deck Template for Seed Fundraising *Aim to have around 8 primary slides. Many decks manage to succinctly address each of these pitch topics with 1 slide per section, but sometimes you may need additional supporting slides per section. We don’t recommend having more than 3 per section.* 1. *Title:* Introduce your company with its name, logo, and a concise tagline of your elevator pitch. Think 7-10 word description, max. 2. *Problem:* Clearly articulate the pain points or importance of the problem you are addressing for your target users. Provide context to investors who may not be familiar with your industry. Demonstrate that this is a problem shared by a lot of customers == big market. If you can also indicate how much money customers may be wiling to pay, by comparing what they are paying now or other analogous comps, that will strengthen this as well. (We find you can hit on market size question here without needing an entirely separate market size section.) 3. *Solution:* Describe how your product or service solves the problem identified in the previous slide. Provide a demo or concrete screenshots. Avoid buzzwords, marketing speak and abstract terms. Investors are usually itching to understand what it is you’re building at this point. 4. *Insight:* Explain what’s driving the early traction. Share what is special about the solution and what the core insights are. We typically do not recommend competitor slides, but this is the slide to contrast yourself to other solutions. Speak to what you get right that others get wrong. 5. *Traction:* Showcase the most convincing evidence that you have a compelling solution to a hair-on-fire problem. Use graphs or data to illustrate revenue growth, user/usage growth, LOIs or PoCs, or timelines of achieved milestones and future plans. 6. *GTM Playbook:* Explain the early GTM. Who are your users? How are you finding them? What’s your unfair advantage with targeting and acquiring users? Instill confidence that this is repeatable and you know how to scale this. 7. *Future:* What’s the big vision and how big can this get? Connect the high-level dots for how you get from where this business and product are today to that big vision. 8. *Team:* Highlight why your team is the best fit to build your business. Convincingly answer the “Why You?”. While you should emphasize relevant expertise, education, work experience, or notable accomplishments in this, don’t go overboard with data. 1. Logos are great if they’re impressive 2. When talking over this slide, you should mention how you know one another The above 8 topics are the must-haves and how we would recommend ordering your pitch deck. Here are a few additional slides that you might include in the pitch (or in your appendix). - Market + Business Model: Present a bottom-up calculation of your market size along with the assumptions you've made. This slide also serves to explain your business model and revenue generation strategies to investors. [Depending on the nature of your business and how far along you are, you might move this into the main slide deck.] - Milestones + Use of Funds: Communicate the specific milestones you plan to achieve with the funding you are seeking. Investors want to see alignment between these milestones and future funding requirements. - Why Now?: Explain the recent changes in the world that have created an opportune environment for building your company, which may not have been possible in previous years. These changes could be related to regulations, technology advancements, shifting customer behaviors, or widespread platform adoption. - Sales process and sales economics: If you are a B2B company with significant revenue, consider including a slide about your sales process and relevant sales metrics such as average deal size. - Customers: For B2B companies, showcase logos and relevant information about your customers, particularly if they are well-known or recognizable. - Customer case study: Walk through a successful B2B customer's experience with your product or service, highlighting the positive impact it had on their business. - Engagement and retention: Provide statistics on user retention and engagement, particularly for consumer-focused companies. This slide can be included in an appendix if needed. - Unit economics: If your business model involves high cost of goods sold (COGS), such as labor marketplaces, hardware companies, or certain fintech companies, include relevant information about your unit economics. Nic

---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Nicholas Baird <nebaird.sail@gmail.com>
Date: Tue, Mar 19, 2024 at 10:01 AM
Subject: Decks
To: Cole Smith <cole.s.smith1@gmail.com>


Deck Template for Seed Fundraising

Aim to have around 8 primary slides. Many decks manage to succinctly address each of these pitch topics with 1 slide per section, but sometimes you may need additional supporting slides per section. We don’t recommend having more than 3 per section.

  1. Title: Introduce your company with its name, logo, and a concise tagline of your elevator pitch. Think 7-10 word description, max.
  2. Problem: Clearly articulate the pain points or importance of the problem you are addressing for your target users. Provide context to investors who may not be familiar with your industry. Demonstrate that this is a problem shared by a lot of customers == big market. If you can also indicate how much money customers may be wiling to pay, by comparing what they are paying now or other analogous comps, that will strengthen this as well. (We find you can hit on market size question here without needing an entirely separate market size section.)
  3. Solution: Describe how your product or service solves the problem identified in the previous slide. Provide a demo or concrete screenshots. Avoid buzzwords, marketing speak and abstract terms. Investors are usually itching to understand what it is you’re building at this point.
  4. Insight: Explain what’s driving the early traction. Share what is special about the solution and what the core insights are. We typically do not recommend competitor slides, but this is the slide to contrast yourself to other solutions. Speak to what you get right that others get wrong.
  5. Traction: Showcase the most convincing evidence that you have a compelling solution to a hair-on-fire problem. Use graphs or data to illustrate revenue growth, user/usage growth, LOIs or PoCs, or timelines of achieved milestones and future plans.
  6. GTM Playbook: Explain the early GTM. Who are your users? How are you finding them? What’s your unfair advantage with targeting and acquiring users? Instill confidence that this is repeatable and you know how to scale this.
  7. Future: What’s the big vision and how big can this get? Connect the high-level dots for how you get from where this business and product are today to that big vision.
  8. Team: Highlight why your team is the best fit to build your business. Convincingly answer the “Why You?”. While you should emphasize relevant expertise, education, work experience, or notable accomplishments in this, don’t go overboard with data.
    1. Logos are great if they’re impressive
    2. When talking over this slide, you should mention how you know one another

The above 8 topics are the must-haves and how we would recommend ordering your pitch deck. Here are a few additional slides that you might include in the pitch (or in your appendix).

  • Market + Business Model: Present a bottom-up calculation of your market size along with the assumptions you've made. This slide also serves to explain your business model and revenue generation strategies to investors. [Depending on the nature of your business and how far along you are, you might move this into the main slide deck.]
  • Milestones + Use of Funds: Communicate the specific milestones you plan to achieve with the funding you are seeking. Investors want to see alignment between these milestones and future funding requirements.
  • Why Now?: Explain the recent changes in the world that have created an opportune environment for building your company, which may not have been possible in previous years. These changes could be related to regulations, technology advancements, shifting customer behaviors, or widespread platform adoption.
  • Sales process and sales economics: If you are a B2B company with significant revenue, consider including a slide about your sales process and relevant sales metrics such as average deal size.
  • Customers: For B2B companies, showcase logos and relevant information about your customers, particularly if they are well-known or recognizable.
  • Customer case study: Walk through a successful B2B customer's experience with your product or service, highlighting the positive impact it had on their business.
  • Engagement and retention: Provide statistics on user retention and engagement, particularly for consumer-focused companies. This slide can be included in an appendix if needed.
  • Unit economics: If your business model involves high cost of goods sold (COGS), such as labor marketplaces, hardware companies, or certain fintech companies, include relevant information about your unit economics.
Nic
