Body:
Nic




---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: Isabelle Rossi de Leon <isabelle.rossideleon@gmail.com>
Date: Wed, Apr 3, 2024 at 8:27 AM
Subject: Fwd: Your 100 Level Puppy Class Starts Tonight - Welcome and
Homework!
To: Nicholas Baird <nebaird.sail@gmail.com>




---------- Forwarded message ---------
From: SF Puppy Prep <info@sfpuppyprep.com>
Date: Wed, Apr 3, 2024 at 8:08 AM
Subject: Your 100 Level Puppy Class Starts Tonight - Welcome and Homework!
To: SF PuppyPrep (Sf Puppy Prep) <info@sfpuppyprep.com>


Hello everyone,



Welcome to the SF Puppy Prep family! We can't wait to meet you and start
training together! This email contains everything you need to watch the
orientation video, prepare for and participate in all your classes, and
join us for office hours to ask any additional questions that arise for you
during the term of your class.



*How to prepare for Class:*



BEFORE CLASS:

· If you haven't already done so, please upload your vaccines records here!
<https://airtable.com/shrOrxMgKxbPOU3Tq> Puppies must have one round of
*DHPP*, and one *Bordetella* to attend.

· Sign our liability waiver
<https://esignatures.io/signl/1d60e7a4-c790-49e6-9446-2b0e826a91c6>

· Review Covid Policies

o Class will take place indoors. No more than 2 people per puppy. To reduce
risk, we recommend everyone wear a mask while attending class but it's not
required. If you experience any COVID symptoms or may be at risk of
exposure to coronavirus, we ask that you stay home.



INSTRUCTIONS AND EQUIPMENT NEEDED FOR YOUR FIRST CLASS:



This video <https://youtu.be/lVJRsxCgmDQ> is intended to help set you up
for success in the classes ahead that you attend with your puppy or dog.



Here are the down and dirty keys:

· Bring lots of different yummies. Cut them into tiny pieces ahead of time.
Bring much more than you think you need. Human-grade food treats are best!
A BAIT BAG can really help you, too.

· Bring your puppy or dog on a flat collar *and/or an anti-pull harness!* (We
can help you after class with the anti-pull harness if you don't have one
yet and want one.)

· Bring your puppy or dog on a 6' flat leash, nothing longer. *No
retractable leashes inside, please!*



The video forgot to mention – bring something for your puppy to chew on
during talking points! Bully stick, peanut butter stuffed kong are good
options!



When you come into class, please follow your trainer's instructions and go
directly to your seats to begin training.



*We are located at 251 6th St between Folsom and Howard. *



*Your class is on** Wednesdays** @ 5:30pm **for four consecutive
weeks (4/3, 4/10, 4/17, 4/24). *



*Here is your Orientation Video*



If you haven't seen this already, you'll find it really helpful! This video
covers puppy raising essentials such as: socialization, setting your home
up for success, confinement & crating, potty training, biting, mouthing and
chewing, alone time, exercise & stimulation, and how to prepare for class
and training success.  At the end of the video instructions are provided to
attend online classes which you can disregard.



*Click here to watch your orientation video. *
<https://vimeo.com/417692134/713cfe6c43>



*Here is your course content!*



In addition here’s a great Puppy Kindergarten handbook
<https://drive.google.com/open?id=1_LzC4u0hwqvL0Qd6KKs5u2-r-XqcqL7W> for
even more information, tips, and tricks. In fact, some of the homework
reminders below reference further reading for you in the handbook.



The ‘homework’ below covers all four weeks of our class, so hang on to this
email!



Homework & Class Overview

*Table of Contents*



*Handbook* for Further
Reading.....................................................................
2

Taking Treats
Gently..................................................................................
2

Impulse Control - just the
beginning!........................................................... 2

Capturing
behavior!...................................................................................
2

Name game (see page 37 of your
handbook)................................................ 3

"Touch"....................................................................................................
3

Luring
behavior!........................................................................................
4

Mouthing & Bite
Inhibition...........................................................................
4

Socialize, socialize,
socialize!!!....................................................................
4

More about Impulse Control: wait (at the
door).............................................. 5

Impulse Control: jumping up or building
confidence....................................... 5

Collar Grabs +
Handling..............................................................................
6

Recall Beginnings (coming when
called)........................................................ 6

Recall Building Blocks (e.g. at the
park)....................................................... 7

Using Hand Signals & Verbal
Cues............................................................... 7

Loose Leash
Walking.................................................................................
8

Loose Leash Walking – Red Light, Green
Light............................................... 9

Resource Guarding
Prevention.....................................................................
9

Puppy Play: Be in the
‘know’......................................................................
10

Want
More?............................................................................................
11

Thank
you..............................................................................................
12



*Handbook*
<https://drive.google.com/file/d/1_LzC4u0hwqvL0Qd6KKs5u2-r-XqcqL7W/view>* for
Further Reading*



As we progress through our classes, you might want to refer to our Puppy
Kindergarten Handbook
<https://drive.google.com/open?id=1_LzC4u0hwqvL0Qd6KKs5u2-r-XqcqL7W>.  It
needs a visual upgrade but the content is very relevant and packed with a
lot of great info. Some of the homework each week references further
reading in that handbook, so keep the link handy or consider downloading a
copy. Below you will find reminders for the topics we’ll be covering
throughout the course.

*Taking Treats Gently *

This can be done in a couple of ways.  I like to wait until puppy starts to
use their tongue - I wait for two licks, then release the food.  In a
little while, puppy learns that using teeth only delays the cookie, so
they'll begin licking immediately!  Another method is described in your
handbook
<https://drive.google.com/open?id=1_LzC4u0hwqvL0Qd6KKs5u2-r-XqcqL7W> on
page 34.



*Impulse Control - just the beginning!*

Puppies need to learn to control their impulses, much in the way children
do - a little bit at a time!!!  We'll practice a short exercise we call
"skydiver" to get you off in the right direction. Show puppy you've got a
treat, maybe give her one.  Then come down from above her head, starting
about 2-3' above, with another treat - if her paws come off the ground,
immediately remove the treat!  If her paws stay down, give it to her.



Adjust the speed you come in with to help her be successful - quickly
coming down with the treat will be easier for her. The slower you move
towards her with the treat the harder it will be.



Once she’s good when coming straight down fairly slowly, begin to change
the angle of approach with the treat to provide alternative challenges.

For review you can have a look at pages 39 & 40, practicing "skydiver" on
page 40.

*Capturing behavior! *

Capturing means you wait for "it" (choose anything you like that puppy may
offer), to happen and then click when it does.   This helps us work on our
clicker timing and mechanics right from the start.



If you don’t have a clicker or prefer not to use one, substitute “yip”
instead. Try and be consistent in your tone and keep the “yip” short and
crisp!



We'll wait for our pups to offer something we like (a look towards us, or
some of you may choose a sit, down, or something else), and then click when
they do what we want.



Over a few minutes of practice, you will discover that your pup just keep
offering more and more of what you clicked for! You’ll barely get your pup
to stop looking (or sitting) at you! So great!!!!



Since "you get what you click" you'll see more of what you're clicking for
- you're creating a pup who will work to figure out how to make you say
"yes" as opposed to doing all his puppy things to which you would want to
say "no"!



Just think of all the things you might say "yes" to throughout puppy's day
- laying down, chewing his toy, walking with all four paws on the ground
(vs. jumping up), etc. Catch him doing it right! for review, you could:



·       Read pages 28-30 in your handbook about using the clicker

·       Practice clicking your pup for looking at you in many different
places

·       keep engaging your helpers to be your training coach - making sure
you "click" THEN move with the treat.



*Name game (see page 37 of your handbook).  *

After you learn to click for something your pup happened to offer, we'll
move right away onto teaching our pups to orient towards us as soon as
their name is called.



Say your puppy’s name only once, then click when she orients towards you
and give her a treat. The objective is for her to learn that it pays to
look towards you when her name is called.



At first, it's good enough if she just turns her head in your direction. As
she gets good at the game, you can hold out for her to look upwards toward
your head, then later still for direct eye contact. A ton of repetition of
this game is a GREAT idea - it builds the foundation for all future
behavior, especially coming when called.



For homework, continue to play this game in increasingly more distracting
environments. Be careful to time your click correctly - just as your pup
begins to orient towards you. Also remember to avoid the human tendency to
repeat his/her name. Just say it once!



If you say puppy's name and she doesn't orient towards you, what can you
do? You can make all kinds of odd noises to help prompt them to look in
your direction, then "click" as soon as they do so!



As puppy begins to learn that hearing her name will be followed by a click
if she turns your way, the amount of prompting (funny noises) you should
need will be less and less, and before you know it, they'll respond EVERY
time you say their name!



*"Touch"  *

We will work to teach your puppy to target your hand with their nose for a
"click" then a treat!



This can be useful for moving your puppy to new places, as a greeting for
new people (touching a hand that's placed low can prevent jumping), to help
shy dogs build confidence when meeting new people, and for an easy game to
play to get puppy focused and working with you.



Once puppy is really good at it, you can use "touch" to get puppy to come
to you from increasing distances away (if it sounds like the beginning for
coming when called, you're on the right track!). The more you work on this,
the more you and puppy will love it - and you'll find endless uses for your
puppy's great "touch!"



Read page 36 to review this exercise and practice it everywhere!



*Luring behavior! *

We'll also work on how to use a technique called lure/reward training.
We'll learn to lure our pup into a down position, or teach them a "spin".



Putting the food on his/her nose and moving very slowly (pretend it's a
magnet - if you move too quickly the magnet will disconnect), you'll work
gradually until your pup lays down. For some, this might mean having to
lure and feed every inch until finally your pup will put elbows on the
ground. For others, you may need to lure your pups under your leg to get
them into position.



They key to luring is to keep the pup with you, and release the food when
you get what you want (either in stages or for a full behavior).



It’s critical to get that food out of your hand as soon as you can! That
way puppy doesn't wait for you to pull out food before they will get to
work, but instead will respond to your hand signals and *THEN* get a treat.



For review:

· read page 31 in your handbook

· practice your "down", first lured, then with an empty hand signal in lots
of locations (making sure to keep distractions low until puppy is really
good at it!)

· ONLY add a word AFTER your puppy has MASTERED doing what you want for an
empty hand signal. We’ll cover adding cues in a later section.

*Mouthing & Bite Inhibition*

Our puppies are little biting machines!!!  What does it mean and what
should we do? There are two great pages in your handbook on this, and it’s
a topic that really needs full justice given.



Please visit pages 19 & 20 to review and implement the practices that will
help your puppy gain good bite inhibition and stop biting at you in play!

*Socialize, socialize, socialize!!! *

"Look at that" is a great socialization game. You can use it when
socializing puppies to different sights - a shopping cart, stroller, person
skateboarding or riding a bike, etc.



 “Click” when puppy notices ‘the person, dog, or thing’, THEN lure puppy’s
nose back in your direction, and THEN feed what you were luring with.



Make sure your lure stays on puppy’s nose as if it were a magnet - move
slowly so the magnet stays attached!!



Now, in addition to creating a great association with different things,
you’re also training puppy to look at something novel and check back in
with you automatically! We’re creating a great behavior pattern that helps
puppy break focus away from things s/he might find unusual or distracting.



This is a great game to play with your puppy when they see another dog on
leash. It helps teach them to ignore other dogs on leash. Socialization
with a bonus!



For homework, get puppy out there and do some more!!! This should make up
the bulk of your time with puppy until they’re 16 or 18 weeks old. If you
like, visit pages 14-17 in your handbook for more socialization ideas and
tips.  Just get out there and let your pup experience the world in a
positive way (by pairing anything they notice with food - sounds, people,
smells).



At home, change things when puppy isn’t watching. Put them to bed in the
crate next to your bed and then place a chair upside down where it doesn’t’
belong! Move a big bin into the floor. Open an umbrella and place it in the
kitchen. Use your imagination and let puppy discover, be surprised, and
recover from the changes in their environment. That is socialization!



Also consider finding a great Spotify list or downloading a playlist of
socialization sounds. Play it at a very low level to begin with. Puppy
should take notice of it, then recover and go on as though they don’t care.
Keep it at that level for a day or two, playing it for about 20 minutes
three times a day, then increase the volume ONLY SLIGHTLY, and repeat.



Positive exposure is key; prevent fearfulness by making sure the sounds and
sights they are weary of don't get too close or loud and feed them while
they look or hear. Gradually get closer, being careful not to push them too
hard.  Every puppy needs to go at their own pace.



Your puppy also needs to learn to communicate with other puppies, so as
they mature they know how to appropriately interact with all canine
personalities, breeds and sizes. This can be a challenge for you and we
strongly encourage you to consider our puppy day school
<https://www.sfpuppyprep.com/puppy-day-school/> to help with this aspect of
socialization and to lay the foundation for all of puppy’s training needs
at the same time!





*More about Impulse Control: wait (at the door)*

Teach your puppy to wait at the door, rather than launching through of his
own inclination. Surprise – another puppy impulse control exercise!!!



You can work on this either by asking for a sit and then opening the door,
or by just using the opening and closing of the door as environmental
feedback for puppy. Our personal preference is to let the door do the
talking for you, but you can use either method.



Review page 41 in your handbook
<https://drive.google.com/open?id=1_LzC4u0hwqvL0Qd6KKs5u2-r-XqcqL7W> for
more help on this!

*Impulse Control: jumping up or building confidence*

There’s never enough practice for this. Get your puppy super excited, then
stop dead in your tracks and become very boring the moment they jump up.



Resume your excited behavior when those paws go back down and quickly go
down to puppy’s level to reinforce them for being “four-on-the-floor.”



Remember to remove yourself quickly if puppy jumps up!



Also remember that shy puppies shouldn't be pushed beyond their comfort
zone – if your excitement and arousal seems scary to them, use this
exercise to build their confidence by only being a little excited, then
toss a few treats. Build up slowly to higher excitement levels until your
puppy looks forward to your crazy dance!



*Collar Grabs + Handling*

Throughout the course of a dog’s life, there are many instances when we
might want to reach for (and hold onto) their collar. Some pups are
naturally shy about hands reaching towards them, while others have learned
to run away because the main consequence to grabbing their collar has been
an undesirable one from the puppy’s perspective.



Whichever the case, we can teach puppy that it is GOOD NEWS when we grab
onto them, and this can help us in a very big way later on at the vet,
possibly in an emergency, or just through the course of the day to either
prevent or encourage certain behaviors (not the least of which is
connecting a leash).



·       Figure out where your puppy’s comfort level is with you reaching
for and grabbing their collar.  Do they shy away? If so, instead of a full
collar grab, just reach towards them as close as you can get but BEFORE
they feel the need to shy away. After several repetitions (at least 5-10),
move SLIGHTLY closer.  Repeat until you can grab their collar without puppy
leaning away from you.



·       Do at least 10 random collar grabs every day!  Try your best to
hide the food so puppy doesn’t know what’s coming such that the collar grab
is the ONLY predictor of the food. You can also use play for reinforcement
– works really well with fetch or tug. Just grab the collar, pause, then
release and start play!



·       All the same rules apply when teaching puppy to continue to be
comfortable with other body parts! Practice handling ears, paws, tail,
etc., using the same method and order of events!



*Recall Beginnings (coming when called)*

Be sure to read about the critical 5 keys to getting puppy to come when
called reliably, on page 44 of your handbook. If you hold true to all of
those keys, your puppy will be able to have lots of freedom and exercise
and of course, your amazing recall will impress everyone at the park!



We actually begin working on coming when called with the name game (see
earlier section). If you can get your puppy to look at you when you say
their name, then you've got the beginning of a fabulous recall!



Next work on a ‘back up recall’: calling puppy from further away but still
well within their capability – no further than the other end of the leash.
Practice only a few times, a few times a day.



As your puppy heads towards you, back up a little. It can also help to turn
away from your puppy somewhat. Both of those strategies help to draw puppy
in to you, making for a stronger recall. If your puppy is accepting of you
grabbing their collar, it’s time to start ending every recall with a collar
grab and *then* a treat party!



Once you’ve got a great ‘back up’ recall, it’s time to play some great
indoor games that help with fun factor while teaching puppy that coming to
you when called is a brilliant idea! We’ll play Hide and Seek, and another
fun game we call FaceTime!

*Recall Building Blocks (e.g. at the park)*

In addition to the great games we’ve worked on, here are some things to
consider when you’re out and about.



·       Choose the right moment to call your dog, and be sure to be close
enough to guarantee success!

·       Decide when to call, and when to wait it out. Choosing the right
moment at this point in their development likely means waiting until puppy
isn't engaged in much else (yes, it's a nano-second so you have to be ready
for it), and when they're fairly close by so it doesn't take much effort to
come your way. Then, when they arrive, you throw a treat and praise party,
and maybe even play some tug!

·       If your puppy is enjoying play with another dog, at this stage it’s
best to get SUPER close and wait for a split second pause. Say your puppy’s
name and then put a really GREAT treat in her mouth - even if she DIDN’T
give you any sign she heard her name at all.

·       Repeat this frequently (10 times or more) within a brief period.
Watch as she slowly catches on - that upon hearing her name she gets
something FANTASTIC, and still gets to keep on playing!!

·       You get the picture - help her catch on, teach her she doesn’t
loose play privileges, and a tiny bit at a time make it slightly harder,
waiting for her to come a step away from play to get the treat (and then
let her go right back again).

·       This forms the basis of a great recall, and as your puppy gets
better, you’ll notice that you’ll say her name and she WILL begin to look
around at you. Then it’s time to ask from a HALF STEP further away.

·       If you called and puppy didn't come to you, then you'll need to do
everything you can to make it happen. Keep working on expanding your
cheerleading vocabulary!  Any funny sounds that bring your pup towards you
are free game! (Hint: higher pitched ones work better.) Of course, we don't
want to cheer-lead every time - only when it's going to be really hard for
puppy to come but we've gone ahead and made the ask so must follow up!!!

·       It's critical to build success upon success with recall in such a
way that your call always results in the right response - puppy coming to
you. Then, with hundreds of trials, one tiny bit at a time, recalls get
harder.

·       It's such a gentle upward slope, puppy almost never fails and
before you know it, you've got a stellar recall.



*Using Hand Signals & Verbal Cues*

Dogs really struggle to learn words for things you want from them. Just
think about how they must tune out the flood of language they hear from us
all day long – think Charlie Brown!



If you do want your dog to ‘tune in’ to your word for something, here is
the very best way to help them learn. Let’s use teaching puppy to lie down
when you say, “down”:



1.    Make sure they know how lay down when you give them a hand signal
(this should look similar to your lure, but with no food and it might also
be an attenuated (smaller) movement).

2.    You should be at a stage where puppy doesn’t need food in your hand
at all.

3.    You should also be at a stage where your puppy goes down without
reservation when you give the hand signal just once!

4.    Once all of those things are true, now you’re ready to teach the word:

a.    Say “Down” in a happy tone.

b.    PAUSE

c.     Show hand signal

d.    FEED a treat

e.    REPEAT, REPEAT, REPEAT!

f.     Make sure you’re only doing ONE step at a time: talk, THEN hand
signal, THEN treat!



Practice positions (sit, down, stand, and/or spin) with your puppy every
day for only a couple of minutes at a time, maybe 3 times a day.  Chose
only one or two positions to work on during each session.



For some skills, you probably have puppy responding some of the time when
you make a verbal request.  For other skills, you might be offering a hand
signal, or perhaps are still luring with food in your hand.



If you’re at the stage of adding a verbal cue, just practice that one thing
during any particular session at first. This makes it easy for puppy to
guess that word predicts your hand signal (and they’ll learn more quickly
to do what you’ve asked before you’ve even had a chance to get your hand
signal out)!



Work at whatever stage you are at with your pup, specific to each
position. Remember to work quickly at removing that lure so puppy doesn’t
become dependent upon seeing the food in order to be willing to work!



Then try teaching a new trick, adhering to all of the steps above and see
how much faster your pup can learn a word! Work on fading out the use of
lures in lieu of a hand signal. From there, gradually attenuate the
magnitude of your hand signal.



Once your hand signal is reasonable (e.g. you don't have to do a hand
signal that touches the ground for down, for example), then you can begin
to add a verbal cue. Make it easier for your dog to learn by ensuring that
your verbal cue always PRECEDES your already reliable hand signal.

*Loose Leash Walking*

Let’s teach puppy to walk nicely on a leash!  If you do not already have
one, go get an anti-pull harness (several brands are available: sensation,
easy walk, wonder walker).



A correct harness can help your dog from practicing pulling while you’re
working to train them to walk nicely!



A flat leash, no longer than 6’ is the best choice.



To begin, start without a leash at all! First, create a great association
for your puppy sitting BESIDE you! This is a huge shift for your puppy who
has grown up receiving a ton of reinforcement for being in front of you
instead!



Choose a side and be consistent across family members if at all possible.
It’s easier for puppy to master one side first. You can train the other
side later.



Second, lure puppy to your side and into a sit. Sounds simple, but it
isn’t! It can help to use the hand that’s on the same side as your dog.
Hold several treats in your hand and once you get puppy positioned (sitting
at your side), dole them out one at a time in rapid succession.



Then, take one step forward, lure the sit quickly, and feed multiple times.
We’re creating anchors – puppy sits to start and sits to finish, and we’ll
gradually increase the number of steps beside you in between the anchor
points!



Once your pup is pretty into sitting beside you and waiting between treats,
try taking two steps, then luring the sit. Make sure you are feeding
frequently enough that your dog is eager to make it to the next ‘stop’ and
thus stays with you in between!



If you get really good, you can even try turning corners and getting your
pup to stay with you! You can also try pausing briefly after stopping to
see if your puppy will sit automatically without your lure!



*Loose Leash Walking – Red Light, Green Light*

If you haven't already, read about the exercise, "red light/green light" to
build your leash walking success, on page 45 of your handbook.



With “Red Light/Green Light”, there are two main keys to success: 1) keep
your leash arm anchored to your body so there won't be any play in the
leash (putting your hand in your pocket might be an easy way to prevent
this); and, 2) watch for slack and tension in the leash as close to where
it connects to the collar/harness as possible – that way your timing will
be accurate.



If you put your hand in your pocket, be careful not to lose your balance or
fall – not recommended if you have a big dog who could pull you over!



GO when the leash is slack and STOP the moment it’s taught. Your dog earns
the “GO” by making sure he releases the tension in the lead. Any way he
accomplishes that is far game! He might lay down. He might sit. He might
back up. Whichever way he does it, let him WIN immediately by moving
forward.



If you’re using food on the floor to practice, let him have it! Or let him
sniff the tree. Or greet the person. Or get the toy! There are all kinds of
opportunities to practice this, you just have to train yourself to stop
dead when you feel tension – EVERY TIME it happens. That way, it ultimately
won’t happen very often at all!



*Resource Guarding Prevention*

Some of you may have already noticed some resource guarding behavior in
your puppies.  They may have tried to keep something you wanted to take
away, or rushed to consume their food or a chewie on approach.



It’s a completely natural and normal behavior on the part of your puppy,
but isn’t very practical in our human world, especially if they’re coveting
things from people (vs. from other dogs).



Dogs will most often guard food, toys, water and/or people.  They may guard
from people, and/or from other dogs. Signs they are guarding may include
playing keep away, freezing and glancing at you in their periphery,
accelerated consumption, growling, snarling, snapping and of course, biting.



If you are seeing significant signs of your puppy guarding from people,
it’s a good idea to get advice and possibly have a trainer to work with you
right away.  If you ignore early warning signs, guarding can escalate and
become dangerous to you or your family and guests.



We can do a lot to help prevent puppy’s development of guarding behavior.
Here are just a few examples:



·       Practice trading low value objects (or food) for high value objects
(or food).  Puppy will learn to give things up easily if they think that
doing so will gain them something even more favorable.

·       Sharing is caring.  Puppy learns that they get the yummy bully
stick, but only when you’re holding it (and you can practice trading it out
for steak, at the same time).

·       Adding high value yummies to food bowls.  Provided you have not
seen any guarding in your pup thus far, you can add “extras” to puppy’s
bowl while they are eating.  This teaches them that a hand reaching into
their food bowl is predictive of something great and not that you are a
threat to their current food source!



Practice all of the exercises to help puppy learn that hands towards him
when he's got something very valuable is never a threat! You can read page
48 in your handbook for review.



*Puppy Play: Be in the ‘know’*

Puppy play is a little bit like going to a party - there will be some folks
one connects with right away, and other folks who aren't as easy to get to
know at first. There are different social styles, and some styles go
together like peanut butter and jam, yet others more like water and oil
over an open flame! This can change over time as learning happens and
people get to know one another.



So it is with puppy play, too! And, just like the guidance of good adult
mentors of children, puppy owners can help their puppies learn good social
skills, and help them cope in a world of differing personalities - and
hugely different sizes!



It’s helpful to know what healthy dog play contains:

·       role reversals (i chase you, you chase me)

·       activity shifting (we chase, then wrestle, then break, move on to
play with a different pup, etc.)

·       frequent breaks - about every 3 seconds (even a quick pause in the
action will do)

·       loose, wiggly body movements / relaxed postures



It’s also good to know when it’s appropriate to interrupt your puppy by
calling their name, luring them away with food if necessary, or doing a
collar grab, then feeding:

·       if the above things are missing in play - one easy way to do this
is to look and interrupt if any one thing goes on longer than 3 seconds

·       if you are concerned your puppy might be overwhelming another dog
(perceived bully)

·       if you are concerned your puppy might be overwhelmed by another dog
(perceived victim)



For the last two, you can do a quick consent test to ascertain if either of
the two scenarios are at play.  Interrupt the perceived 'bully' and then
watch what the perceived 'victim' does.



The way to do this is to call the 'bully's' name and then keep their
attention by feeding them. Watch to see what the 'victim' does. If the
victim moves away, you'll know s/he was being overwhelmed and in future,
try to interrupt slightly earlier. If the victim comes towards the 'bully'
wanting to continue play, you'll know it was consensual and can let it
continue, re-testing as needed.



We highly recommend giving your puppy some puppy-to-puppy socialization
several times during their critical window of socialization. Our puppy day
school <https://www.sfpuppyprep.com/puppy-day-school/> can help you with
this if you don’t know enough different sizes, breeds and temperaments of
puppies, or have a safe place to do it yourself.



If done appropriately and enough times with many different puppies, your
puppy will grow up to be more relaxed and confident when other dogs are
present. They’ll know how to handle themselves at the party – without
rocking out of control or without experiencing fear.



*Want More?*

After you’ve earned your way to being a kindergarten graduate, you’ll have
some solid foundational skills and a good understanding of how to build on
them.

You may be ready and able to fly on your own entirely from here!



For many, the structure and support of ongoing instruction helps maintain
momentum and ensures that you don’t stray too far from your goals.



As your puppy matures, you’ll likely find yourself scratching your head
from time to time, wanting to make sure you’re on the right track, and also
wanting to continue to challenge your puppy, who increasingly has more
energy and confidence.



Luckily, we’ve got just the thing! *200: Middle School*! Here is a sampling
of what we’ll cover at the next level:



·       *stay* in place

·       *stand* (think checking feet, vet exam, grooming)

·       learn to *groom with ease*

·       more *coming when called*: increasing challenge level with
distraction, distance

·       *leash walking*, greater distractions, alternatives and beginning
to fade food

·       *leave it*, progressing to real life scenarios and higher value
objects

·       listening better: building a *dog who's truly listening* (cue
discrimination)

It has been such a pleasure having you with us. We meant what we said when

As you probably realize, SF Puppy Prep is a small business. Puppies that

If you’ve enjoyed your time with us and would be open to sharing your

help set you up for success in the classes ahead that you attend with
your puppy or dog.  </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif"> </span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif">Here are the down and
dirty keys:</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 0in 47.25pt;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Symbol">·<span style="font-variant-numeric:normal;font-variant-east-asian:normal;font-variant-alternates:normal;font-kerning:auto;font-feature-settings:normal;font-stretch:normal;font-size:7pt;line-height:normal;font-family:"Times New Roman"">
</span></span><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif">Bring lots of different
yummies. Cut them into tiny pieces ahead of time. Bring much more than you
think you need. Human-grade food treats are best! A BAIT BAG can really help
you, too.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 0in 47.25pt;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Symbol">·<span style="font-variant-numeric:normal;font-variant-east-asian:normal;font-variant-alternates:normal;font-kerning:auto;font-feature-settings:normal;font-stretch:normal;font-size:7pt;line-height:normal;font-family:"Times New Roman"">
</span></span><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif">Bring
your puppy or dog on a flat collar <b>and/or an anti-pull
harness!</b> (We can help you after class with the anti-pull
harness if you don't have one yet and want one.)</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif"></span></p>

Kindergarten Handbook</span></a></span><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">.  It needs a visual
upgrade but the content is very relevant and packed with a lot of great info.
Some of the homework each week references further reading in that handbook, so
keep the link handy or consider downloading a copy. Below you will find
reminders for the topics we’ll be covering throughout the course. </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Taking Treats Gently </span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">This can be done in a
couple of ways.  I like to wait until puppy starts to use their tongue - I
wait for two licks, then release the food.  In a little while, puppy
learns that using teeth only delays the cookie, so they'll begin licking immediately! 
Another method is described in your </span><span style="color:black"><a href="https://drive.google.com/open?id=1_LzC4u0hwqvL0Qd6KKs5u2-r-XqcqL7W" target="_blank"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;text-decoration-line:none">handbook</span></a></span><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> on
page 34.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Impulse Control - just the beginning!</span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Puppies need to learn to
control their impulses, much in the way children do - a little bit at a
time!!!  We'll practice a short exercise we call "skydiver" to
get you off in the right direction. Show puppy you've got a treat, maybe give
her one.  Then come down from above her head, starting about 2-3' above,
with another treat - if her paws come off the ground, immediately remove the
treat!  If her paws stay down, give it to her.  </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Adjust the speed you come
in with to help her be successful - quickly coming down with the treat will be
easier for her. The slower you move towards her with the treat the harder it
will be.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Once she’s good when
coming straight down fairly slowly, begin to change the angle of approach with
the treat to provide alternative challenges. </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">For review you can have a
look at pages 39 & 40, practicing "skydiver" on page 40.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Capturing behavior! </span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Capturing means you wait
for "it" (choose anything you like that puppy may offer), to happen
and then click when it does.   This helps us work on our clicker timing
and mechanics right from the start.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">If you don’t have a
clicker or prefer not to use one, substitute “yip” instead. Try and be
consistent in your tone and keep the “yip” short and crisp!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">We'll wait for our pups to
offer something we like (a look towards us, or some of you may choose a sit,
down, or something else), and then click when they do what we want.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Over a few minutes of
practice, you will discover that your pup just keep offering more and more of
what you clicked for! You’ll barely get your pup to stop looking (or sitting)
at you! So great!!!!  </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Since "you get what
you click" you'll see more of what you're clicking for - you're creating a
pup who will work to figure out how to make you say "yes" as opposed
to doing all his puppy things to which you would want to say "no"!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Just think of all the
things you might say "yes" to throughout puppy's day - laying down,
chewing his toy, walking with all four paws on the ground (vs. jumping up),
etc. Catch him doing it right! for review, you could:</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 0in 0.75in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       Read
pages 28-30 in your handbook about using the clicker</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 0in 0.75in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       Practice
clicking your pup for looking at you in many different places</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 0in 0.75in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       keep
engaging your helpers to be your training coach - making sure you
"click" THEN move with the treat.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Name game (see page 37 of your handbook).  </span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">After you learn to click
for something your pup happened to offer, we'll move right away onto teaching
our pups to orient towards us as soon as their name is called.  </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Say your puppy’s name only
once, then click when she orients towards you and give her a treat. The
objective is for her to learn that it pays to look towards you when her name is
called. </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">At first, it's good enough
if she just turns her head in your direction. As she gets good at the game, you
can hold out for her to look upwards toward your head, then later still for
direct eye contact. A ton of repetition of this game is a GREAT idea - it
builds the foundation for all future behavior, especially coming when called.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">For homework, continue to
play this game in increasingly more distracting environments. Be careful to
time your click correctly - just as your pup begins to orient towards you. Also
remember to avoid the human tendency to repeat his/her name. Just say it
once!  </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">If you say puppy's name
and she doesn't orient towards you, what can you do? You can make all kinds of
odd noises to help prompt them to look in your direction, then
"click" as soon as they do so!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">As puppy begins to learn
that hearing her name will be followed by a click if she turns your way, the
amount of prompting (funny noises) you should need will be less and less, and
before you know it, they'll respond EVERY time you say their name!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">"Touch"  </span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">We will work to teach your
puppy to target your hand with their nose for a "click" then a treat!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">This can be useful for
moving your puppy to new places, as a greeting for new people (touching a hand
that's placed low can prevent jumping), to help shy dogs build confidence when
meeting new people, and for an easy game to play to get puppy focused and
working with you.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Once puppy is really good
at it, you can use "touch" to get puppy to come to you from increasing
distances away (if it sounds like the beginning for coming when called, you're
on the right track!). The more you work on this, the more you and puppy will
love it - and you'll find endless uses for your puppy's great
"touch!"</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Read page 36 to review
this exercise and practice it everywhere!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Luring behavior! </span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">We'll also work on how to
use a technique called lure/reward training. We'll learn to lure our pup into a
down position, or teach them a "spin".</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Putting the food on
his/her nose and moving very slowly (pretend it's a magnet - if you move too
quickly the magnet will disconnect), you'll work gradually until your pup lays
down. For some, this might mean having to lure and feed every inch until finally
your pup will put elbows on the ground. For others, you may need to lure your
pups under your leg to get them into position.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">They key to luring is to
keep the pup with you, and release the food when you get what you want (either
in stages or for a full behavior).</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">It’s critical to get that
food out of your hand as soon as you can! That way puppy doesn't wait for you
to pull out food before they will get to work, but instead will respond to your
hand signals and <i>THEN</i> get a treat.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">For review:</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:3pt 0in 3pt 47.25pt;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Symbol;color:black">·<span style="font-variant-numeric:normal;font-variant-east-asian:normal;font-variant-alternates:normal;font-kerning:auto;font-feature-settings:normal;font-stretch:normal;font-size:7pt;line-height:normal;font-family:"Times New Roman""> </span></span><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">read
page 31 in your handbook</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:3pt 0in 3pt 47.25pt;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Symbol;color:black">·<span style="font-variant-numeric:normal;font-variant-east-asian:normal;font-variant-alternates:normal;font-kerning:auto;font-feature-settings:normal;font-stretch:normal;font-size:7pt;line-height:normal;font-family:"Times New Roman""> </span></span><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">practice
your "down", first lured, then with an empty hand signal in lots of
locations (making sure to keep distractions low until puppy is really good at
it!)</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:3pt 0in 3pt 47.25pt;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Symbol;color:black">·<span style="font-variant-numeric:normal;font-variant-east-asian:normal;font-variant-alternates:normal;font-kerning:auto;font-feature-settings:normal;font-stretch:normal;font-size:7pt;line-height:normal;font-family:"Times New Roman""> </span></span><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">ONLY
add a word AFTER your puppy has MASTERED doing what you want for an empty hand
signal. We’ll cover adding cues in a later section.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Mouthing & Bite Inhibition</span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Our puppies are little
biting machines!!!  What does it mean and what should we do? There are two
great pages in your handbook on this, and it’s a topic that really needs full
justice given.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Please visit pages 19
& 20 to review and implement the practices that will help your puppy gain
good bite inhibition and stop biting at you in play!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Socialize, socialize, socialize!!! </span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">"Look at that"
is a great socialization game. You can use it when socializing puppies to
different sights - a shopping cart, stroller, person skateboarding or riding a
bike, etc.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> “Click” when puppy
notices ‘the person, dog, or thing’, THEN lure puppy’s nose back in your
direction, and THEN feed what you were luring with.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Make sure your lure stays
on puppy’s nose as if it were a magnet - move slowly so the magnet stays
attached!!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Now, in addition to
creating a great association with different things, you’re also training puppy
to look at something novel and check back in with you automatically! We’re
creating a great behavior pattern that helps puppy break focus away from things
s/he might find unusual or distracting.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">This is a great game to
play with your puppy when they see another dog on leash. It helps teach them to
ignore other dogs on leash. Socialization with a bonus!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">For homework, get puppy
out there and do some more!!! This should make up the bulk of your time with
puppy until they’re 16 or 18 weeks old. If you like, visit pages 14-17 in your
handbook for more socialization ideas and tips.  Just get out there and
let your pup experience the world in a positive way (by pairing anything they
notice with food - sounds, people, smells).</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">At home, change things
when puppy isn’t watching. Put them to bed in the crate next to your bed and
then place a chair upside down where it doesn’t’ belong! Move a big bin into
the floor. Open an umbrella and place it in the kitchen. Use your imagination
and let puppy discover, be surprised, and recover from the changes in their
environment. That is socialization!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Also consider finding a
great Spotify list or downloading a playlist of socialization sounds. Play it
at a very low level to begin with. Puppy should take notice of it, then recover
and go on as though they don’t care. Keep it at that level for a day or two,
playing it for about 20 minutes three times a day, then increase the volume
ONLY SLIGHTLY, and repeat.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>
