<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Positive exposure is key;
prevent fearfulness by making sure the sounds and sights they are weary of
don't get too close or loud and feed them while they look or hear. Gradually
get closer, being careful not to push them too hard.  Every puppy needs to
go at their own pace.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Your puppy also needs to
learn to communicate with other puppies, so as they mature they know how to
appropriately interact with all canine personalities, breeds and sizes. This
can be a challenge for you and we strongly encourage you to consider our </span><span style="color:black"><a href="https://www.sfpuppyprep.com/puppy-day-school/" target="_blank"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;text-decoration-line:none">puppy day school</span></a></span><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> to
help with this aspect of socialization and to lay the foundation for all of
puppy’s training needs at the same time!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">More about Impulse Control: wait (at the door)</span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Teach your puppy to wait
at the door, rather than launching through of his own inclination. Surprise –
another puppy impulse control exercise!!!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">You can work on this
either by asking for a sit and then opening the door, or by just using the
opening and closing of the door as environmental feedback for puppy. Our
personal preference is to let the door do the talking for you, but you can use
either method.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Review page 41 in
your </span><span style="color:black"><a href="https://drive.google.com/open?id=1_LzC4u0hwqvL0Qd6KKs5u2-r-XqcqL7W" target="_blank"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;text-decoration-line:none">handbook</span></a></span><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> for
more help on this!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Impulse Control: jumping up or building confidence</span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">There’s never enough
practice for this. Get your puppy super excited, then stop dead in your tracks
and become very boring the moment they jump up.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Resume your excited
behavior when those paws go back down and quickly go down to puppy’s level to
reinforce them for being “four-on-the-floor.”</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Remember to remove
yourself quickly if puppy jumps up!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Also remember that shy
puppies shouldn't be pushed beyond their comfort zone – if your excitement and
arousal seems scary to them, use this exercise to build their confidence by
only being a little excited, then toss a few treats. Build up slowly to higher
excitement levels until your puppy looks forward to your crazy dance!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Collar Grabs + Handling</span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Throughout the course of a
dog’s life, there are many instances when we might want to reach for (and hold
onto) their collar. Some pups are naturally shy about hands reaching towards
them, while others have learned to run away because the main consequence to
grabbing their collar has been an undesirable one from the puppy’s perspective.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Whichever the case, we can
teach puppy that it is GOOD NEWS when we grab onto them, and this can help us
in a very big way later on at the vet, possibly in an emergency, or just
through the course of the day to either prevent or encourage certain behaviors
(not the least of which is connecting a leash).</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 0in 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       Figure
out where your puppy’s comfort level is with you reaching for and grabbing
their collar.  Do they shy away? If so, instead of a full collar grab,
just reach towards them as close as you can get but BEFORE they feel the need
to shy away. After several repetitions (at least 5-10), move SLIGHTLY
closer.  Repeat until you can grab their collar without puppy leaning away
from you.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 0in 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       Do
at least 10 random collar grabs every day!  Try your best to hide the food
so puppy doesn’t know what’s coming such that the collar grab is the ONLY
predictor of the food. You can also use play for reinforcement – works really
well with fetch or tug. Just grab the collar, pause, then release and start
play!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 0in 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       All
the same rules apply when teaching puppy to continue to be comfortable with
other body parts! Practice handling ears, paws, tail, etc., using the same
method and order of events!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Recall Beginnings (coming when called)</span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Be sure to read about the
critical 5 keys to getting puppy to come when called reliably, on page 44 of
your handbook. If you hold true to all of those keys, your puppy will be able
to have lots of freedom and exercise and of course, your amazing recall will
impress everyone at the park!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">We actually begin working
on coming when called with the name game (see earlier section). If you can get
your puppy to look at you when you say their name, then you've got the
beginning of a fabulous recall!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Next work on a ‘back up
recall’: calling puppy from further away but still well within their capability
– no further than the other end of the leash. Practice only a few times, a few
times a day.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">As your puppy heads
towards you, back up a little. It can also help to turn away from your puppy
somewhat. Both of those strategies help to draw puppy in to you, making for a
stronger recall. If your puppy is accepting of you grabbing their collar, it’s time
to start ending every recall with a collar grab and <i>then</i> a
treat party!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Once you’ve got a great
‘back up’ recall, it’s time to play some great indoor games that help with fun
factor while teaching puppy that coming to you when called is a brilliant idea!
We’ll play Hide and Seek, and another fun game we call FaceTime!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Recall Building Blocks (e.g. at the park)</span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">In addition to the great
games we’ve worked on, here are some things to consider when you’re out and
about.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       Choose
the right moment to call your dog, and be sure to be close enough to guarantee
success!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       Decide
when to call, and when to wait it out. Choosing the right moment at this point
in their development likely means waiting until puppy isn't engaged in much
else (yes, it's a nano-second so you have to be ready for it), and when they're
fairly close by so it doesn't take much effort to come your way. Then, when
they arrive, you throw a treat and praise party, and maybe even play some tug!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       If
your puppy is enjoying play with another dog, at this stage it’s best to get
SUPER close and wait for a split second pause. Say your puppy’s name and then
put a really GREAT treat in her mouth - even if she DIDN’T give you any sign
she heard her name at all.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       Repeat
this frequently (10 times or more) within a brief period. Watch as she slowly
catches on - that upon hearing her name she gets something FANTASTIC, and still
gets to keep on playing!! </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       You
get the picture - help her catch on, teach her she doesn’t loose play
privileges, and a tiny bit at a time make it slightly harder, waiting for her
to come a step away from play to get the treat (and then let her go right back
again).</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       This
forms the basis of a great recall, and as your puppy gets better, you’ll notice
that you’ll say her name and she WILL begin to look around at you. Then it’s
time to ask from a HALF STEP further away.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       If
you called and puppy didn't come to you, then you'll need to do everything you
can to make it happen. Keep working on expanding your cheerleading
vocabulary!  Any funny sounds that bring your pup towards you are free
game! (Hint: higher pitched ones work better.) Of course, we don't want to
cheer-lead every time - only when it's going to be really hard for puppy to
come but we've gone ahead and made the ask so must follow up!!!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       It's
critical to build success upon success with recall in such a way that your call
always results in the right response - puppy coming to you. Then, with hundreds
of trials, one tiny bit at a time, recalls get harder.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       It's
such a gentle upward slope, puppy almost never fails and before you know it,
you've got a stellar recall. </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Using Hand Signals & Verbal Cues</span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Dogs really struggle to
learn words for things you want from them. Just think about how they must tune
out the flood of language they hear from us all day long – think Charlie Brown!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">If you do want your dog to
‘tune in’ to your word for something, here is the very best way to help them
learn. Let’s use teaching puppy to lie down when you say, “down”:</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">1.    Make
sure they know how lay down when you give them a hand signal (this should look
similar to your lure, but with no food and it might also be an attenuated
(smaller) movement).</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">2.    You
should be at a stage where puppy doesn’t need food in your hand at all.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">3.    You
should also be at a stage where your puppy goes down without reservation when
you give the hand signal just once!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">4.    Once
all of those things are true, now you’re ready to teach the word:</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 1in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">a.    Say
“Down” in a happy tone.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 1in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">b.    PAUSE</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 1in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">c.     Show
hand signal</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 1in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">d.    FEED
a treat</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 1in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">e.    REPEAT,
REPEAT, REPEAT!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 1in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">f.     Make
sure you’re only doing ONE step at a time: talk, THEN hand signal, THEN treat!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Practice positions (sit,
down, stand, and/or spin) with your puppy every day for only a couple of
minutes at a time, maybe 3 times a day.  Chose only one or two positions
to work on during each session.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">For some skills, you
probably have puppy responding some of the time when you make a verbal
request.  For other skills, you might be offering a hand signal, or
perhaps are still luring with food in your hand.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">If you’re at the stage of
adding a verbal cue, just practice that one thing during any particular session
at first. This makes it easy for puppy to guess that word predicts your hand
signal (and they’ll learn more quickly to do what you’ve asked before you’ve
even had a chance to get your hand signal out)!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Work at whatever stage you
are at with your pup, specific to each position. Remember to work quickly
at removing that lure so puppy doesn’t become dependent upon seeing the food in
order to be willing to work!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Then try teaching a new
trick, adhering to all of the steps above and see how much faster your pup can
learn a word! Work on fading out the use of lures in lieu of a hand signal.
>From there, gradually attenuate the magnitude of your hand signal.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Once your hand signal is
reasonable (e.g. you don't have to do a hand signal that touches the ground for
down, for example), then you can begin to add a verbal cue. Make it easier for
your dog to learn by ensuring that your verbal cue always PRECEDES your already
reliable hand signal.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Loose Leash Walking</span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Let’s teach puppy to walk
nicely on a leash!  If you do not already have one, go get an anti-pull
harness (several brands are available: sensation, easy walk, wonder walker).</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">A correct harness can help
your dog from practicing pulling while you’re working to train them to walk
nicely!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">A flat leash, no longer
than 6’ is the best choice.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">To begin, start without a
leash at all! First, create a great association for your puppy sitting BESIDE
you! This is a huge shift for your puppy who has grown up receiving a ton of
reinforcement for being in front of you instead!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Choose a side and be
consistent across family members if at all possible. It’s easier for puppy to
master one side first. You can train the other side later.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Second, lure puppy to your
side and into a sit. Sounds simple, but it isn’t! It can help to use the hand
that’s on the same side as your dog. Hold several treats in your hand and once
you get puppy positioned (sitting at your side), dole them out one at a time in
rapid succession.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Then, take one step
forward, lure the sit quickly, and feed multiple times. We’re creating anchors
– puppy sits to start and sits to finish, and we’ll gradually increase the
number of steps beside you in between the anchor points!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Once your pup is pretty
into sitting beside you and waiting between treats, try taking two steps, then
luring the sit. Make sure you are feeding frequently enough that your dog is
eager to make it to the next ‘stop’ and thus stays with you in between!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">If you get really good,
you can even try turning corners and getting your pup to stay with you! You can
also try pausing briefly after stopping to see if your puppy will sit
automatically without your lure!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Loose Leash Walking – Red Light, Green Light</span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">If you haven't already,
read about the exercise, "red light/green light" to build your leash
walking success, on page 45 of your handbook.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">With “Red Light/Green
Light”, there are two main keys to success: 1) keep your leash arm anchored to
your body so there won't be any play in the leash (putting your hand in your
pocket might be an easy way to prevent this); and, 2) watch for slack and tension
in the leash as close to where it connects to the collar/harness as possible –
that way your timing will be accurate.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">If you put your hand in
your pocket, be careful not to lose your balance or fall – not recommended if
you have a big dog who could pull you over!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">GO when the leash is slack
and STOP the moment it’s taught. Your dog earns the “GO” by making sure he
releases the tension in the lead. Any way he accomplishes that is far game! He
might lay down. He might sit. He might back up. Whichever way he does it, let
him WIN immediately by moving forward.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">If you’re using food on
the floor to practice, let him have it! Or let him sniff the tree. Or greet the
person. Or get the toy! There are all kinds of opportunities to practice this,
you just have to train yourself to stop dead when you feel tension – EVERY TIME
it happens. That way, it ultimately won’t happen very often at all!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Resource Guarding Prevention</span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Some of you may have
already noticed some resource guarding behavior in your puppies.  They may
have tried to keep something you wanted to take away, or rushed to consume
their food or a chewie on approach.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">It’s a completely natural
and normal behavior on the part of your puppy, but isn’t very practical in our
human world, especially if they’re coveting things from people (vs. from other
dogs).</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Dogs will most often guard
food, toys, water and/or people.  They may guard from people, and/or from
other dogs. Signs they are guarding may include playing keep away, freezing and
glancing at you in their periphery, accelerated consumption, growling,
snarling, snapping and of course, biting.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">If you are seeing
significant signs of your puppy guarding from people, it’s a good idea to get
advice and possibly have a trainer to work with you right away.  If you
ignore early warning signs, guarding can escalate and become dangerous to you
or your family and guests. </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">We can do a lot to help
prevent puppy’s development of guarding behavior.  Here are just a few
examples:</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       Practice
trading low value objects (or food) for high value objects (or food). 
Puppy will learn to give things up easily if they think that doing so will gain
them something even more favorable.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       Sharing
is caring.  Puppy learns that they get the yummy bully stick, but only
when you’re holding it (and you can practice trading it out for steak, at the
same time).</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       Adding
high value yummies to food bowls.  Provided you have not seen any guarding
in your pup thus far, you can add “extras” to puppy’s bowl while they are
eating.  This teaches them that a hand reaching into their food bowl is
predictive of something great and not that you are a threat to their current
food source!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Practice all of the
exercises to help puppy learn that hands towards him when he's got something
very valuable is never a threat! You can read page 48 in your handbook for
review.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 12pt;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Puppy Play: Be in the ‘know’</span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Puppy play is a little bit
like going to a party - there will be some folks one connects with right away,
and other folks who aren't as easy to get to know at first. There are different
social styles, and some styles go together like peanut butter and jam, yet
others more like water and oil over an open flame! This can change over time as
learning happens and people get to know one another. </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">So it is with puppy play,
too! And, just like the guidance of good adult mentors of children, puppy
owners can help their puppies learn good social skills, and help them cope in a
world of differing personalities - and hugely different sizes!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">It’s helpful to know what
healthy dog play contains:</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       role
reversals (i chase you, you chase me)</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       activity
shifting (we chase, then wrestle, then break, move on to play with a different
pup, etc.)</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       frequent
breaks - about every 3 seconds (even a quick pause in the action will do)</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       loose,
wiggly body movements / relaxed postures</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">It’s also good to know
when it’s appropriate to interrupt your puppy by calling their name, luring
them away with food if necessary, or doing a collar grab, then feeding:</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       if
the above things are missing in play - one easy way to do this is to look and
interrupt if any one thing goes on longer than 3 seconds</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       if
you are concerned your puppy might be overwhelming another dog (perceived
bully)</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 3pt 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       if
you are concerned your puppy might be overwhelmed by another dog (perceived
victim)</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">For the last two, you can
do a quick consent test to ascertain if either of the two scenarios are at
play.  Interrupt the perceived 'bully' and then watch what the perceived
'victim' does.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">The way to do this is to
call the 'bully's' name and then keep their attention by feeding
them. Watch to see what the 'victim' does. If the victim moves away,
you'll know s/he was being overwhelmed and in future, try to interrupt slightly
earlier. If the victim comes towards the 'bully' wanting to continue play,
you'll know it was consensual and can let it continue, re-testing as needed.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">We
highly recommend giving your puppy some puppy-to-puppy socialization several
times during their critical window of socialization. Our </span><span style="color:black"><a href="https://www.sfpuppyprep.com/puppy-day-school/" target="_blank"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;text-decoration-line:none">puppy day school</span></a></span><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> can
help you with this if you don’t know enough different sizes, breeds and
temperaments of puppies, or have a safe place to do it yourself.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="text-align:justify;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">If
done appropriately and enough times with many different puppies, your puppy
will grow up to be more relaxed and confident when other dogs are present.
They’ll know how to handle themselves at the party – without rocking out of
control or without experiencing fear.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Want More?</span></b><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">After you’ve earned your
way to being a kindergarten graduate, you’ll have some solid foundational
skills and a good understanding of how to build on them.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">You may be ready and able
to fly on your own entirely from here!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">For many, the structure
and support of ongoing instruction helps maintain momentum and ensures that you
don’t stray too far from your goals.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">As your puppy matures,
you’ll likely find yourself scratching your head from time to time, wanting to
make sure you’re on the right track, and also wanting to continue to challenge
your puppy, who increasingly has more energy and confidence.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>
