<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">Luckily, we’ve got just
the thing! <b>200: Middle School</b>! Here is a sampling of what we’ll
cover at the next level:</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 0in 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       <b>stay</b> in
place</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 0in 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       <b>stand</b> (think
checking feet, vet exam, grooming)</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 0in 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       learn
to <b>groom with ease</b></span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 0in 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       more <b>coming
when called</b>: increasing challenge level with distraction, distance</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 0in 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       <b>leash
walking</b>, greater distractions, alternatives and beginning to fade food</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 0in 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       <b>leave
it</b>, progressing to real life scenarios and higher value objects</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:0in 0in 0in 0.5in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;vertical-align:baseline;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">·       listening
better: building a <b>dog who's truly listening</b> (cue
discrimination)</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="margin:10pt 0in 0in;background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><a name="m_7383250819041766719_m_5264517584437752601_m_4491742720331507024_m_1557958155401158"><b><span style="font-size:10pt;font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:rgb(79,129,189)">Thank you</span></b></a><b><span style="font-size:18pt;font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></b></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">It has been such a
pleasure having you with us. We meant what we said when we said, “welcome to
the family”. As family, we are here to support you all the way through – so
don’t hesitate to reach out. Thank you for sharing your time and your puppy
with us, and for working so hard each week!</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">As you probably realize,
SF Puppy Prep is a small business. Puppies that come into our programs
aren’t here for long; it’s often only a few months before our puppy students
are ready to move on to adolescent/adult dog services like dog walking and day care. While
we often see them later in life, it means we are constantly looking for ways to
help more puppies. If you have any feedback for us that would help us improve
your experience, please </span><span style="color:black"><a href="http://www.sfpuppyprep.com/contact/" target="_blank"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;text-decoration-line:none">reach out</span></a></span><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> and
let us know – you can call our office anytime (415-618-0828), or send an email
with your thoughts. We are always on the lookout for ways to improve, and
would like to hear from you directly if you’re willing.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> </span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

<p class="MsoNormal" style="background-image:initial;background-position:initial;background-size:initial;background-repeat:initial;background-origin:initial;background-clip:initial;margin:0in;font-size:12pt;font-family:Calibri,sans-serif"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black">If you’ve enjoyed your
time with us and would be open to sharing your positive experience with folks
on our </span><span style="color:black"><a href="https://www.yelp.com/biz/sf-puppy-prep-san-francisco?osq=sf+puppy+prep" target="_blank"><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;text-decoration-line:none">Yelp profile,</span></a></span><span style="font-family:Verdana,sans-serif;color:black"> we
would genuinely appreciate it.  Your contribution in this way will truly
help us further serve our community, both human and canine.</span><span style="font-family:Arial,sans-serif;color:black"></span></p>

Subject: Great to meet you!
Body:
Hey Jimmy, great to get in touch. Klint was helping me out with some discovery I'm doing for a software tool I'm considering building and thought you might also be willing to help me out! Can we schedule a time to chat in the next week or so? I can tell you more about what I'm working on when we are live. This is when I'm free this coming week. I'm on PT. [image: Screenshot 2024-03-31 at 20.05.26.png] Also, noticed you live in Tampa / St. Pete! I grew up in St. Petersburg, most of my family still lives there, in Shore Acres. Thanks, and looking forward to chatting soon, Nic
Hey Jimmy, great to get in touch. Klint was helping me out with some discovery I'm doing for a software tool I'm considering building and thought you might also be willing to help me out!

Can we schedule a time to chat in the next week or so? I can tell you more about what I'm working on when we are live. This is when I'm free this coming week. I'm on PT.


Also, noticed you live in Tampa / St. Pete! I grew up in St. Petersburg, most of my family still lives there, in Shore Acres.

Thanks, and looking forward to chatting soon,

Nic

Hey John, Likewise! And apologies for my email delinquency. I'm in mexico this week and early next. Can we try Thursday or Friday next week instead? I'm wide open after 1 PT on Thursday and after 11 PT on Friday. Would you have some time on > Friday morning to discuss? I would like to have our VP of Engineering in > the discussion to understand the data structure that would be required to > test something out, if that makes sense. > > Would 8:30am MT on Friday morning work for you? > > Please let me know. > > Thank you Nic. > > John > > -- > > > > John Golinvaux > CEO & Founder, Fulcrum > 250 Steele St.Suite 375, Denver CO 80206 > 303-223-6515 Office | 303-748-5870 Mobile > john.golinvaux@fulcrumsaas.com > https://fulcrumsaas.com*Book a meeting* > > >
Hey John,

Likewise! And apologies for my email delinquency. 

I'm in mexico this week and early next. Can we try Thursday or Friday next week instead? 
I'm wide open after 1 PT on Thursday and after 11 PT on Friday. 

On Wed, Mar 20, 2024, 7:16 AM John Golinvaux <john.golinvaux@fulcrumsaas.com> wrote:
Hey Nic,
Great to catch up with you last week, I really enjoyed the conversation, excited to see what you develop.

In regards to our discussion on the AI Model and associated data, I am intrigued to talk with you more about this. Would you have some time on Friday morning to discuss? I would like to have our VP of Engineering in the discussion to understand the data structure that would be required to test something out, if that makes sense.

Would 8:30am MT on Friday morning work for you?

Please let me know.

Thank you Nic.

John 

--

*BUILDING STRONG RELATIONSHIPS* - *How should founders interact with investors?* *High level advice: Don't be afraid to ask.* - VCs get pretty good at saying no to requests from portfolio companies (or they'll find another person on their team to help you instead). A good rule of thumb is to let an investor do the filtering on what's too much work. - That said, every investor has a different philosophy: some investors are strictly seeking option value. For example, a Series A fund may participate in a seed round just for the opportunity to make a future investment. There are other funds that spray and pray (making lots of investments, even without conviction). In this case, your investor may be less engaged. - SPC is a high conviction, high ownership fund. SPC only leads or co-leads rounds, because the expectation is that once a partner makes an investment, they treat themselves as a member of the founding team. They’re on board to serve and help you. - *What makes for a good relationship?* The best investor-founder relationships are the ones where there's a high degree of trust and frequent collaboration. Yes there's a power dynamic between investors and founders; but after investment, investors want to make their money work. As an investor, I want to be treated as a member of the founding team. There's no such thing as asking too much, or overloading me. Your investor should know everything that's happening at the company, and should know enough to jump in if they had to (even though they're not involved in the day-to-day). Don't be worried about impressing them. Trust and transparency first. The healthiest relationships have almost complete transparency. - *How to know if your relationship has gone awry?* If a founder always communicates that everything is roses, then an investor knows that: 1) there is a lack of mutual trust; 2) the founder is scared of the investor; or 3) the founder is not being honest with themselves (i.e. avoiding the pain of reality). All of these are red flags. On the flip side, a good investor should have your back. They’re part of the company. If they’re not with you for the whole ride (the good and the bad), they're not a true partner. You shouldn’t need to worry about sharing the failures with them. The version of the company they present to the world will be the version that they'd want presented if they were the founders. Here are some specific signs that an investor is not pulling weight: - They’re not putting in time. Don’t expect an investor to drop everything (they also have lives), but responses should not be several days late… You should expect normal email protocol. - You never have conversations that feel high bandwidth. At some point, you should be discussing core issues with your investor, not the surface-level issues that every company needs to figure out. It's a good sign if it feels like a collaborative relationship, with problem-solving at the earliest stages. - *If you think an investor's instincts are off, how/when to communicate this?* Immediately. Investors have a lot of ideas, and they are used to spouting off. They need to go a mile wide and an inch deep; they're good at pattern matching across industries. But the founder knows a lot more about their own company. Post-funding, if you're the CEO, you almost have an obligation to correct your investors’ instincts. The situation may be different pre-funding... But generally investors respect founders who are comfortable pushing back, as long as they're respectful. If a founder has a strong point of view about their own domain, I respect their priors (even for domains that I think I know well). Even today, when I meet a company in a space I've operated in, my default is that all my information is old or out-dated. I enter with a point of view, but I’m open to being shown otherwise. Investors who think they know more than the startup are likely arrogant. For an investor, a good philosophy is that if a founder has a strong point of view, the default is that they're right (until you can prove that they're wrong). - *How does the founder-investor relationship change over time?* The most successful long-term relationships are ones with a human bond. Where the founder and investor genuinely have an interest in each other’s success (something that transcends the business value of success). You both want the product to succeed, and you want the people involved to get some reward. This doesn’t happen with every relationship. Over the longer-term, you also develop a sense of the other person’s strengths and weaknesses — e.g. where they’re most effective. You’ll know when to reach out to each other for different problems or opportunities. This is not always obvious *a priori*, especially when first making an investment. It’s builds, based on the level of comfort in the relationship. *RELATIONSHIP MAINTENANCE* - *What’s the best way to share updates with investors?* Good investors will read all the reports sent by portfolio companies, and will even reply. Most updates have an ask, and investors will try to chime and help. Here are a few best practices: - Use the same format each time, to maintain flow across updates. - Bucket your content into what’s going well (i.e., where we’re winning); what’s not going well (i.e. where we’re losing, where investors can help); and some of your longer-term thinking. - The longer-term thinking might spark ideas for investors -- e.g. who should I make an intro to for this founder? - Check out: Investor Updates for a template. - *How to prioritize the company’s needs over investor updates?* Prioritizing day-to-day is more art than science. The tricky part about being a CEO is the duality of having to deal with the thorniest/most ambiguous stuff (if you’ve hired well, other people will handle the more straightforward stuff), while also being the fulcrum for the cadence of the company (like leading all-hands, running board meetings, keeping the pulse). You can’t afford to give up your role in setting and maintaining pace. You have to take care of fires while keeping the overall structure in place. There will always be issues that threaten your routines -- every week. But you can’t let that disrupt the flow. Some guidelines: - Never cancel a board meeting. - Never cancel an all-hands. There’s nothing more important than communicating with your team. - Never cancel a regular meeting with your executives. It may be OK to cancel a 1:1 if you need to put out a fire. But there are disciplines you need to keep. You need to balance short-term fires with maintaining the company’s structure and cadence. - *What is something most founders obsess about, that turns out to not matter that much?* When it comes to relationships with investors, founders often obsess about coming off as having everything under control, all the time. True leadership means acknowledging what you don't know, and that the startup journey is an experiment (with ebbs and flows). Investors who have been operators will already understand this. By the way, it's obvious when things are not going well. Don't put on a brave face. It's healthier for you and the relationship to be honest. - *How do investors view internal conflicts, e.g. when there are strong but divergent convictions within a company?* Every company needs an individual responsible for big decisions. The principle needs to be “*we disagree, but commit*.” This could be CEO’s role, but there always needs to be someone whose job is to make the final decision. - It’s poisonous for a company when people disagree but don’t commit; then you get passive aggression and open conflict. - Even when there are two co-founders, you always need the CEO to make a decision and move on. You can’t keep pursuing consensus. As an investor, no opinion should count more than the CEO’s. Investors might provide capital and serve as advisors, but it’s not their company. Investors can’t force the firm to wait before raising the next round, or avoid a specific co-investor. They should support whatever the CEO decides. Investors do have a voice, and they want to be listened to -- but the best ones are humble, and just provide the advice. *COMMUNICATING PRE-INVESTMENT* - *How should founders approach investors with an investment opportunity?* There is a different relationship between an entrepreneur and an investor before a funding commitment is made. Before an investment, investors want to hear from founders at most once per month. Honestly not much happens in a month, no matter how quickly a company is moving. Of course a good investor will never turn down an offer to get more information; information is power. At the same time, there are three problems with communication: 1. It takes time to digest information. When you haven't committed to helping a company, getting too many updates can feel like overload. 2. It takes effort to process updates that are poorly written. This can make it feel like the entrepreneur is lazy. 3. Too much communication comes across as desperate. There are also entrepreneurs that try to get VCs to do work for them, as a power play. But for everyone, the most precious commodity is time. - *At what stage should SPC members come talk to the SPC Fund?* Once you join SPC, there’s a commitment we make to each other -- a commitment to help out. With many of SPC’s investments in member companies, the relationship between the fund partner and the company started well before investment. One of the partners will have spent time brainstorming and regularly jamming with the founders. SPC partners also play a role as members of the community, giving feedback to others. If one of us is slammed, we might refer you to another partner. But members should err on the side of hanging out, spending time, getting feedback.
📖 Check out our fundraise resources:
💡 SPC Fund partners hold weekly office hours for members. This is a great starting point for an early conversation about fundraising or a practice pitch. Ping @Danh Trang for details.
💬 Schedule an Unofficial Board Meeting with SPC partners. Ping @Arian Agrawal for details.
👥 Come join our next quarterly “Fundraising Lunch + Learn” in NY or SF. Ping @Arian Agrawal and @Evan Tana for details.
- *If you're getting pursued by an investor while at SPC, what's the best way to interact?* Regardless of the “quality” of an investor, most good VCs will want you to have a strong idea when they meet with you — something that's worth pursuing. So, chats with investors are the most interesting and useful when you're focused on an idea and ready for feedback. - You should be poised to discuss and ask about your target markets, and whether they make sense. - It's not crazy to meet for coffee earlier on, but if it's a completely undirected conversation (and a low-strength connection), it's easy to waste your time. Also, the investors who are most anxious to get involved at the earliest stages may not end up being strategic partners. Most “good” VCs are not pursuing random outreach. They tend to be more directed and systematic, especially if they’re a Series A/B firm. More venerable firms ask their junior associates to learn by cutting small checks. But in this case, you won't get much input from the senior partner at that firm. A general note: capital for ventures is in abundance, and no good idea will go unfunded. Don't feel anxiety about access to capital; worry about whether what you’re working on is a good idea. - *How can you tell if you’ve got investor-founder fit?* - Remember, you are partnering not with the brand name of the firm, but with the partner. This should be someone you can trust, because ultimately your interface to the firm is the partner. And it sucks if you’re just one of the 30 companies in a partner’s stack (especially if you’re at the bottom of the pile). - When you're selecting an investor: if you don't feel like you have transparency, then you need to think twice. Find somebody you feel a connection to, and someone who will spend time on your company. - In addition to the sense of connection and transparency, consider the partner’s relevant investing and/or operating experience in the area that you’re building. - What’s the investor’s slope in understanding your market? Are they asking you meaningful questions that help inflect your understanding or are they mostly surface-level questions? As much as investors want you to think they’re the “make or break”, ultimately it’s up to you. Investors can play a role, but you shouldn’t need to spend time worrying what your investor thinks. You need to trust that they’re on your team and will help out when you need it. Nic

BUILDING STRONG RELATIONSHIPS

  • How should founders interact with investors?

    High level advice: Don't be afraid to ask.

    • VCs get pretty good at saying no to requests from portfolio companies (or they'll find another person on their team to help you instead). A good rule of thumb is to let an investor do the filtering on what's too much work.
    • That said, every investor has a different philosophy: some investors are strictly seeking option value. For example, a Series A fund may participate in a seed round just for the opportunity to make a future investment. There are other funds that spray and pray (making lots of investments, even without conviction). In this case, your investor may be less engaged.
    • SPC is a high conviction, high ownership fund. SPC only leads or co-leads rounds, because the expectation is that once a partner makes an investment, they treat themselves as a member of the founding team. They’re on board to serve and help you.

  • What makes for a good relationship?

    The best investor-founder relationships are the ones where there's a high degree of trust and frequent collaboration. Yes there's a power dynamic between investors and founders; but after investment, investors want to make their money work. As an investor, I want to be treated as a member of the founding team. There's no such thing as asking too much, or overloading me.

    Your investor should know everything that's happening at the company, and should know enough to jump in if they had to (even though they're not involved in the day-to-day). Don't be worried about impressing them. Trust and transparency first. The healthiest relationships have almost complete transparency.

  • How to know if your relationship has gone awry?

    If a founder always communicates that everything is roses, then an investor knows that: 1) there is a lack of mutual trust; 2) the founder is scared of the investor; or 3) the founder is not being honest with themselves (i.e. avoiding the pain of reality). All of these are red flags.

    On the flip side, a good investor should have your back. They’re part of the company. If they’re not with you for the whole ride (the good and the bad), they're not a true partner. You shouldn’t need to worry about sharing the failures with them. The version of the company they present to the world will be the version that they'd want presented if they were the founders.

    Here are some specific signs that an investor is not pulling weight:

    • They’re not putting in time. Don’t expect an investor to drop everything (they also have lives), but responses should not be several days late… You should expect normal email protocol.
    • You never have conversations that feel high bandwidth. At some point, you should be discussing core issues with your investor, not the surface-level issues that every company needs to figure out. It's a good sign if it feels like a collaborative relationship, with problem-solving at the earliest stages.

  • If you think an investor's instincts are off, how/when to communicate this?

    Immediately. Investors have a lot of ideas, and they are used to spouting off. They need to go a mile wide and an inch deep; they're good at pattern matching across industries. But the founder knows a lot more about their own company. Post-funding, if you're the CEO, you almost have an obligation to correct your investors’ instincts.

    The situation may be different pre-funding... But generally investors respect founders who are comfortable pushing back, as long as they're respectful. If a founder has a strong point of view about their own domain, I respect their priors (even for domains that I think I know well). Even today, when I meet a company in a space I've operated in, my default is that all my information is old or out-dated. I enter with a point of view, but I’m open to being shown otherwise. Investors who think they know more than the startup are likely arrogant.

    For an investor, a good philosophy is that if a founder has a strong point of view, the default is that they're right (until you can prove that they're wrong).

  • How does the founder-investor relationship change over time?

    The most successful long-term relationships are ones with a human bond. Where the founder and investor genuinely have an interest in each other’s success (something that transcends the business value of success). You both want the product to succeed, and you want the people involved to get some reward. This doesn’t happen with every relationship.

    Over the longer-term, you also develop a sense of the other person’s strengths and weaknesses — e.g. where they’re most effective. You’ll know when to reach out to each other for different problems or opportunities. This is not always obvious a priori, especially when first making an investment. It’s builds, based on the level of comfort in the relationship.

RELATIONSHIP MAINTENANCE

  • What’s the best way to share updates with investors?

    Good investors will read all the reports sent by portfolio companies, and will even reply. Most updates have an ask, and investors will try to chime and help.

    Here are a few best practices:

    • Use the same format each time, to maintain flow across updates.
    • Bucket your content into what’s going well (i.e., where we’re winning); what’s not going well (i.e. where we’re losing, where investors can help); and some of your longer-term thinking.
    • The longer-term thinking might spark ideas for investors -- e.g. who should I make an intro to for this founder?
    • Check out: Investor Updates for a template.

  • How to prioritize the company’s needs over investor updates?

    Prioritizing day-to-day is more art than science. The tricky part about being a CEO is the duality of having to deal with the thorniest/most ambiguous stuff (if you’ve hired well, other people will handle the more straightforward stuff), while also being the fulcrum for the cadence of the company (like leading all-hands, running board meetings, keeping the pulse).

    You can’t afford to give up your role in setting and maintaining pace. You have to take care of fires while keeping the overall structure in place. There will always be issues that threaten your routines -- every week. But you can’t let that disrupt the flow.

    Some guidelines:

    • Never cancel a board meeting.
    • Never cancel an all-hands. There’s nothing more important than communicating with your team.
    • Never cancel a regular meeting with your executives.

    It may be OK to cancel a 1:1 if you need to put out a fire. But there are disciplines you need to keep. You need to balance short-term fires with maintaining the company’s structure and cadence.

  • What is something most founders obsess about, that turns out to not matter that much?

    When it comes to relationships with investors, founders often obsess about coming off as having everything under control, all the time. True leadership means acknowledging what you don't know, and that the startup journey is an experiment (with ebbs and flows). Investors who have been operators will already understand this.

    By the way, it's obvious when things are not going well. Don't put on a brave face. It's healthier for you and the relationship to be honest.

  • How do investors view internal conflicts, e.g. when there are strong but divergent convictions within a company?

    Every company needs an individual responsible for big decisions. The principle needs to be “we disagree, but commit.” This could be CEO’s role, but there always needs to be someone whose job is to make the final decision.

    • It’s poisonous for a company when people disagree but don’t commit; then you get passive aggression and open conflict.
    • Even when there are two co-founders, you always need the CEO to make a decision and move on. You can’t keep pursuing consensus.

    As an investor, no opinion should count more than the CEO’s. Investors might provide capital and serve as advisors, but it’s not their company. Investors can’t force the firm to wait before raising the next round, or avoid a specific co-investor. They should support whatever the CEO decides. Investors do have a voice, and they want to be listened to -- but the best ones are humble, and just provide the advice.

COMMUNICATING PRE-INVESTMENT

  • How should founders approach investors with an investment opportunity?

    There is a different relationship between an entrepreneur and an investor before a funding commitment is made. Before an investment, investors want to hear from founders at most once per month. Honestly not much happens in a month, no matter how quickly a company is moving.

    Of course a good investor will never turn down an offer to get more information; information is power. At the same time, there are three problems with communication:

    1. It takes time to digest information. When you haven't committed to helping a company, getting too many updates can feel like overload.
    2. It takes effort to process updates that are poorly written. This can make it feel like the entrepreneur is lazy.
    3. Too much communication comes across as desperate.

    There are also entrepreneurs that try to get VCs to do work for them, as a power play. But for everyone, the most precious commodity is time.

  • At what stage should SPC members come talk to the SPC Fund?

    Once you join SPC, there’s a commitment we make to each other -- a commitment to help out. With many of SPC’s investments in member companies, the relationship between the fund partner and the company started well before investment. One of the partners will have spent time brainstorming and regularly jamming with the founders. SPC partners also play a role as members of the community, giving feedback to others. If one of us is slammed, we might refer you to another partner. But members should err on the side of hanging out, spending time, getting feedback.

    <aside> 📖 Check out our fundraise resources:

    </aside>

    <aside> 💡 SPC Fund partners hold weekly office hours for members. This is a great starting point for an early conversation about fundraising or a practice pitch. Ping @Danh Trang for details.

    </aside>

    <aside> 💬 Schedule an Unofficial Board Meeting with SPC partners. Ping @Arian Agrawal for details.

    </aside>

    <aside> 👥 Come join our next quarterly “Fundraising Lunch + Learn” in NY or SF. Ping @Arian Agrawal and @Evan Tana for details.

    </aside>

  • If you're getting pursued by an investor while at SPC, what's the best way to interact?

    Regardless of the “quality” of an investor, most good VCs will want you to have a strong idea when they meet with you — something that's worth pursuing. So, chats with investors are the most interesting and useful when you're focused on an idea and ready for feedback.

    • You should be poised to discuss and ask about your target markets, and whether they make sense.
    • It's not crazy to meet for coffee earlier on, but if it's a completely undirected conversation (and a low-strength connection), it's easy to waste your time.

    Also, the investors who are most anxious to get involved at the earliest stages may not end up being strategic partners. Most “good” VCs are not pursuing random outreach. They tend to be more directed and systematic, especially if they’re a Series A/B firm. More venerable firms ask their junior associates to learn by cutting small checks. But in this case, you won't get much input from the senior partner at that firm.

    A general note: capital for ventures is in abundance, and no good idea will go unfunded. Don't feel anxiety about access to capital; worry about whether what you’re working on is a good idea.

  • How can you tell if you’ve got investor-founder fit?

    • Remember, you are partnering not with the brand name of the firm, but with the partner. This should be someone you can trust, because ultimately your interface to the firm is the partner. And it sucks if you’re just one of the 30 companies in a partner’s stack (especially if you’re at the bottom of the pile).
    • When you're selecting an investor: if you don't feel like you have transparency, then you need to think twice. Find somebody you feel a connection to, and someone who will spend time on your company.
    • In addition to the sense of connection and transparency, consider the partner’s relevant investing and/or operating experience in the area that you’re building.
    • What’s the investor’s slope in understanding your market? Are they asking you meaningful questions that help inflect your understanding or are they mostly surface-level questions?

    As much as investors want you to think they’re the “make or break”, ultimately it’s up to you. Investors can play a role, but you shouldn’t need to spend time worrying what your investor thinks. You need to trust that they’re on your team and will help out when you need it.

Nic

Nic

Nic

Subject: planning a raise
Body:
High-Level Thoughts - *Commit to the process.* If you're going to fundraise, commit to it and do it properly. You'll waste time and be ineffective if you are haphazard or non-committal about your raise. - *Fundraising requires a ton of time and energy.* You need to budget for the productivity hit. Make sure one person takes the lead to limit the distraction to your co-founders and teammates. - *Run a tight and strategic process.* Be deliberate about how you prioritize your investors and schedule them within a tight timeframe. Avoid large time gaps between your conversations; otherwise, you risk losing leverage and the ability to generate momentum. - *Approach with an iterative mindset.* Every pitch is an opportunity to understand what resonates and what doesn't. Make sure you reflect on what can be improved and don't be afraid to iterate and experiment with your pitch. (With that said, recognize that some investors simply won't get it and aren't a fit. While you should iterate, don't over-rotate.) - *Don't be afraid of "getting to a no".* Be prepared to be told "no" many times in the process. A "no" helps you move on and prioritize your other conversations. “If you receive a no, ask for feedback and be okay if they don’t respond. Every now and again, you’ll get a gem that vastly accelerates your learning.” - *SPC is here to help you fundraise successfully.* Please engage us early in the process so we can help you prepare the narrative and also help accelerate your investor intros. Checklist for your Fundraise - [ ] Pitch Deck - [ ] Blurb & Company Description - [ ] Fundraise Timeline - Avoid Thanksgiving through New Years (late November through early January) and late summer (July and August) - [ ] Intro List - Who you plan to reach out to to help you fundraise - Include anyone in your network you feel comfortable asking - you never know who knows who - Strategizing on how introductions are made is very important. Portfolio company founders and SPC staff will be your strongest channels for intros. - [ ] Investor List - Create this spreadsheet of who you want to raise from and who will connect you to that person - A good starting point to create this list is from the SPC Investor Network - Prioritize the list (practice, Tier I and Tier 2) Types of investors There are many different types of investors you are going to pitch, the below will help you prioritize who you meet and when. Anchor on having some early friendlier conversations to get warmed up. Schedule your larger fund conversations near one another. Additionally, group potential investors into tiers 1 (your tier 1 will be your target ideal investors) ,2, and 3 and reach out to 5-7 funds from tier 2 to warm up before pitching tier 1 investors. This way you can hear feedback and incorporate or pause to course-correct if there’s something weak. 1. Friends & Family: Small check sizes (under $25k), quick closings, minimal effort. 2. Eager Angel Investors: Check sizes not important, focus on quick investment and generating momentum. 3. Angel Investors with Domain Expertise: Check sizes not important, look for quick movers and industry credibility. 4. Well-Respected Angels: Closing deals with these angels increases credibility, preparation is key. 5. Seed Firms (aka "Angel Firms"): Seek firms with previous investments, domain experts, and respected angels. Multiple meetings may be required. 6. Series A Multi-stage VC Firms: Mainly write Series A and B checks ($5M+), variable policies on seed checks, low conversion rates. Some use seed checks to buy an option into the Series A Proposed Timeline 6-8 weeks before first investor pitch 1. Create a pitch outline. 1. The outline is fine as a written one-pager. (It’s better to start with an outline to focus on the high-level narrative and content and avoid getting slowed by deck design.) 2. Get feedback from the SPC staff on this early outline. 2. Create or update your shareable investor blurb . 3. Create your target investor list (you can copy this format ) 1. Include on this list people you think are your ideal investors 2. A good starting point to create this list is from the SPC Investor Network 3. Ask the SPC staff + other founders in SPC which other investors they would be able to introduce you to. 4. Create spreadsheet or update your personal crm with everyone you plan to notify that you are going out to raise and will need their help 4-6 weeks before 1. Create your pitch deck . We recommend spending a bit of time and money on deck design. Great looking slides go a long way! 2. Start outreach to friends and network to fill out your spreadsheet with who they can help you with intros to. 1. This spreadsheet will be public and shared with your friends and close investors like SPC, *so do not use it to track notes* on your meetings, create a separate CRM for you and your team only. Once you are starting connections and tracking notes on who you meet with to follow up. 2. Keep your ask simple, clear and short. You want people to fill out their name in the spreadsheet. 1. Sample ask: “I’m going out to fundraise in a few weeks and wanted to plan out the outreach strategy. I wanted to see if you would be comfortable making any introductions to any investors on this spreadsheet attached. My ask is if you see someone on this list that you would be comfortable introducing me to in a few weeks when I am ready, that you list your name in column E or F if you have a connection, and if you think of anyone else.” 3. Email your partner and cc investors@southparkcommons.com to get their help filling out the spreadsheet of intros you are looking for. Present your fundraising strategy and timeline in the email. 4. Engage with designer to take a pass on deck 2-4 weeks before 1. Schedule a practice pitch with the SPC staff 2. Demo product and pitch within whole SPC community with your ask being for intros to investors or customers 3. Queue up another 5 friendly investor-like people to get real feedback on the pitch so that you go into the first round of meetings with more confidence and experience 4. Iterate on feedback 1-3 weeks before 1. Send out note to everyone that was willing to connect you and tell them you are kicking off the raise and ask them to introduce you to the people they agreed to. Include your blurb with the clear ask . 2. Begin to schedule meetings in person or over zoom for dates starting the week you had planned to kick off based on intros as they come in. - Investors love fomo, having a busy schedule of back to back meetings over a condensed amount of time, increases the likelihood that you can drum it up. - Try to reply within a few hours of being connected. 3. Create a CRM to track of all meetings and people and conversations so you know who to follow up with and don’t forget anyone Week before first meeting 1. Practice practice practice 1. Do it with friends, do it with each other, do with the SPC partners Once the meetings are kicked off 1. Take notes on every meeting that you think is promising in your private CRM tracker 2. Be responsive to investor emails afterwards Additional Resources - Asking for an intro - Blurb & Company Description - Intro Emails - Elad Intro - Pitch Deck - ‣ - Fundraising advice - https://www.healthtechnerds.com/articles/community-wisdom-fundraising-at-the-seed-stage Nic

High-Level Thoughts

  • Commit to the process. If you're going to fundraise, commit to it and do it properly. You'll waste time and be ineffective if you are haphazard or non-committal about your raise.
  • Fundraising requires a ton of time and energy. You need to budget for the productivity hit. Make sure one person takes the lead to limit the distraction to your co-founders and teammates.
  • Run a tight and strategic process. Be deliberate about how you prioritize your investors and schedule them within a tight timeframe. Avoid large time gaps between your conversations; otherwise, you risk losing leverage and the ability to generate momentum.
  • Approach with an iterative mindset. Every pitch is an opportunity to understand what resonates and what doesn't. Make sure you reflect on what can be improved and don't be afraid to iterate and experiment with your pitch. (With that said, recognize that some investors simply won't get it and aren't a fit. While you should iterate, don't over-rotate.)
  • Don't be afraid of "getting to a no". Be prepared to be told "no" many times in the process. A "no" helps you move on and prioritize your other conversations. “If you receive a no, ask for feedback and be okay if they don’t respond. Every now and again, you’ll get a gem that vastly accelerates your learning.”
  • SPC is here to help you fundraise successfully. Please engage us early in the process so we can help you prepare the narrative and also help accelerate your investor intros.

Checklist for your Fundraise

  • [ ] Pitch Deck
  • [ ] Blurb & Company Description
  • [ ] Fundraise Timeline
    • Avoid Thanksgiving through New Years (late November through early January) and late summer (July and August)
  • [ ] Intro List
    • Who you plan to reach out to to help you fundraise
      • Include anyone in your network you feel comfortable asking - you never know who knows who
      • Strategizing on how introductions are made is very important. Portfolio company founders and SPC staff will be your strongest channels for intros.
  • [ ] Investor List
    • Create this spreadsheet of who you want to raise from and who will connect you to that person
    • A good starting point to create this list is from the SPC Investor Network
    • Prioritize the list (practice, Tier I and Tier 2)

Types of investors

There are many different types of investors you are going to pitch, the below will help you prioritize who you meet and when. Anchor on having some early friendlier conversations to get warmed up. Schedule your larger fund conversations near one another.

Additionally, group potential investors into tiers 1 (your tier 1 will be your target ideal investors) ,2, and 3 and reach out to 5-7 funds from tier 2 to warm up before pitching tier 1 investors. This way you can hear feedback and incorporate or pause to course-correct if there’s something weak.

  1. Friends & Family: Small check sizes (under $25k), quick closings, minimal effort.
  2. Eager Angel Investors: Check sizes not important, focus on quick investment and generating momentum.
  3. Angel Investors with Domain Expertise: Check sizes not important, look for quick movers and industry credibility.
  4. Well-Respected Angels: Closing deals with these angels increases credibility, preparation is key.
  5. Seed Firms (aka "Angel Firms"): Seek firms with previous investments, domain experts, and respected angels. Multiple meetings may be required.
  6. Series A Multi-stage VC Firms: Mainly write Series A and B checks ($5M+), variable policies on seed checks, low conversion rates. Some use seed checks to buy an option into the Series A

Proposed Timeline

6-8 weeks before first investor pitch

  1. Create a pitch outline.
    1. The outline is fine as a written one-pager. (It’s better to start with an outline to focus on the high-level narrative and content and avoid getting slowed by deck design.)
    2. Get feedback from the SPC staff on this early outline.
  2. Create or update your shareable investor blurb.
  3. Create your target investor list (you can copy this format)
    1. Include on this list people you think are your ideal investors
    2. A good starting point to create this list is from the SPC Investor Network
    3. Ask the SPC staff + other founders in SPC which other investors they would be able to introduce you to.
  4. Create spreadsheet or update your personal crm with everyone you plan to notify that you are going out to raise and will need their help

4-6 weeks before

  1. Create your pitch deck. We recommend spending a bit of time and money on deck design. Great looking slides go a long way!
  2. Start outreach to friends and network to fill out your spreadsheet with who they can help you with intros to.
    1. This spreadsheet will be public and shared with your friends and close investors like SPC, so do not use it to track notes on your meetings, create a separate CRM for you and your team only. Once you are starting connections and tracking notes on who you meet with to follow up.
    2. Keep your ask simple, clear and short. You want people to fill out their name in the spreadsheet.
      1. Sample ask: “I’m going out to fundraise in a few weeks and wanted to plan out the outreach strategy. I wanted to see if you would be comfortable making any introductions to any investors on this spreadsheet attached. My ask is if you see someone on this list that you would be comfortable introducing me to in a few weeks when I am ready, that you list your name in column E or F if you have a connection, and if you think of anyone else.”
  3. Email your partner and cc investors@southparkcommons.com to get their help filling out the spreadsheet of intros you are looking for. Present your fundraising strategy and timeline in the email.
  4. Engage with designer to take a pass on deck

2-4 weeks before

  1. Schedule a practice pitch with the SPC staff
  2. Demo product and pitch within whole SPC community with your ask being for intros to investors or customers
  3. Queue up another 5 friendly investor-like people to get real feedback on the pitch so that you go into the first round of meetings with more confidence and experience
  4. Iterate on feedback

1-3 weeks before

  1. Send out note to everyone that was willing to connect you and tell them you are kicking off the raise and ask them to introduce you to the people they agreed to. Include your blurb with the clear ask.
  2. Begin to schedule meetings in person or over zoom for dates starting the week you had planned to kick off based on intros as they come in.
    • Investors love fomo, having a busy schedule of back to back meetings over a condensed amount of time, increases the likelihood that you can drum it up.
    • Try to reply within a few hours of being connected.
  3. Create a CRM to track of all meetings and people and conversations so you know who to follow up with and don’t forget anyone

Week before first meeting

  1. Practice practice practice
    1. Do it with friends, do it with each other, do with the SPC partners

Once the meetings are kicked off

  1. Take notes on every meeting that you think is promising in your private CRM tracker
  2. Be responsive to investor emails afterwards

Additional Resources

  • Asking for an intro
    • Blurb & Company Description
    • Intro Emails
    • Elad Intro
  • Pitch Deck
    • ‣
  • Fundraising advice
    • https://www.healthtechnerds.com/articles/community-wisdom-fundraising-at-the-seed-stage
Nic

Subject: Decks
Body:
Deck Template for Seed Fundraising *Aim to have around 8 primary slides. Many decks manage to succinctly address each of these pitch topics with 1 slide per section, but sometimes you may need additional supporting slides per section. We don’t recommend having more than 3 per section.* 1. *Title:* Introduce your company with its name, logo, and a concise tagline of your elevator pitch. Think 7-10 word description, max. 2. *Problem:* Clearly articulate the pain points or importance of the problem you are addressing for your target users. Provide context to investors who may not be familiar with your industry. Demonstrate that this is a problem shared by a lot of customers == big market. If you can also indicate how much money customers may be wiling to pay, by comparing what they are paying now or other analogous comps, that will strengthen this as well. (We find you can hit on market size question here without needing an entirely separate market size section.) 3. *Solution:* Describe how your product or service solves the problem identified in the previous slide. Provide a demo or concrete screenshots. Avoid buzzwords, marketing speak and abstract terms. Investors are usually itching to understand what it is you’re building at this point. 4. *Insight:* Explain what’s driving the early traction. Share what is special about the solution and what the core insights are. We typically do not recommend competitor slides, but this is the slide to contrast yourself to other solutions. Speak to what you get right that others get wrong. 5. *Traction:* Showcase the most convincing evidence that you have a compelling solution to a hair-on-fire problem. Use graphs or data to illustrate revenue growth, user/usage growth, LOIs or PoCs, or timelines of achieved milestones and future plans. 6. *GTM Playbook:* Explain the early GTM. Who are your users? How are you finding them? What’s your unfair advantage with targeting and acquiring users? Instill confidence that this is repeatable and you know how to scale this. 7. *Future:* What’s the big vision and how big can this get? Connect the high-level dots for how you get from where this business and product are today to that big vision. 8. *Team:* Highlight why your team is the best fit to build your business. Convincingly answer the “Why You?”. While you should emphasize relevant expertise, education, work experience, or notable accomplishments in this, don’t go overboard with data. 1. Logos are great if they’re impressive 2. When talking over this slide, you should mention how you know one another The above 8 topics are the must-haves and how we would recommend ordering your pitch deck. Here are a few additional slides that you might include in the pitch (or in your appendix). - Market + Business Model: Present a bottom-up calculation of your market size along with the assumptions you've made. This slide also serves to explain your business model and revenue generation strategies to investors. [Depending on the nature of your business and how far along you are, you might move this into the main slide deck.] - Milestones + Use of Funds: Communicate the specific milestones you plan to achieve with the funding you are seeking. Investors want to see alignment between these milestones and future funding requirements. - Why Now?: Explain the recent changes in the world that have created an opportune environment for building your company, which may not have been possible in previous years. These changes could be related to regulations, technology advancements, shifting customer behaviors, or widespread platform adoption. - Sales process and sales economics: If you are a B2B company with significant revenue, consider including a slide about your sales process and relevant sales metrics such as average deal size. - Customers: For B2B companies, showcase logos and relevant information about your customers, particularly if they are well-known or recognizable. - Customer case study: Walk through a successful B2B customer's experience with your product or service, highlighting the positive impact it had on their business. - Engagement and retention: Provide statistics on user retention and engagement, particularly for consumer-focused companies. This slide can be included in an appendix if needed. - Unit economics: If your business model involves high cost of goods sold (COGS), such as labor marketplaces, hardware companies, or certain fintech companies, include relevant information about your unit economics. Nic

Deck Template for Seed Fundraising

Aim to have around 8 primary slides. Many decks manage to succinctly address each of these pitch topics with 1 slide per section, but sometimes you may need additional supporting slides per section. We don’t recommend having more than 3 per section.

  1. Title: Introduce your company with its name, logo, and a concise tagline of your elevator pitch. Think 7-10 word description, max.
  2. Problem: Clearly articulate the pain points or importance of the problem you are addressing for your target users. Provide context to investors who may not be familiar with your industry. Demonstrate that this is a problem shared by a lot of customers == big market. If you can also indicate how much money customers may be wiling to pay, by comparing what they are paying now or other analogous comps, that will strengthen this as well. (We find you can hit on market size question here without needing an entirely separate market size section.)
  3. Solution: Describe how your product or service solves the problem identified in the previous slide. Provide a demo or concrete screenshots. Avoid buzzwords, marketing speak and abstract terms. Investors are usually itching to understand what it is you’re building at this point.
  4. Insight: Explain what’s driving the early traction. Share what is special about the solution and what the core insights are. We typically do not recommend competitor slides, but this is the slide to contrast yourself to other solutions. Speak to what you get right that others get wrong.
  5. Traction: Showcase the most convincing evidence that you have a compelling solution to a hair-on-fire problem. Use graphs or data to illustrate revenue growth, user/usage growth, LOIs or PoCs, or timelines of achieved milestones and future plans.
  6. GTM Playbook: Explain the early GTM. Who are your users? How are you finding them? What’s your unfair advantage with targeting and acquiring users? Instill confidence that this is repeatable and you know how to scale this.
  7. Future: What’s the big vision and how big can this get? Connect the high-level dots for how you get from where this business and product are today to that big vision.
  8. Team: Highlight why your team is the best fit to build your business. Convincingly answer the “Why You?”. While you should emphasize relevant expertise, education, work experience, or notable accomplishments in this, don’t go overboard with data.
    1. Logos are great if they’re impressive
    2. When talking over this slide, you should mention how you know one another

The above 8 topics are the must-haves and how we would recommend ordering your pitch deck. Here are a few additional slides that you might include in the pitch (or in your appendix).

  • Market + Business Model: Present a bottom-up calculation of your market size along with the assumptions you've made. This slide also serves to explain your business model and revenue generation strategies to investors. [Depending on the nature of your business and how far along you are, you might move this into the main slide deck.]
  • Milestones + Use of Funds: Communicate the specific milestones you plan to achieve with the funding you are seeking. Investors want to see alignment between these milestones and future funding requirements.
  • Why Now?: Explain the recent changes in the world that have created an opportune environment for building your company, which may not have been possible in previous years. These changes could be related to regulations, technology advancements, shifting customer behaviors, or widespread platform adoption.
  • Sales process and sales economics: If you are a B2B company with significant revenue, consider including a slide about your sales process and relevant sales metrics such as average deal size.
  • Customers: For B2B companies, showcase logos and relevant information about your customers, particularly if they are well-known or recognizable.
  • Customer case study: Walk through a successful B2B customer's experience with your product or service, highlighting the positive impact it had on their business.
  • Engagement and retention: Provide statistics on user retention and engagement, particularly for consumer-focused companies. This slide can be included in an appendix if needed.
  • Unit economics: If your business model involves high cost of goods sold (COGS), such as labor marketplaces, hardware companies, or certain fintech companies, include relevant information about your unit economics.

Subject: Fwd: The Vector Computer Company
Body:
Seems relevant to our discussion today from a technical perspective. Got roped into hanging out with my future father-in law this afternoon. Will spin up some Notion stuff this evening. Nic ---------- Forwarded message --------- From: Tomasz Tunguz Date: Mon, Mar 18, 2024 at 11:45 AM Subject: The Vector Computer Company To: Tomasz Tunguz Venture Capitalist *If you were forwarded this newsletter, and you'd like to receive it in the future, **subscribe here.* The Vector Computer Company If you were to watch three videos on YouTube Shorts - one on Italian cooking, one on chess openings, & a third on crypto trading, YouTube Shorts’ recommendation algorithm combines the video descriptions with your dwell time. Watching the osso bucco video to its end would trigger more Italian cooking specialty videos in your feed. We believe every LLM-based application will need this capability. Combining text & structured data in an LLM workflow the right is difficult. It requires a new software infrastructure layer: a vector computer. [image: image] Vector computers simplify many kinds of data into vectors - the language of AI systems - and push them into your vector database. As Spark has become the system for transforming large volumes of data in BI & AI training, the vector computer manages the data pipelines to feed models, optimizing them for a purpose or user. Today, most vectors are very simple, but increasingly, vectors will have all kinds of data embedded in them, & vector computers will be the engines that unleash those powerful combinations. Superlinked is building a vector computer. Founder Daniel Svonava is a former engineer at YouTube who worked on real-time machine learning systems for a decade. Vector computers improve LLM accuracy by helping to surface the right data for Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG). They allow faster optimization of LLMs by including many kinds of data that can be updated quickly. Other techniques for LLM optimization require retraining or fine-tuning. These work, but take time. Standard LLM stacks of the (not-so-distant) future will leverage both RAG & fine-tuning. Superlinked is now in product preview, working with several major infrastructure partners like MongoDB, Redis, Dataiku, & others. If you’d like to learn more, click here . We’re thrilled to be partnering with Daniel & Ben. If you didn’t enjoy the email you can unsubscribe here . 3130 Alpine Road Suite 288#411 , Portola Valley, CA 94028

From: Tomasz Tunguz <blog@tomtunguz.com>
Date: Mon, Mar 18, 2024 at 11:45 AM
Subject: The Vector Computer Company
To: <nebaird.sail@gmail.com>


Tomasz Tunguz

Venture Capitalist

If you were forwarded this newsletter, and you'd like to receive it in the future, subscribe here.

The Vector Computer Company

If you were to watch three videos on YouTube Shorts - one on Italian cooking, one on chess openings, & a third on crypto trading, YouTube Shorts’ recommendation algorithm combines the video descriptions with your dwell time.

Watching the osso bucco video to its end would trigger more Italian cooking specialty videos in your feed.

We believe every LLM-based application will need this capability.

Combining text & structured data in an LLM workflow the right is difficult. It requires a new software infrastructure layer: a vector computer.

Vector computers simplify many kinds of data into vectors - the language of AI systems - and push them into your vector database.

As Spark has become the system for transforming large volumes of data in BI & AI training, the vector computer manages the data pipelines to feed models, optimizing them for a purpose or user.

Today, most vectors are very simple, but increasingly, vectors will have all kinds of data embedded in them, & vector computers will be the engines that unleash those powerful combinations.

Superlinked is building a vector computer. Founder Daniel Svonava is a former engineer at YouTube who worked on real-time machine learning systems for a decade.

Vector computers improve LLM accuracy by helping to surface the right data for Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG). They allow faster optimization of LLMs by including many kinds of data that can be updated quickly.

Other techniques for LLM optimization require retraining or fine-tuning. These work, but take time. Standard LLM stacks of the (not-so-distant) future will leverage both RAG & fine-tuning.

Superlinked is now in product preview, working with several major infrastructure partners like MongoDB, Redis, Dataiku, & others. If you’d like to learn more, click here.

We’re thrilled to be partnering with Daniel & Ben.

If you didn’t enjoy the email you can unsubscribe here.

3130 Alpine Road Suite 288#411 , Portola Valley, CA 94028

Subject:
Fwd: Grant Castillou responded to Transcending Genesis: AI and the
 New Paradigm of Consciousness
Body:
Lol, getting responses on Medium Nic ---------- Forwarded message --------- From: Medium Date: Mon, Mar 18, 2024 at 8:53 AM Subject: Grant Castillou responded to Transcending Genesis: AI and the New Paradigm of Consciousness To: Your story has a response. Grant Castillou has responded to Transcending Genesis: AI and the New Paradigm of Consciousness : [image: Grant Castillou] Grant Castillou It's becoming clear that with all the brain and consciousness theories out there, the proof will be in the pudding. By this I mean, can any particular theory be used to create a human adult level conscious machine. My bet is on the late Gerald Edelman's Extended Theory of Neuronal Group Selection. The lead group in robotics based on this theory is the Neurorobotics Lab at UC at Irvine. Dr. Edelman distinguished between primary consciousness, which came first in evolution, and that humans share with other conscious animals, and higher order consciousness, which came to only humans with the acquisition of language. A machine with only primary consciousness will probably have to come first. What I find special about the TNGS is the Darwin series of automata created at the Neurosciences Institute by Dr. Edelman and his colleagues in the 1990's and 2000's. These machines perform in the real world, not in a restricted simulated world, and display convincing physical behavior indicative of higher psychological functions necessary for consciousness, such as perceptual categorization, memory, and learning. They are based on realistic models of the parts of the biological brain that the theory claims subserve these functions. The extended TNGS allows for the emergence of consciousness based only on further evolutionary development of the brain areas responsible for these functions, in a parsimonious way. No other research I've encountered is anywhere near as convincing. I post because on almost every video and article about the brain and consciousness that I encounter, the attitude seems to be that we still know next to nothing about how the brain and consciousness work; that there's lots of data but no unifying theory. I believe the extended TNGS is that theory. My motivation is to keep that theory in front of the public. And obviously, I consider it the route to a truly conscious machine, primary and higher-order. My advice to people who want to create a conscious machine is to seriously ground themselves in the extended TNGS and the Darwin automata first, and proceed from there, by applying to Jeff Krichmar's lab at UC Irvine, possibly. Dr. Edelman's roadmap to a conscious machine is at https://arxiv.org/abs/2105.10461 View all responses As the author, you can clap for this response to make it visible under your story, so other readers can discover it. Subject: Grant Castillou responded to Transcending Genesis: AI and the New Paradigm of Consciousness
To: <nebaird.sail@gmail.com>


Your story has a response.

Grant Castillou has responded to Transcending Genesis: AI and the New Paradigm of Consciousness:
Grant Castillou

It's becoming clear that with all the brain and consciousness theories out there, the proof will be in the pudding. By this I mean, can any particular theory be used to create a human adult level conscious machine. My bet is on the late Gerald Edelman's Extended Theory of Neuronal Group Selection. The lead group in robotics based on this theory is the Neurorobotics Lab at UC at Irvine. Dr. Edelman distinguished between primary consciousness, which came first in evolution, and that humans share with other conscious animals, and higher order consciousness, which came to only humans with the acquisition of language. A machine with only primary consciousness will probably have to come first.

What I find special about the TNGS is the Darwin series of automata created at the Neurosciences Institute by Dr. Edelman and his colleagues in the 1990's and 2000's. These machines perform in the real world, not in a restricted simulated world, and display convincing physical behavior indicative of higher psychological functions necessary for consciousness, such as perceptual categorization, memory, and learning. They are based on realistic models of the parts of the biological brain that the theory claims subserve these functions. The extended TNGS allows for the emergence of consciousness based only on further evolutionary development of the brain areas responsible for these functions, in a parsimonious way. No other research I've encountered is anywhere near as convincing.

I post because on almost every video and article about the brain and consciousness that I encounter, the attitude seems to be that we still know next to nothing about how the brain and consciousness work; that there's lots of data but no unifying theory. I believe the extended TNGS is that theory. My motivation is to keep that theory in front of the public. And obviously, I consider it the route to a truly conscious machine, primary and higher-order.

My advice to people who want to create a conscious machine is to seriously ground themselves in the extended TNGS and the Darwin automata first, and proceed from there, by applying to Jeff Krichmar's lab at UC Irvine, possibly. Dr. Edelman's roadmap to a conscious machine is at https://arxiv.org/abs/2105.10461

Awesome riffing with you, sir! And thanks for sharing the Streamlit and Notion doc. It's interesting to see some similarities between your weekend app and the MVP interface I built out (which has some preset "vibe" options & a separate location filter).

I'll dig into the Notion doc and send over thoughts once I've wrapped up W&B and have some space to start thinking deeply about these ideas. Which: I actually only have 3 days left at W&B! The four weeks I mentioned today is a timebox I'm giving myself to go heads-down after W&B and code up a reasonable prototype from the MVP skeleton I've already hacked together over the past few months.

At a minimum, it'd be super helpful to get your advice on how to go about things once I have an initial prototype and am thinking about getting feedback, considering investors, rough timelines, etc. And I imagine as I shift into building mode full-time I'd come up with a few topics that'd be good to riff with you about as well, if you'd be game to read some Notion docs/do another walk 'n talk.

In the meantime, let me know if that building group comes to fruition. Sounds like a nice opportunity to spark some new ideas!

Also, tell Skyler "what up" the next time you see/shred with him. Gotta love the small world nature of SF.

Fun stuff indeed,

Hoff

Nic ---------- Forwarded message --------- From: Anna Baudreu - Château Canet Date: Tue, Mar 12, 2024 at 1:26 AM Subject: TR: Your 2025 Wedding at Château Canet To: Dear Nicholas, Thank you very much for your recent enquiry to get married at Château Canet. We are following up on your enquiry and making sure, you have received all the information you need from us and to see if you have any questions. We would love to welcome you here, and I hope the below email found you well and was helpful. Meanwhile, you can have a look at some reel weddings that happened here… Jodie + Harry Caroline + Joris Elinor + Carlin Ashleigh + Matthew As you can see, each wedding is unique and has its own vibe & style. What will be yours? If you are interested, do let us know if there is a time that would work for you to have a virtual tour. Wishing you a great week, Best regards [image: Beige Modern Minimalist Business Email Signature (4)] *De :* Anna Baudreu - Château Canet *Envoyé :* mardi 5 mars 2024 18:32 *À :* 'nebaird.sail@gmail.com' *Objet :* Your 2025 Wedding at Château Canet Dear Nicholas; Congratulations on your engagement, and thank you for your enquiry and interest in celebrating your wedding at Château Canet. We are fully booked on May 17th, 2025, but we do have more availability earlier in May and in June as well. Are your dates flexible? Château Canet offers you the opportunity to celebrate your wedding the way you want. We offer a minimum of 3 nights stay, allowing you the time to celebrate more than just your wedding. Our venue nestled between vineyards and olive groves is the perfect place for you to enjoy your nearest and dearest and create memories that will stay with you for a lifetime. Below is an overview of what is included in our exclusive rental and the information attached information will give you more details as well as an idea of weddings we have hosted and the kind of atmosphere you can create. *Accommodation for 39 guests* in 9 cottages with the possibility of an additional 9 beds. Guests can enjoy the heated swimming pool, tennis & boules courts. We can organise transport for other guests, there are local B&B’s and Carcassonne, 15 minutes away has a large choice of accommodation. *Breakfast included* for guests staying on site. *Choice of venues. *You can design your wedding around the different indoor and outdoor venues and surprise your guests at every occasion. Do note, there is no curfew! **The interior of the Château is private, but the lawn can be used for either the reception or the ceremony. We are limited to 80 guests for indoor seating (Orangerie reception hall). * *Flexible Catering*. You can enjoy anything from a gourmet French dinner, a food truck, to more informal BBQ or vineyard picnic. *Domaine wine at cellar door prices.* We offer a range of red, white, rosé & sparkling wines from 7€ to 25€ per bottle. You only pay for what is consumed. *Suppliers list.* We share our list of trusted contacts such as photographer, florist, musicians, celebrants, hairdresser, make up, transport etc. *Pre wedding weekend *allowing you to get familiar with the property and to meet your suppliers. *Unique wine activities. *Take advantage of staying on a wine estate and offer your guests a cellar tour, interactive wine tasting or blend your own wedding wine. *Wedding coordination and planning support*. This includes three meetings to discuss and share our experience on how best to plan your wedding weekend. We can help you with the ambiance, style and overall experience you are looking to create. We also help you plan your timeline and provide valuable behind the scenes support to ensure that everything runs just the way you want. *On site hosting *from the moment you arrive with a friendly face you can call on. The exclusive rental price in 2025 is 18.000€ including 3 nights’ accommodation for 39 guest and your planning & coordination support. I trust this gives you a good sense of what we offer and if you are interested I would of course be delighted to set up a call or virtual tour. We look forward to hearing back from you; Best regards Anna [image: Beige Modern Minimalist Business Email Signature (1)]

Nic

De : Anna Baudreu - Château Canet <anna@chateaucanet.com>
